number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Take a quick scroll through the negative reviews and note the "hrs on record" for each player:309 hrs clocked? Negative review. 166.6 hrs clocked? Negative review.202 hrs clocked? Negative review.272.9 hrs clocked? Negative review.257.8 hrs clocked? Negative review.Do you notice a slight pattern here? Everyone giving this game the thumbs down has spent well more than their money's worth, playing the thing. If the game really is as bad as everyone says it is, then why do they spend hundreds of hours of their lives on it? If the game was as bad as everyone attempts to make out then surely they'd play it for several hours, regret that they purchased it, give it a bad review then leave it to be nothing more than a statistical +1 on # of games they own. They don't however, they spend weeks and months playing the thing every evening/weekend and why do they do this?The answer is simple, it's not a bad game. Far from it, the game is actually very good. Rome II has had A LOT of criticism from die-hard TW fans and I can understand why. There were many bugs on release, the AI should simply be called A as it's certainly not very intelligent and I sometimes find my saved games corrupt after each update. I dislike the city building (as cool as the sharing of structures within a region is) and think they should have kept it moreso like Shogun's. I hate how the game tends to be split entirely with the Tribes (Northern Eu) and the Greeks/Romans (South Eu) as if they are only 2 different playable factions within the game. What I mean is that all of the tribes feel the same, as do all of the Greek nations. So I wish there was more diversity between nations' units and structures. Also, would it be so hard as to create just a few more character models? Seeing an army of 10,000 tribesmen all with the same face and 1 of 2 haircuts is annoying as hell.All of these things frustrate me and this game could have been a lot better but, it's certainly not a bad game that we should all be trying to discourage others from buying, such as Infestation:Survivor stories. The original TW Rome was for many TW fans, the best in the franchise so Rome II had some pretty big boots to fill and unfortunately, many people feel that because it didn't give them that nostalgia they were seeking, "the game sucked 0/10". I don't think that is at all fair.Now, is Rome 2 my favourite TW? No, it isn't. I'm not going to lie but, it's certainly worth getting if you are a TW fan, or generally someone who enjoys RTS games. The graphics are definitely the best of all the TW games to date (I don't understand why so many people seem to think Shogun 2 had better graphics, maybe their computers are too sh*te to play Rome II on a high graphical setting) and the DLC is pretty much the same old generic content that you'd expect to find (extra factions and units etc), priced at the amount you'd expect it to be.Rome II is certainly a lot easier to mod than Shogun 2 was, so if you enjoy modding then you also have that going for you, which is nice. You're actually able to hide units now as hills and trees obscure line of sight. You no longer have to be in the forest to be hidden, simply the other side of them is enough. Many units now have multiple abilities, some even passively activate themselves, such as front line melee infantry letting loose a volley of javelins before charging in to battle without your intervention. Even though the AI isn't so intelligent, I still find it much less predictable than it was in Shogun 2 and diplomacy is key to surviving on higher difficulties so, choose your allies wisely or you can find the game to be quite brutal.I've personally enjoyed all those hours that I've clocked on Rome II and will enjoy many more in the future to come. If you're unsure about it, wait until a steam sale but you should certainly get it either way, so that you too can waste hundreds of hours of your own life building an empire to span the entirety of Europe! Killing and conquering all, like a boss.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Review for Emperor Edition: All the updates leading up to and including the free Emperor Edition update have turned Rome II into a great game. They have added upgrades to the culture system, seasons and seasonal effects (both visual and in applying bonuses or penalties), campaign and battle balancing, more playable factions and units, building chain revamps (more variety of buildings and chains), and various performance improvements. The latest update, which upgrades the game to Emperor Edition for free, has modified politics and civil war in ways that are very impactful to your campaign. You have reason to constantly track your family or partys influence, having to assasinate your own generals for fear of sparking a civil war or engage in political actions to improve your influence. Failure to do so results in harsh public order and tax penalties that will really cause you problems if you dont handle your politics correctly. The update also adds improvements to the user interface (color coding various things and reworking the politics screen), although overall the ui is not as visually appealing as in previous games. It also adds the Imperator Augustus campaign, which adds the playable Armenia faction to the Grand Campaign as well. It uses the Grand Campaigns map while adding various roman factions and changes to other factions to fit the setting.Overall the game is as it should have been when it launched last september. However, the user interface still a downgrade from the beautiful Shogun 2 scrolls. You also dont get as attached to your generals as in previous games (partly due to the lack of a family tree and the minimal importance given to aquired character traits). I would have also liked to have seen the return of the system where some settlement buildings were spread out across their territories (e.g. the farms or gold mines of Shogun 2 being represented on the campaign map as potential targets). It got removed in favor of the province system and of armies using the raiding stance in enemy territory, even though both systems could have worked in tandem to greater effect. It would have also made strategic raids of provinces more interesting since you had an additional, strategic target to attack or defend besides settlements, ports or other armies.In short, the game has substantially improved since launch and the Emperor Edition is a testament to that. I give the game in its current form a solid 9/10.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Rome II had a rough start, nobody can deny that. But now that the game is done and all the DLC are out, I really enjoy it!I'm a campaing player, and thus I can't really talk too much about the multiplayer. I've done a couple of matches, but really missed the FFA aspect in it. That was my favorite thing to do in Rome, and I think it's sad that they haven't brought it back. There are a lot of factions (if you have the DLC that is) and enough diversity to keep it fun. But for more info on multiplayer you shouldn't be here, but at other reviews. Now, campaing gameplay! The begining of campaings can be a pain in the bum, but that's a good thing! But what I've noticed is that when you gain enough land and armies, you can just steamroll the rest of the map if given enough time. I haven't really played campaings above the "Hard" setting, and don't feel like playing one again, so this could prevent my problem. Multiplayer campaings are a lot of fun, but sometimes they restrict what you can do. For example in the Hannubal at the Gates DLC. If one player is Rome and the other Carthage you can't have peace. This of course is logical, but I feel like in a game you should be able to make your own choices. And before I forget, sieges are still pretty broken. Pikes on a wall etc. shouldn't be a thing!Overall a good game, would recomend it and then get the DLC on a sale. 7/10.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. I've waited till all the patches were in place. I've got all the expansions, dlcs and so forth.As a fanatic of previous Total War games (all of them, but Rome, Medieval and Shogun 2 are stand outs) I really wanted to give this game a chance too, without the bug madness and all that.I think over 100 hours of gameplay is more than a fair chance.PROS:- The game runs fast on the highest settings.- The units are detailed.- The UI is convenient enough.- The campaign map is nice, realistic and not too cumbersome.- The army specific traits are a nice addition.- The graphics, on highest settings, are very nice to look at.- Plenty of mods make the game slightly better.CONS- The Game has been stipped down to bare bones.- The AI is laughable at best, both strategically and tactically.- Family trees are gone.- Diplomacy is completely void.- No matter what difficulty the game is too easy (as Rome I've conquered the whole map in less than 100 turns).- Units lose formation, every battle turns into a brawl, or a mosh pit at best.- As long as you field the heaviest infantry possible you win everything.- from a tactical standpoint, all battles are the same, once you have defended a camp, or a city, or attacked a camp, or a city you have seen everything there was to see.- Naval combat is a sad joke.- Even the units and buildings icon look cheap.- The technology tree is non sensical.- City building is limited to a maximum of 6 buildings (usually 4-5) in capital provinces.- Every faction looks different but behaves the same way.Overall 4/10Yes, the game is playable, not buggy (as of April 2015), and looks great. Too bad it's not funny, there's no sense of achievement, and a total failure in terms of strategic and tactical play. Huge let down.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												The game delivered on so many bases it was a shame that it fell flat on its face during the others. Huge battles that play out for more than an hour real time give you a real sense of achievement when you win and a great pit of disappointment when you are crushed. The graphics are truly amazing… until you have a battle which has more than 20units each side fighting. Of course if you have an NVidia Titan or 780Ti, this probably will not be a problem but if you don’t the chances are you will have to lower the GFX right down and play in permanent slow mode. The price tag is still a little high on this game at $79.99 – considering you will be made to pay for extras such as blood and gore. Although it has an almost unlimited amount of play time capturing all the continents from Europe to Asia, I’d have only paid $40 at most knowing then what I do now.  My advice would be wait for this one to go on sale and double check your hardware. Don’t go by the recommended requirements as it will likely not deliver the proper gameplay for this good game.

												I have played all but one of the Total War games and I think this is a great addition. My only complaint is that diredting units on the battlefield can still be clunky but no more so than the other games in the series and in fact I would say it is a bit better in this edition than others. It seems fairly well optimized for my PC, but I did have to turn down some of the graphics settings for the big battles when I had troop number maxes out. I run a GTX 760 though and I imagine if you have a 900 series card you should be able to play all maxed out. I got 121 hours of play out of this and did not even do the last scenario in Sparta. I may play that campaign later after a break, 121 hours and I think I have had enough for a bit, lol! I recoomend you get this game if you like the other games in the series. I had a great time with this.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												There's two kinds of those who write the reviews on Rome II - those who played original Rome and those who didn't. For those who didn't played it is a good, epic strategy. For those who played - it is a strange (not to say ugly) ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of Rome and Warcraft.Endless bugs, absence of the family tree, taking cities without siege weapons, buttons that magically replenish energy, drunken brawl instead of clever tactics - there's much said about all of this, no need to repeat. All this rage is not about bugs, it's about game mechanics, that became RTS in a bad meaning of the term.Particular word about music - it is... wait, is there music already? I'm don't remember. I remember Jeff van Duke's soundtrack in Rome till now, but soundtrack in Rome II - it's a pitiful attempt to depict something epic.Little secret - Rome II Emperor Edition - it is, in fact, final release of the game. First release was alpha, that was released without disclaimer that it is an early access. But whatever, the game is a fail. 6/10, and only for merits of the previous games (excluding Empire, that was also fail). Summary - I was foolish enough to preorder this. In future, I'll buy CA products on 80% sale... maybe.P.S. Wait... CA is developing Alien Isolation? Well, gentlemen, it's the end of the Total War series.

number of helpful: 25 of 46 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game has bugs and it does have features that weren't the smartest move since Shogun 2; however, the game has a fun factor that trumps all of its downfalls.CA implemented certain features in this total war game that will make it harder to play older TW games, and they did in fact put in more beneficial and simpler features than poorly implemented ones.  The game suffers from AI problems and other misc bugs, and I feel it's not nearly as polished as Shogun 2 (one of the most polished TW games after expansions/patching imo), but it has a way better campaign, factions, unit rosters, building/culture rosters, and other features that make it a lot more fun than Shogun 2.I wrote a positive review about Shogun 2 before, claiming it to be the best TW game released ever, and while that's true for the most polished and bug-free total war ever, I feel that Rome 2 will become the better game if it continue to be patched positively.So in summary, I feel Shogun 2 is the better polished and bug-free game.  Rome 2 is the more fun game and better campaign with more interesting units.  It just needs help to improve and polish it.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												At this state, the game seem way more polished compared to the clusterfock that was at release. However, doesn't feel an inprovement at all with respect Rome, or other Total War games. After finishing the grand campaign here are my feelings:-This is a couple of things that they have done better but fall into nothingThe political intrigue is more deep now than the mechanics with the shogun, the pope, or the 3 rome factions. However, is completely worthless. I have spend millions of talens to secure promotions, I have only active my family generals, and adopt and bribe any other character, and still I only have a 35% maximum of the senate control. The civil war meter hasen't move from 0 in the entire campaing.The thing about the provinces seems like a good idea, you can also build into several settlements at a time which is nice. But doesn't seem to have a significant bonus. The province control seems rather useless other than the own satisfaction of sorting your own stuff in an arbitrary matter. You can't even interchange settlement in the diplomatic view to complete provinces.-One thing that is actually an improvement respect Rome.The art style is fantastic. It quite similar to Shogun 2 in regard of placing you into the historical settting. Not so much the music though; not bad, but not good neither.-Other than than the game falls flat in many aspect.The AI is horrible. Is worse than other TW games. Most of the naval battles are the enemy waiting there doing nothing. And the diplomatic interchange is just silly. I have multiple faction declaring war on me, only to surrender in the next turn and giving me 5000+ talens in compensation without even having a battle.The combat seems simplify respect other titles. I remember using way more siegue weapons, archers, hoplites and lancers, and their respective special moves. In here I don't have a feeling of actually having to do anything on the battlemap. And to make things worse, the last tier lancers are replaced with swordmans preators, which are cool and nice, but albeit no sustitue for a spear wall.Another thing that I have no idea what is for, the victory/strategy points in the battle map. Previously, if you loose the plaza, you loose the settlement. Now nothing happens. there is a flag that goes up and down but it has no consequence. The only thing that you can use it for is to capture gates and towers, but nothing else.There are bad things with the IU. For example now you can click and draw a unit where what should happen, and what happened before is that you will make a square for multiple selection, and this is quite annoying actually. Another thing is that the tactical map in the continent view doesn't draw the icon if you zoom too much; why?? doesn't make any sense. The diplomatic view could also be mix with the tactical view, they are pretty much the same. When you click a general to figure it out the family you need to click in another 3 menu and look for him manually. The artifact bonus thing, I got 50+ extra at the end of the campaign without use. And I haven't figure it out yet how to build the coliseum. And the slums are horrible and annoying, there is no way to have a multiple settlement view to tell you where are space available and you need to look for them manually or else the slums will pop-up.And finally, the DLC market strategy and promotion/spam aspect of the game is not acceptable. There is a constant reminder to "buy this other cool stuff" all over. Just leave me alone!

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Looked forward to this game but it ended up being a disappointment.  They shouldn't have tried to fix things that weren't broken.  I've played TW games since the original Shogun, my favorite being Medieval II Total War, which improved greatly upon it's predecessors. Medieval II TW was intuitive.  Unfortunately Rome II was clunky and far from intuitive.  The interface seemed to be a random hunt and peck setup, scattered throughout the screen in a chaotic order.  Many details that added color to M2TW were removed from Rome 2 and then things that created nothing but tedium were added. The unit cards were larger than necessary yet gave no way to know the exact number of troops in a unit by looking at them; you have to guesstimate.  The creators also decided to use a mimicry of old Roman art instead of more appealing and identifiable pictures:  I feel that was an aesthetic, if not functional, mistake.   Management of settlements and provinces was limited and yet clunky.  Most everything is based off fighting penalties and not gaining bonuses.  Overall control leaves much to be desired, yet the AI factions, of course, flourish without fail or penalty. Attilla looks like it made some improvements although it uses much of the same flawed system, so perhaps I would suggest playing that one over Rome 2, but honestly I have not had enough game time on Attilla to accurately commit to that suggestion.All I can say is that Rome 2 has been painfully dissapointing to me, and I write that with sadness as a TW fan.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												why didn't they just improve the classical Rome total war.. with better graphics and physics.. that's all.. why did they have to make like.. a totaly different game? I was betrayed! I hope many people will pirate this game! It's boring.. i can't personaly attach my self to anything.. it's so.. blend and it feels casual.. but the map is huge and you just force yourself to "conquer" it .. I found my self fighting with feelings like "hey.. it has amazing graphics.. yeh, but fighting kinda sux.. I know, but look at the new politics now.. I see but i liked the old ones more.. Hey you can poison a well in the village.. sure, but where are the family trees.. i'd like to LIKE someone! .. You can upgrade your generals... But they feel IMPERSONAL.." I even tried to get drunk and play like i'm used to play Rome 1 .. oh .. it doesn't work.. it just p....... me more! Fights are joke.. it feels like the soldiers are just standing or walking.. eventually i see a duel.. and it's like instant K.O. In Rome 1 there were so many sweet moments and soldiers were swinging swords, making damage to enemies.. thats fine with me.. i don't need a duels if it means that those are going to be happening ocassionaly, while others are just running around waiting for one enemy to "join" a duel. Im so sad i paid that much money, then waited so long for updates.. and now it still feels like ... some generic game about romans that you play few times and forget.. I love Rome 1 and tried to love Rome 2.. but no.. i can't fake feelings.. It looks nice.. good graphics.. enemy react to you ..he can kick you behind.. but that was happening in Rome 1 too and it was obvious part of the game.. so much hyp for this. I'd like to see my city im building, it was possible in R1, You could recognize individual buildings too..  or i'd like to know that one of my generals is a drunker! i miss those things, it was original! you know what.. im going to pull out my old dusty Rome 1 DVD and Im going to go back to the past... again.. just like I do with 98% of the modern games that come out in last 3 years! that's it, Im not buying any modern games! I have spent soooo much money for a stroooong and powerful PC and all for nothing...PS: message to developers: we, the gamers, are not dummies, please, don't implement stuff that simplifies games, because all the fun and thrill is gone and we, the gamers, will stop buying Your boring games..

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I love the Total war series but I can't for my life enjoy Rome 2.This is the third time I've given the game a chance and I thought I'd play it as you're "supposed to", as a Roman.The whole game is hindered by it's terrible, uninformative UI design that is more confusing than helpful.Sea battles are horribly clunky, unresponsive and just plain annoying. Also, ramming is the way to go, over and over again until everything dies. it feels like the AI cheat. I had a province rebel at me, they attack it unguarded and managed to size controll with a minor force which took quite heavy casualties. The next turn I engaged the same army with around 1k troops only to be faced by 1800 which had suddently magically appeared. And the Rebels where more trained than my standing army!  Later on I dealt with rebels, took the city back but had to fight public disorder which I couldn't lower in any way. So I ended up in war with neighbouring countrys, moved my army away from the town and BAM! New rebel army stormed in and sized controll once again without any kind of warning.Then Carthago attacked.I sailed out to engage one of their minor fleets. Didn't have the movement point to engage them two meters away from port for unknown reason so my fleet stopped in the middle of the ocean, surrounded by enemy fleets. This is when I notice that the army I'd told to garison the town, was loaded on ships following my fleet. I had never told them to load onto the boats at any time during the campaign. Needless to say, it was a slaughter.And this is a few turns after I tried for several turns to get another army onto another fleet but couldn't do it for unknown reason again. It's so frustratingly unintuative, uninformative, cluttered and clunky that I can't even play for an hour without tearing my hair. And on top of that, the whole game look like two steps backwards in graphical quality compared to Shogun 2. I seriously can't understand how they ♥♥♥♥ed up so badly on every level when you look at their last game!

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Not a bad game by any stretch but definitly a step-down from Total War : Shogun 2 and the Fall of the Samurai. There is a huge map with large number of opponents but it all feels more oppressive than grand. If you're willing to put a hundred or so hours into the game it will most probably be rewarding but as there is no short-campaign option, more time-challenged gamers will find this too slow paced. The need for large investments of time in each game you play means that it can be almost impossible to see why one faction differs from another (apart from starting position) as the bonuses don't add up to large gains very quickly.The unit cards used as displays for what is in your army don't differ enough and the user interface is unusually cluttered without actually revealing any more information than the previous games in the series did. All in all it means the user will have to have a very long look at the game's encyclopedia before any action takes place. The parent company, Creative Assembly, have continued to release patches for this game but have also continued charging a high price ($80 AUSD base game + $7 AUSD for factions/unit packs +  $14+AUSD for campaigns) coupled with core-game features needlessly hidden behind DLC (Blood and Gore, All the faction packs for the grand campaign). Imperetor Augustus campaign is a good free DLC and there should have been more for free up to the point of writing this. Overall 2.5/5 - The tighter combat and map design in Shogun 2 was more to my liking. I live in a place in Australia were online play is unstable so I can't comment on this game's multiplayer.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												8 major patches and a mini-expansion later...it is perhaps the right time to review this.When it came out earlier in the year Rome II was a huge disappointment, it had been the game I had been most looking forward to for most of the year, the next iteration in a series I enjoyed immensely and a game I had specifically bothered to upgrade my PC for.On release the game was straight up broken, everything from AI and key gameplay mechanics to turn times and performance was quite simply a mess. Some people argued that it was to be expected from Creative Assembly and was no worse than empire however having played both games (and all the ones in-between) on release I would disagree and say it was actually worse simply because of how poor some of the underlying political systems were along with my own views on some of the directions taken (most significantly the removal of family trees and adoption of one turn per year). Basically to me the game wasn't just broken....it was bad.There is no doubt that within the last 3-4 months Rome II has improved significantly, so much so that I would argue it is actually a fun and playable Total War game. Performance is now at least on par with what you would expect from a demanding PC game, the AI has seen a number of improvements and while not problem free it is more capable and responsive on both the campaign and battle map. The amount of small tweaks implemented have also made the user experience much better including removing the performance tanking 'ghost' unit icons and adding numbers onto the unit cards. More promising mechanical changes have also started to be implemented including modifications to the culture and recruitment systems within the last patch.A huge part of Rome II becoming more enjoyable to play is due to the work of the community and the various free mods developed for the game, adding the steam workshop on release is probably one of the best moves that CA made with Rome II. While not averse to applying mods I generally like a more 'vanilla' experience however Rome II is an exception and I could not imagine playing without 2 turns per year, unit icon and Trait overhaul mods.Despite improvements and mods issues still remain with Rome II, the political systems are obviously half baked and lacking in explanation, the game relies on far too many unit buffs and incremental improvements which are sometimes put behind other systems which despite having played 40+ hours still make next to no sense ('Gravitas', 'Authority', 'Cunning' etc). The AI still displays moments of utter stupidity or non-responsiveness, especially in sieges which will hopefully be further improved upon by patches. I would also say that despite tweaks the 'blobbing' of units is still a big problem, this may be more down to the lack of unit object collision detection that is inherent to the engine CA is now using but units still have a rather nasty tendency to morph into a single compacted blob which doesn't always make for interesting battle mechanics.So overall...I would be willing to recommend Rome II. I think it is somewhat helped by the fact that the time period is probably the most suited and interesting it could be for the series but the game has also improved a lot since release and will hopefully continue to do so. A complete revamp of the political systems along with a re-implementation of the family tree would be highly appreciated however I do not expect this to take place until the inevitable retail expansion. Up until that point we have a fairly flawed but nonetheless fun and working experience that will hopefully be improved upon further into 2014.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Review of Emperor Edition/Patch 15 in comparison to Rome 1Battles and SiegesBattles last much longer than Rome 1 and with the inclusion of new features like Line of Sight, Rome II's battles more engaging and generally better. Javelins are devastating if left to do their thing, cavalry if used correctly does exactly what it should, and top tier troops can last a VERY long time.The battlefield AI is on occasion outstanding. On these occasions it can leave you gobsmacked. The AI's usage of Line of Sight and it's ability to wait until the right moment in defensive battles is particularly impressive. Siege AI is passable and often very good, it is good enough but still needs work mainly to resolve ongoing glitches.Oh, and most of the magic abilities are gone :)CampaignWhile the styling and design of the campaign mechanics are up for debate, Rome II's less clinical approach to empire manangement is on the whole more involving, much more maleable and less predictable.In Emperor Edition public order is more complex to balance, and also much more changable. Seasons, wars and other factors can contributed to large changes and overall it is much more complex to manage than previous games - which used 1 single attribute for this - population. Rome II's system is more complex and fickle, and for me this is a good thing. In Rome II you will find yourself destroying buildings and redesigning entire provinces often, something I have never done in previous games.Steamrolling is a thing of the past in Emperor Edition - Creative Assembly have finally reduced player income to sane levels, a good player can still make a lot of money, but no way near as much as in the past/previous games. Late and mid game will be much better now.The updated Civil War/Politics mechanics now actually does something, which is good, but the system as a whole is still in my honest opinion nothing more than a polished placeholder with glaring ommisions, such as dynasties/families - no longer can your character have long lasting bloodlines where their offpring inherit traits, like in Medieval 2 for example.Visuals and PerformanceThe game looks and performs very well with a few exceptions - like when a gate is on fire with a lot of men around it, or when thousands of bodies litter the battlefield.There are a LOT of units in Rome II, but because of the sheer massive amount of factions (around 150 in the grand campaign) many factions and cultures can start to feel a bit 'samey' - hopefully we will see further unit/faction packs/freelc's to remedy this. Overall i'm very happy with visuals and performance.SCORE8.5/10 - A great Total War game.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Great game, exactly what you want from the TW series. Continues the long line of grandcampaign inovation that we have enjoyed from the series. Some of the minor factions lack distinct units and as a result can feel like blah. However, the historical major powers are great. Seige play has always something that bothered me about the series because there was not incentive to attack. You could starve out the units and not suffer any damage to your stack. This game fixes that with both sides suffering attrition. As a result you have decent seige fights now. Furthermore, stacks of units regen per turn so you don't have disband and send up replacements.  This make upgrading more desirable as the units produced can surrvive for many campaigns making the turns to build improvements finally cost effective. Before in rome 1 having three more stacks of legions built was always better then a 4 turn upgrad as bigger armies always won an gained you more income.  This is no longer a issue.I don't agree with the "army limt" but, it does slow snowballing and allows for epic battles bettween larger empires later into the campaign. Bugs: Mostly ironed out, but some strange AI behavior on the battlefield. In my opinon its not that bad but keep in mind i'm a  fan of the series so I'm used to Rome 1's staionary army bug where you had to wait 45 minutes for the batttle to end.

												This game failed across all levels. Gameplay is poor most of the factions are unavailable unless you buy dlc that should have been part of the main game to beginw ith. Unit blobs to much and inability to give certain commands like stopping pila from being thrown. Animations of units break down rapidly into poorly constructed affrais testudo appear slike magic rather than disciplined troops forming up. Huge step back from Shogun 2 which was a step forward. This game should only be bought for 75% off from an already reduced price. Side note maybe by the end of 2014 it will be playable unmoded and maybe the opus it was suppossed to be rather than the rushed♥♥♥♥♥♥it is. Creative Assembly and Sega have had only excuses rather than admiting they failed in their promise. They as way of apology only offered one DLC for free and only for a short window as recompence so be weary of this game and those that made it.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I will say. This game was a complete let down. I've been a total war fan since the original Shogun Total War to Shogun 2 Total War... I have purchased every total war game you can name. I thought Empire Total War was my biggest let down until I invested 63 hours of my own time in a constant repeat of the same turn over and over again... hoping it would work its self out. I have invested 812 hours of my time into Shogun 2 Total War which to this day I still love. My last few hundered hours I'd play with my buddy(s) and we would constantly talk about awaiting the release of Rome 2. How awesome Rome 2 will be. How we will conquere the ancient roman era.... Instead we constantly have desync issues.... We can't even manage to get through a fifth of our campaign.... before we have to trash it and attempt another. I am now at the point I don't even intend on attempting another coop campaign with anyone and actually look at just uninstalling the game all together. I love playing Total War Games.... Ever since Shogun 2.... I can't play a Total War campaign alone.... It isn't the same with out your buddy.... no matter how many minutes they take to go through with their turn. If your a kind of person who enjoys playing by your self on a game.... by all means buy it.... but if your looking at taking over the world with your best friend.... then there is no reason to attempt the game. Sorry for the let down ladies and gentlemen.....

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												Here is the review for Rome 2 from a real fan of series since Shogun (First), and i must add, my favourite was not the First Rome like many others instead i favored Medieval 2 greatly.This one, even with some new good ideas especially for coop playing,  is the worst one in the whole series. The most empty , divided , broken , vane  total-war experience you ever had and they try to sell you pieces of the game which undoubtedly should be in the game, such as greek cities, as dlc's. I don't want to go into details of AI (Artificial Idiotism) in this game , since many other already mentioned about it in great detail. I understand nobody loves micro-managing stuff these days but everything is streamlined in this game now to the point of no strategy. (This is where you should stop reading.)Most unit fights goes like one-vs-ones, only important thing is their stats or tiers (or if theyre pikes, chariots, elephants there is no contest) and you will know which one will win for sure, no place for randoms, if somehow this does not bore you down, you can always get amazing siege ai seizures and if you wait long enough, legolas'(plural) at your towers will crush your enemy,  best part is, you will win even if they don't bother, since the ai will be sending its troops mostly by 2s or 4s. (and i must also add, the autoresolve engine would be telling you "oh boy you're so dead"). As soon as you go co-op with your best pal, you will encounter MORE GAME CRASHING BUGS (incredibly yeah, more than single player), like being stuck in diplomacy screen with not working escape button and no interaction at all, slow-mo battles, slow-mo after battle miniature duel. When you ask your ally to your aid, and if he/she had client states or satrapies, they will refuse the call most of the time, since the call is made by you , not by your ally and since they refuse to join a war their masters joined , their status as client state / satrapy , will end, with a revolt against your ally.Oh and i really can't believe how my cavalry still unable to pursue fleeing enemies properly! C'mon CA that problem is there since your first game!Months past since the first release, many patches released, its much more playable than it was but most of the issues still remain, people mostly play it with mods, fan boys still defend, but at least they don't assume that this will be a better game than its predecessors anymore. Still, who wants to play this?After Shogun 2, this is a disaster. A MAJOR step-down from CA.Do Not Buy until its price drops considerably then buy if you're a fan of the series.BEWARE this game is way worse than Empire, at least in Empire they created a whole new approach to TW from scratch, which laid the foundation for highly praised Shogun 2 and Napoleon.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This is the first review I have ever written, and probably the last one. But I am so disappointed with this game that I feel that I must do it. As you can see in my profile, I have been trying desperately through hours and hours of playing, to make this game enjoyable, remembering how wonderful and superb this saga was with Rome I and Medieval 2. If I had never known and played his two predecessor (rome I and Medieval 2), I think I should have enjoyed rome 2, but I knew them and I loved them. Then, the question is inevitable: how can Rome 2 be such a big failure? (yes, it is a big failure, no matter how more patches you bring). Here is my answer directly to Creative Assembly: - DO NOT RELEASE a BROKEN GAME. I can forgive you the first time, with EMPIRE, but AGAIN AND AGAIN this is a JOKE. - If you do NOT KNOW to CODE a  IA to build correctly buildings so they do not auto-kill starving each of his armies… DO NOT ADD this feature to the game!. Or just make the IA CHEAT and give it infinite FOOD!.- IF I play Rome, I expect to fight cataphracts of Partia, or phalanx from Macedon, not ALWAYS LEVY Pikemen, LEVY archers, LEVY swordsmen…  AGAIN, If you DON´T KNOW how to CODE a decent AI, make it CHEAT so they can SPAWN ELITE units.  - Reconsider about making strategy games with the absolutely brain-insanity features like: 	- If I AMBUSH an enemy army I can only use ONE army. (I usually force march my armies to engage IA armies one to one..  It´s crazy!). 	- A spy can poison an entire army of elite+veteran units with a high chance. Where´s the epic in that?. I wan´t “TOTAL WAR”!!!. 	- A spy/diplomat/heroe can´t STOP my army from moving from turn to turn. Where´s the epic in that???. I wan´t TOTAL WAR!!!. 	- …  don´t make me continue… Finally, I must say, because it is true, with all this flaws and design errors, this is a 7/10 game. But as I have written at the beginning, I will always remember Rome 1 and Medieval 2, and I KNOW how GOOD it COULD HAVE BEEN if you have done your work correctly. You have FAILED us, your hardcore fans, and you have FAILED…. HORRIBLY…   And there is nothing you can´t say or apologies to give to erase that in my memory. Please, I beg you, learn the lesson, and try to live and work true to the legacy of games like Rome 1, Medieval 2, Shogun, ….

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Total War: Rome 2 is now over a year old, if you are like me and you are a huge fan of the series there is a large chance you got the game when it came out, heavy disappointment probably ensued afterwards from a game that was buggy, broken and un-optimised compiling together to make a mess of a game.After about a month after the games came out, fixes and patches started to roll out slowly fixing the broken game. I played the game for a good 70 hours during the broken stages of the game playing the game as they fixed it slowly adding to my enjoyment as the game was slowly fixed. However I had a very long hiatus of the game around July time till a few month ago and If we fast forward to 2014 the game got its “official debut” in the form of the Emperor edition or as I like to call it, “The version we meant to make” it’s taken me from a game I found hard to recommend only to those who are hardcore Total War fans willing to wait out the storm to now I can highly recommend this game to those who enjoy the types of games however I have to make clear there are much better entries in the series.The game is a successor to the first and probably greatest Total War game, Rome. Set in the same time period however now you have a hell of a lot more factions to choose from 117 factions, with say about 20 of those been playable of the top of my head including the DLC factions. The game also boasts a few very good campaign DLC with my personal favourite been Wrath of Sparta and Hannibal at the Gates, but each to his/her own if you choose to purchase them along with the faction DLC.Gameplay:The game runs just like all the games before it with a few new game changing implements such as: now Armies are formed under a general, you can’t make random armies and you only have a limited number of generals and fleets that is based on your successes of your empire in the form of prestige. Personally I like this new addition, it makes the game a little harder but does slow down the pace of majorly large factions but adds a tactical edge to the planning of your empire. The problem with this however is smaller, one settlement factions can afford to somehow field a huge, massive one General armies meaning fighting those small settlements is a dreadful thing to have to do time and time again, but I personally think this is to make the game harder so I can tolerate it and with the pace of the game by the time you are 50 turns in large factions already start to appear and that’s when large wars ensue. Another new feature is the region system, now each region has one large settlement and 2 to 3 smaller non-walled settlements. At first I hated this as you can’t add walls to all settlements making it feel like I’m not in controlled of my cities as much as I wanted but later I grew to like this idea for spicing up the game options and means I have to choose my buildings wisely. Overall I love all the additions to the games apart from Slums, Slums and go fornicate themselves but slums are easily avoided just make sure you build in empty slots before they appear.Graphics:The graphics of the game are very well done, at the time of launch for the scale of the game I saw it to be a very beautiful game and even now I think the games graphics are done very well, my full system specs can be seen on my Profile however I have a TITAN Z with a 2560x1440 monitor at 144Hz and the game runs at about 30fps to highs of 90fps however I would still like to see some better optimization in the game as I feel they can do this. The graphics of the game really help sell the environments and atmospherics of the game from the African deserts to the green forests of Europe. I would agree with some that the graphics are not as promised but if I’m honest I don’t remember what we were promised and enjoy the graphics regardless.The games rocky start means I wasn’t very happy with Creative Assembly who I always saw as a very high end professional PC developer who have created flawless games in the past but let’s hope they have learned from this.I can personally now highly recommend Total War: Rome 2. Pros-	Beautiful looking game-	Classic Total War-	Easy level of complex and simple RTS management-	Lots of FactionsCons-	Game can be very easy even on Legendary-	Game still needs some optimization in graphics-	Slums -.--	One region factions have huge armies compared to there size

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Having been a fan of the TW series ever since Shogun 1 I simply couldn't miss Rome II. So after waiting for a while to have some major bugs fixed, I finally decided to give the game a try.The first thing I noticed at a faction choosing screen is that there were no hints as to what military strengths and special units each faction has, like in previous games. A minor disappointment, but a disappointment nonetheless.So, after the game loaded I proceeded to make my first turn. I've always been taking my sweet time in such games, but even then I was surprised that my very first turn took a whole hour. The reason is a completely new interface (minimization is being popularised too much for my tastes in the later years), new features, and the lack of some old ones. After that one hour I decided to play the prologue first, which took me 10 hours, by the way, and didn't explain any of the things I wanted to find out.So, what's there to notice in general:* You can't hire units without a general, nor you can move your armies without one. No more quick reinforcements from the heart of your empire. No more splitting your army to catch up to some weaker enemy armies with your cavalry. Speaking of which, I didn't notice a type of units affecting the overall army speed like in previous games, where hiring a siege weapon greatly reduced the army speed. But maybe that's just me.* Diplomacy has been significally cut. No more political marriages between the factions, no open map trade, no city trade. The only way to get a settlement in Rome II is to capture it, you can't purchase it from other factions anymore.* Several close-located settlements form provinces now. Each province consists of a city, where you can build your most advanced buildings, and 1-3 villages. Happiness is spread throughout the settlements you own in that province. Culture is spread throughout the whole province no matter how many factions own it. Which, in turn, can make alliances a little less effective, because you would obviously aim at owning provinces in whole, without having your ally spreading his culture to your cities, thus affecting a public happiness.* You can't adjust tax rates for each province exclusively anymore. The tax rate is the same throughout your faction. The only thing you can do is to exclude a province from tax collection.* There is no more faction family tree. Totally. The ony people your faction consist of are generals, admirals, and senators, which are fully interchangeable (a general can become an admiral, then a senator, etc.), and there is no confirmation as to whether they are even blood related.* Agents have become more useful. The main reason to that is because they can't die during a mission. At all. The worst thing that could happen to your agent after a failed assassination attempt is the agent being wounded and coming back to work in a couple turns. The only ways to lose an agent are him being assasinated or manipulated with an enemy agent. By the way, manipulating enemy dignitaries to join you is somewhat strange. I managed to capture a druidess and have her spread Latin culture the very next turn. Really?..* Even after so much time since the release of the game it has still got a lot of bugs. So don't be surprised if you get a critical error after winning a long and tough battle.The overall rating:If you are a fan of TW series, I'd still recommend to play Shogun 2 instead. Too many features have been stripped, not many new added in their place. But if you are new to the series and have nothing to compare it to, the game itself is good enough to spend a couple weeks on.

number of helpful: 21 of 39 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I've been a HUGE total war fan for over 10 years. I've played Creative Assembly's games for 100s upon 100s of hours. Rome 1 was legendary! Medieval 2 was grand! Shogun 2 was beautiful! Rome 2 is................ the product of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, stupid, ugly and lack of creativity (oh the irony) all smashed into one. HOW DID THIS HAPPEN CA?I will put this review in different categories. I will compare this product to other total war games. (My playthroughs have been on the hardest difficulty.)The campaign: You start of as a small faction with a limited amount of armies. As you capture more and more cities you get stronger. Pretty basic for a strategy game isn't it? However... you'd expect the AI doing the same right? So you wont steam-roll the whole map once you get strong enough to do so. In shogun 2 there would be atleast 3 other factions in the endgame who would give you a challange. In rome 2 this never happens! Not even a single great empire rises. The AI is almost non-existant! Its like playing chess against a 2 year old!The battles: Where you are supposed to have the most fun! THE BATTLES! It is here where you the tacitical mastermind can shine! And yes! you do shine! ALL THE TIME! Is it because you outsmarted the AI? YES! and no... Outsmarting the AI in this game is like outsmarting a potato. Either the AI doesn't move at all (mostly this happens in sieges) or the AI do the most stupid moves not even you can think of.          Does the battles look epic? yes kinda. The projectiles look awesome! how the stick to the shields, bodies and bounce off things. But the actuall melee look like a mess. soldiers rubberbanding all over the place and bugging out. Soldiers now only fight 1vs1. Which is a downgrade from Rome 1. that game was made 10 YEARS AGO! In rome 1 armies clashed realisticly. In rome 2 armies clash and morph into a huge epileptic seizure. Graphics: The graphics is good. It isn't outdated or anything... but compared to Shogun 2 it is basicly nothing. Shogun 2 had great lighting effects, an amazing set of colors, beautiful water effects and so on. Rome 2 have all that completely removed. They've put in some cool facial animations... or so they say. Never really seen it. other than their mouths opening and closing from time to time. Last words: This game is build upon a game engine designed for Empire total war. That shows. the projectiles works great! But that's about it... The melee was never a key focus for this engine. And thus the battles look stupid and kill immersion as soon as armies clash. If you haven't been a total war fan you might find this game fun. If you are a total war fan and know what this series can do.... then... You will be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ As many fans are.

number of helpful: 26 of 49 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												During the rather buggy launch, I was quite unhappy with Rome 2, I had FPS issues even on low settings which made the great looking campaign map a pain to go through, all the models had stupid faces and the naval combat was terrible. But the game has been patched alot now and I feel it's a better game than what it was but it still could be better.Campaign Map:The map during the turn based sections is incredible, the Hyperbolic terrain really makes the different areas feel truely different. It is also huge, From Western spain all the way to Iran in the east - although it isn't as big geographically as the Empire: Total War map, it does feel alot bigger. It would have been alot better with seasons though, which should have been put in there anyway. The cities are huge on the map and you can expand them to fit more buildings but this is so rarely used and the animation is so short that it isn't that important. Foreign nations in the game are way too peaceful, in my Current campaign as the Roxolani on Very Hard I have been declared war on only once right at the beginning of the campaign, In my first campaign as Rome I didn't lose 1 city throughout to the whole campaign on normal and I don't think any nation declared war on me at all, It does get very boring after a bit so I'd advise playing on harder difficulties. The A.I. also very annoyingly requests stupid things for insane amounts of money which makes ending the turn a pain as you can't just leave it for a bit because it gets stuck on them diplomatic requests.Battle:The battles in this compared to the other Total wars are fast; Units brake quite quickly so I find myself using the slow motion sometimes just to command my troops quick enough. The A.I. is quite stupid still - especially in sieges, E.G. they run to the front of the gates sometimes and just stare at it whilst being cut down by archers. The battles aren't particuarly hard either, in my Roxolani campaign and my Rome Campaign I could defeat armies twice the size of mine with just simple flanking and skirmishing as the Roxolani or just standing in formation and letting the opponents attack whilst doing obvious flanking manoeuvers as Rome. The Terrain and the models during the battles do look great and the fighting animations seem ok, but again, they happen too fast so you don't really see them.Creative Assembly (or SEGA) acting like EA:With all these DLC's Creative Assembly is basically screwing people over. Paying to get factions which should be there for free is insane. The series does seem to be going downhill. An Example of these terrible choices is the Blood and Gore DLC, it should have been an option in the main game already! This sort of stuff is that DLC Quest mocks and it is a shame because Total war is one of my favourite franchises.I really can't decide whether to reccomend this or not as it isn't that bad of a game, but I know it could have been so much more. If you are going to buy it wait for a big sale or a proper price drop. This game does get alot of hate and I understand why, but I still enjoy it as it is still a Total war game, but I feel this game is good by its franchise heritage but not its individuality. If you don't have Shogun 2 or any other Total war games and want a Total war game, get Shogun 2 first, then the others.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												After playing for 500+ hours, I can only say this is the worst game in the series. Half the features that made the previous Total War games epic were removed (Family tree, seasons, deep character building, agent videos, faction intros), followed by terrible design decisions (Metal-blowing torches that can destroy gates, magical abilities that can make entire armies rout without any sense at all, Civil Wars that spawn 12 stacks of elite armies in your capital, Armies being able to move across the sea just by walking into it, 2500 base income allowing tiny village factions to destroy superpowers, etc), and bugs/performance issues everywhere.The only good 'things' about the game were expected to be there regardless like better graphics, tech tree, naval battles, no 300 bc Egyptians.Rome II, 1 step forward, 10 steps backward.Edit: After a year of updates, the game is finally playable and most bugs/performance issues/poor gameplay designs have been sorted out. There's only a few inconveniences left such as torches, lack of family tree, shallow character building (3 traits and 1 ancillary only, 2 traits if you include political promotions), but at least they tried.Game went from 2/10 to 8/10 as of Emperor Edition release.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Rome II is a great game. If you're looking to get your first TW game it's definately worth considering.  As far as single player goes, it has a very bare bones political system compared to Attila, but many players don't mind. That said, that's one of the only  negatives that comes to mind for campaign that's unique to this Total War game. It has a lot of factions with some large variety in them that you just don't find in most other Total War games and can bring you a lot of hours of replayability.Eventually like all other TW games the single player gets kind of old because once you get a good grasp on the game it's so easy to beat the AI. It's not necessarily CA's fault, it's a dautning task to make an AI challening in a game like this, which goes for every TW game. The good news is that Rome II is in my opinion, the best TW game around for multiplayer. Despite there being two newer titles there are still quite a few people playing Rome II ever day of all skill levels. It simply is the best MP experience for several reasons: It has some nice diversity in the factions available, and what may  appear to newcomers to be similar factions coming from the same ethnic peoples, you'll soon learn that there's actually some moderate to large differnces in them.  Yet there's a fairly good balance at play in the game between a large portion of the factions and the differences only become very obvious when you play against someone who is very near your skill level.Atilla is a better single player experience imo because of the challenges and horde system along with a very flushed out political system, but nothing beats Rome II for mulitpayer. Total War Warhammer is very anti-strategic and while it can be fun to do for a while it quickly becomes stale with tons of cheese builds and unit effects making you questions why you're bothering playing it as a strategy game.

												Update after almost 2 years.-------------------------------------------------------The game is now essentially another title. No bugs, better and challenging AI, new features. A Total War title as it should have been at launch. Now, with it's price so low and in this state i can wholeheartedly recommend this game.Old Review:I have been playing the series since the first Shogun. My favorite installment has been Rome Total War which i have been playing non stop since its release to this day and especially Barbarian Invasion (and the appropriate mods later on).Total War series have always been a mark in gaming. I would enjoy any other game but i would count the days for the next installment in the series and speculate which time period it would be about. I was midly dissapointed with Empire's launch and the mandatory steam activation but i loved the period so i enjoyed it. Sadly i wasn't able to play Shogun II as i was lacking a proper rig and i made a promise to get back to it later.Rome II came along. I pre-purchased (which i never do) and when i was 30 mins in game i couldn't believe it. Waterdowned battle, erratic AI, broken multiplayer and a walk in the park difficulty even in legendary.So i came back to Shogun II to find that a previous installment was in everyway better than Rome II. Managable dynasty and generals, better UI and micromanagement, heck even the diplomacy works better.Plus CA moneygrabs the heck out of the fans with senseless dlcs. That was the line for me. After many years this will be the last title that i buy full price from the Total War series.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												What can be said? As this is my very first Total War game, I don't have anything to compare it to, although I hear some of the previous ones should be better?In my experience this is a very good game, which could ofcourse need some polish or unit variation as a lot of them just seem like reskins. Luckily we have a BIG modding community to do those left-over chores which the devs have long since abandoned. If there were not any mods or DLC's, then this game would be on the verge of being a negative review. The DLC's are kind of a must, as they bring in a lot of new playable factions, and even some good new campaigns! The modding support is probably the biggest plus for me, so to sum it up:The good+ Great replayability+ Good graphics+ Lots of different factions to discover (IF you buy the DLC's)+ Different battle modes+ Micro- and macromanaging, not in the negative way!+ Absolutely great to play with friends!+ A huge variety of mods+ SPARTAThe bad- Not a huge amount of different units (mods make up for this though)- Boring music (there's a mod for other types of music)- Bad perfomance in big battles (even for the better rigs)

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												This game displeased an entire generation of Total War fans. Of course those were the fans that I did not agree with at all. This game finally does the series justice by returning to its roots and becoming a strategy game again. Ever since Empire and Napoleon it has been a multiplayer that also had some strategy to it. The added little gems make it much more fluid of a game and it stops the old problem of having to make 50 armies just to maintain order. Order is now about city and region mangement and no longer reliant on masses of troops.The units are well expanded from the original and the seige part of the game especially is much improved. The bells and wistled have been stripped so it is not as pretty to look at any more. You have to read instructions and listings to learn your units and buildings etc...It is an old fashioned war game for old fashioned war gamers like me. I play it with Steam offline because I don't want to be bothered while playing. I like it that much.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Comparing Emperor Edition to the 1.0 game is like day and night. It took them a year but at least they fixed the game.This game offers many unique factions to play with (I ll go to the DLC policy later) and the vanilla factions are a nice mix of hellenic eastern barbarian roman and carthaginian culture.  The time period is in my opinion a great playground and every campaign (while your early tactics are similar for the most part) is different. For example one time i saw the Etruscan Empire sacking Rome and on an other campaign they got rekt by turn 5. This makes for the most part the game fun to play and it offers a unique challenge everytime.  Now going to battles. The game engine is faulty yes, but the issues were at last fixed. Some problems are the game engines fault not the developers fault. For all of you complaining they cant use the engine from Medieval II and Rome I they would basically use a 10 year old game engine.  The warscape engine suits archers peltasts etc very nice but the cavalry fights in particular are a bit clumpsy. The infantry fights look much better in comparison to version 1.0 but it seems that there was margin to improve. About OP units and OP strats, they exist in pretty much every game, this is how it works. This is where modders step in. CA doesnt have endless time for balancing tests etc they need to release a new game in a certain period (Many people see SEGA as the issue here i am not oging to talk about that). Now coming to DLCs. In my opinion a big reason this game recieved a lot of hate. You make a game in the ancient time and we have to pay for the Greeks? Well not all of the Greeks we got the Diadochoi for free which had the most power in the hellenic world during the time period the game is set but its still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. If you dont like a DLC just dont buy it dont spread s*** to Hades and back. Yes you can see me criticizing the Greek States DLC but you need to understand that CA is business. And they (just like all other companies) want to make money. DLCs such as Nomadic Tribes and Black Sea colonies are in my opinion a good idea they are just new unique factions with not so good rosters so if you play TW competitevly you wouldnt be in a disadvantage because you couldnt play as the Attalid Pergamon(Derpamon). Coming now to modding of Rome II. PFM and Assembly kit are very user friendly programms(although PFM likes to crash). There have been many overhauls from complete to campaign ones. And if you see the overhaul-fix mods as a bad thing you are wrong. Mods exist to make the game even better so that the casual player can experience a better game. CA is there to fix the problems, mods are more of a help to the problem fix.UI.The cards are not exactly brilliant(Hard to distinguish first cohort from eagle cohort at a quick glance if you are new for example), but they work. And yes there are mods that change them incase you dont like them.The lists on the campaign map (forces provinces etc) are an awesome new feature allowing you to see the positions of your armies and agents at a glance. Now naval battles.Yes even in emperor edition are buggy but if i am not mistaked in Rome IIs days the naval battles were the best we had even with the bugs but you need to take into account the fact that naval battles were something of a new thing back then and as with new stuff, it takes some time for them in order to be optizimed and provide you the ideal gaming experienceBut but but but...If you have played older Total War Games like Medieval II or Rome I you may find the game "too simple" (eg the buildings) Sure its simple for an experienced player, but players new to TW series need a place to learn the game and in my opinion it does that well. And if you think that Rome II is inferior to Rome I i will agree with you. BUT BUT BUT....If Half Life 3 ever comes out you think it is going to be as good as Half Life 2? I don't think so.The game surely was a disaster upon launch, but its a solid game now.8/10Buying the DLCs on sale is a very prudent and sound idea

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Original review a few months after the game launched.  Updated review (08OCT14) is below this.steaming pile of broken crap.  CA was the ONLY company I was a fanboy for anymore, and theyve lost my loyalty now.They put out patches that beta testers have TOLD THEM WERE BROKEN, and are pushing DLC when THE BASE GAME STILL DOESNT F%$KING WORK.Dont buy this, EVER, until its on sale for 5-10$ and it actually works.  Dont support this crap, wish I had my pre-order money back.Updated as of 08OCT14, a bit over a year since release.  The game... is now playable.  Not great, not amazing, in no way better than anything before it except Napoleon(which isnt saying much), but playable.  Doesnt freeze, turns dont take 10 min each to load, AI is still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but they "buffed" it by giving it advantages.. aka more income than the player to support more armies on harder difficulites.  So... AI is still a joke.  But you can get some enjoyment out of the base game.  The majority of my playtime though is with the radius mod.  Totally overhauls the whole game, makes it much more enjoyable.  It is also 100% multiplayer and achievement compatible, though to play the multiplayer youll need to make sure you both have the exact same mods installed, or just radius mod.I definitely still will NOT recommend spending full price on the game.  CA is still pushing DLC, and now have announce a whole new title, Atilla.  ..and Rome 2 still isnt fully "fixed".  So... dont hold your breath.  But, for 10-15$, especially if you use the radius mod through the workshop, you can now probably get your money out of this game.  I for one though will never again pre-order from CA.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Guide on how to Rome II:Step 1: Decide to play the Grand CampaignStep 2: Select the Roman factionStep 3: Start researching economic techs. (You see if you have all the gold your enemies won't have any to raise armies with!)Step 4: Disband all armies to ensure that no rebellions happen. (How can someone revolt when there is no army to back them?)Step 5: Destroy all buildings (Buildings are expensive and there are much better free buildings)Step 6: Wait until all the open building slots are taken by slums (This will give a place for the poor people to live, and there by, increasing public order.)Step 7: Now that you've successfully quelled all possible public disruptions before they could happen, you can focus on the real problem, diplomacy!Step 8: You see if you've followed step 2 correctly you should have all the gold by now, and the other factions will be jealous and want your gold, so simply give them all your gold!Step 9: Now that the neighboring factions have all your gold they will want your territories as well, so you will need to allow them to take all your territories (This is to avoid any "negative diplomatic relations")Step 10: Victory for Rome!This review was brought to you in part by: The Carthaginians

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Did they fix the bugs? No. Fixing some of the bugs, but leaving game-killing bugs in place does not count as fixing the bugs. One of the main bugs was the inability to disembark naval units despite the presence of space on the map. I held off buying Rome II because of the problems with Shogun II, and got the Empire Edition. First playthrough, and I can't disembark my units in the Prologue. I also can't pull the ships back and try again. So, all the time I spent getting to that point has been wasted.  So I would recommend holding off on buying this game for another year and then check back to see if the bugs are fixed. I feel burned by CA over this, since the Empire Edition was supposed to be their "we've got all of the bugs worked out" edition, not their "we need more of your to buy our buggy game" edition.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												After TW:Rome I wait a loong for a Rome 2. After shogun 2 i have a "dream" about thst Rome 2 will be a great game. And after realse of game I was......The worst game in TS series (I don't have Napoleon). I spend about 750+ hours in game ( but a lots of time try to modding this game). Shogun 2 is much more better then Rome2. I like the ancient time, but I don't feel this ancient times in this game. Game is very poor with aspect which we had is previous game in TW series.What is the worst with game:- Poor AI diplomatic ( But I think this is in all game from TW series.)- Stupid AI on strategic map and on battle field. AI will attack cites even if AI don't have any chance to win a battle, or stupid stuff like: dtupid movement of armies on campaign map, it's look like - What the hell I have to do, what the hell I do, ups I forgot. SO AI will move between two points in map for few round when enemy army siege his cities.- AI in sedge battles is ...... .- Poor soldiers animations in battle. ( Shogun 2 have beautiful fight animation )- Unit's formations: the way how they look like, animations, hole units behavior. Units never hold their formation as they should have. Testudo formation and the phalanx look terrible and soldiers behavior is idiotic. When I remember how this look like in old TW:ROME. Rome units fight in tight formations. They where learn to fight in formation, they don't brake formation, but in game we have great solo fight battles. - Shogun 2 have better graphic ( in my opinion)- General experience tree is too simple, and whole general system I never care about generals, If he die I take other one.- Stupid rebellion system. Rebels armies is always spawned near cites, always with 4 units, and start plunder your region. Stupid AI behavior. - Very stupid and simple auto-resolve system (autobattles). I try to fix this system, I spend a lots of hours for test in this game, but this system is broken. example transport fleet is win battle VS naval units. SO why we need naval fleet. I make a mod to fix that but a land battles are hard to fix. Poor units like levies are able to win with elite army. - Game become bored, after when you conquer some lands. It's too easy. - Only few cities maps. So after some time you know all buildings in cites, You use the same strategic and game become more bored. The game have so many bugs, deficiencies that is to hard to say all of them.What is in plus:+ Nice region/provinces system.+ I don't know, it this on plus but a huge numbers of patches for game (after resale the game was unplayable I was im shock when I sow the game in my first play)+ Some new options in game like Some diplomatic options but AI don't use it. + Ability to play with mods.+ Divide et Impera MOD - without this mod or similar mods the game is unplayable, boring and too easy.+ Divide et Impera MOD+ Divide et Impera MODThis is not en error I write 3 times about Divide et Impera MOD. This mod is a this something what make that I'm still play in ROME 2. Without this mod I give about 5/10 points. With this mod I give 7/10I really try to love this game. The game look beautiful on screen, in trailers. I like this time period, but I don't feel it in this game. SO If you bay this game don't play in vanilla, try to DL some mods which fix and change a lots of game aspect which make this game playable, and better. At the end I can tell something what ROME 2 makes with me. After this game I start hate CA (devs.), that's why I will not bay TW:Attila. Probably I will never bay it or buy it when the Attil will cost 5 euro, or game will have a huge modification, which fix a game(something like DeI mod). Rome 2 was too bugy, unfinished, too simple for me. Attila will look similar. Probably Rome 2 is the last game in TW series, which I bay. This is how I start hate TS series after Rome 2.For this who never see this game after release, and how this game looks like watch this review  


YouTube™ Video: Total War: Rome II Angry Review 

			Views: 3,584,759		

			PROS & CONS Breakdown Here: http://angryjoeshow.com/2013/09/total-war-rome-ii-angry-review/		

P.S. Sorry for my English.EDIT I forgot to write about naval battles- System of naval transport units. Land units are able to enter on sea without any time need to board/build transport ships. It's idiotic. When you attack a cities from sea not only naval units fight with you on sea but a city garrison too, with their transport ships. They got a ships, they build a trans. ships in few minutes. This part of game is terrible.- Naval battles are terrible too. Trans units are better in naval battles against real naval units. So fleet with trans units will always win battle against real naval units. Boarding party is really crap. You need to touch enemy ship and boarding starts. No hooks, ropes, ramps, but ships are connected like with super glue. At this time (ancient) the ramming was the main strategy in naval battles. In Rome 2 this is boarding. What is the best even ships which don't have ram try to ramming you. Empire and shogun 2 have better naval battles. And the biggest argument why I don't recommended you this game is "THIS GAME IS NOT FINISHED". Game have so many bugs, errors, unhistorical aspects or unthinking aspects, and we got now Attila. So we never see a new patch for a Rome 2, none of bugs or aspect will be fixed. This♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. But if TW Attila were a DLC for Rome 2 I will say this game should be RECOMMENDED. I even bought DLC Atilla for Rome 2 even for 20-30 Euro. Attila have some fixes which should be in Rome 2 long time ago. So that's why I never bay any TW series game any more. They leave unfinished game like Rome2 and publish new with similar bugs, error to pull out from us, as much money as they can..
