content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												After TW:Rome I wait a loong for a Rome 2. After shogun 2 i have a "dream" about thst Rome 2 will be a great game. And after realse of game I was......The worst game in TS series (I don't have Napoleon). I spend about 750+ hours in game ( but a lots of time try to modding this game). Shogun 2 is much more better then Rome2. I like the ancient time, but I don't feel this ancient times in this game. Game is very poor with aspect which we had is previous game in TW series.What is the worst with game:- Poor AI diplomatic ( But I think this is in all game from TW series.)- Stupid AI on strategic map and on battle field. AI will attack cites even if AI don't have any chance to win a battle, or stupid stuff like: dtupid movement of armies on campaign map, it's look like - What the hell I have to do, what the hell I do, ups I forgot. SO AI will move between two points in map for few round when enemy army siege his cities.- AI in sedge battles is ...... .- Poor soldiers animations in battle. ( Shogun 2 have beautiful fight animation )- Unit's formations: the way how they look like, animations, hole units behavior. Units never hold their formation as they should have. Testudo formation and the phalanx look terrible and soldiers behavior is idiotic. When I remember how this look like in old TW:ROME. Rome units fight in tight formations. They where learn to fight in formation, they don't brake formation, but in game we have great solo fight battles. - Shogun 2 have better graphic ( in my opinion)- General experience tree is too simple, and whole general system I never care about generals, If he die I take other one.- Stupid rebellion system. Rebels armies is always spawned near cites, always with 4 units, and start plunder your region. Stupid AI behavior. - Very stupid and simple auto-resolve system (autobattles). I try to fix this system, I spend a lots of hours for test in this game, but this system is broken. example transport fleet is win battle VS naval units. SO why we need naval fleet. I make a mod to fix that but a land battles are hard to fix. Poor units like levies are able to win with elite army. - Game become bored, after when you conquer some lands. It's too easy. - Only few cities maps. So after some time you know all buildings in cites, You use the same strategic and game become more bored. The game have so many bugs, deficiencies that is to hard to say all of them.What is in plus:+ Nice region/provinces system.+ I don't know, it this on plus but a huge numbers of patches for game (after resale the game was unplayable I was im shock when I sow the game in my first play)+ Some new options in game like Some diplomatic options but AI don't use it. + Ability to play with mods.+ Divide et Impera MOD - without this mod or similar mods the game is unplayable, boring and too easy.+ Divide et Impera MOD+ Divide et Impera MODThis is not en error I write 3 times about Divide et Impera MOD. This mod is a this something what make that I'm still play in ROME 2. Without this mod I give about 5/10 points. With this mod I give 7/10I really try to love this game. The game look beautiful on screen, in trailers. I like this time period, but I don't feel it in this game. SO If you bay this game don't play in vanilla, try to DL some mods which fix and change a lots of game aspect which make this game playable, and better. At the end I can tell something what ROME 2 makes with me. After this game I start hate CA (devs.), that's why I will not bay TW:Attila. Probably I will never bay it or buy it when the Attil will cost 5 euro, or game will have a huge modification, which fix a game(something like DeI mod). Rome 2 was too bugy, unfinished, too simple for me. Attila will look similar. Probably Rome 2 is the last game in TW series, which I bay. This is how I start hate TS series after Rome 2.For this who never see this game after release, and how this game looks like watch this review  


YouTube™ Video: Total War: Rome II Angry Review 

			Views: 3,584,759		

			PROS & CONS Breakdown Here: http://angryjoeshow.com/2013/09/total-war-rome-ii-angry-review/		

P.S. Sorry for my English.EDIT I forgot to write about naval battles- System of naval transport units. Land units are able to enter on sea without any time need to board/build transport ships. It's idiotic. When you attack a cities from sea not only naval units fight with you on sea but a city garrison too, with their transport ships. They got a ships, they build a trans. ships in few minutes. This part of game is terrible.- Naval battles are terrible too. Trans units are better in naval battles against real naval units. So fleet with trans units will always win battle against real naval units. Boarding party is really crap. You need to touch enemy ship and boarding starts. No hooks, ropes, ramps, but ships are connected like with super glue. At this time (ancient) the ramming was the main strategy in naval battles. In Rome 2 this is boarding. What is the best even ships which don't have ram try to ramming you. Empire and shogun 2 have better naval battles. And the biggest argument why I don't recommended you this game is "THIS GAME IS NOT FINISHED". Game have so many bugs, errors, unhistorical aspects or unthinking aspects, and we got now Attila. So we never see a new patch for a Rome 2, none of bugs or aspect will be fixed. This♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. But if TW Attila were a DLC for Rome 2 I will say this game should be RECOMMENDED. I even bought DLC Atilla for Rome 2 even for 20-30 Euro. Attila have some fixes which should be in Rome 2 long time ago. So that's why I never bay any TW series game any more. They leave unfinished game like Rome2 and publish new with similar bugs, error to pull out from us, as much money as they can..

A Screenshot of Total War: ROME II - Emperor Edition
By: Austria-Hungary > Prussia




  That is a great example of stuff that goes on in this game! Though, to be fair, it could partialy the fault of a mod I had was to "improve naval combat". ANYWAYS that pic should make you want to buy this game 420/69 would buy again. To be supr srius this game has it moments, and is finaly in a playable condition. The multiplayer is pretty balanced, but has way too many metas to be the most enjoyable thing to play. I couldnt say if you want this. The strong points are: Great graphics, amazing detail, good voices for the most part, good amount of variety in factions/units. Bad things: Start of a paid pay to win game(factions that you want like athens, sparta, odysrian kingdom, and many others you have to pay $7 usda for each pack of 3 factions, and the fact that you have to pay for blood and gore that should be in the game anyways, FURTHER MORE you have to pay for units packs.) They have a good PR department beacuse whenever they release new unit packs they give free units, and buffs to factions for free. So you decide after that info if you want the game. I find it enjoyable in shorter 2-3hr sessions.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Guide on how to Rome II:Step 1: Decide to play the Grand CampaignStep 2: Select the Roman factionStep 3: Start researching economic techs. (You see if you have all the gold your enemies won't have any to raise armies with!)Step 4: Disband all armies to ensure that no rebellions happen. (How can someone revolt when there is no army to back them?)Step 5: Destroy all buildings (Buildings are expensive and there are much better free buildings)Step 6: Wait until all the open building slots are taken by slums (This will give a place for the poor people to live, and there by, increasing public order.)Step 7: Now that you've successfully quelled all possible public disruptions before they could happen, you can focus on the real problem, diplomacy!Step 8: You see if you've followed step 2 correctly you should have all the gold by now, and the other factions will be jealous and want your gold, so simply give them all your gold!Step 9: Now that the neighboring factions have all your gold they will want your territories as well, so you will need to allow them to take all your territories (This is to avoid any "negative diplomatic relations")Step 10: Victory for Rome!This review was brought to you in part by: The Carthaginians

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												I started my true path to PC gaming in 2012 as a 13 year old kid playing Rome: Total War on a very old laptop. I loved that game, best and only game I had truly played that was actually mine. And then fast forward to about 2015. I have a new but still crappy laptop, Rome barely works on it and so I play Medieval 2 and that becomes my favorite game. I then see something on sale, Rome 2 Total War. I heard a lot of bad stuff about this game, but they had a free weekend so I decided to try it out. Yes my laptop could barely run it, but I had such a blast that I just had to buy the game. Fast forward to a month ago, I had nearly 150 hours on that game and I had just gotten a new PC. I stopped playing the game due to the fact that half of my hours were there due to waiting for the End Turn or through super slow battles as my laptop was trash. Now I play it on my new PC, and I absolutely love this game. I don't know why. It was such a horrid gaming experience but still a fantastic game and I kept on getting sucked into playing it. Compared to other Total War games this is still a great game. Not the Empire Total War sized catastrophy everyone remembers it as, but a legit good game. Better then even Shogun 2: FOTS. (Although I haven't played Empire nor Napolean just because I hate the guns) So if you haven't played this game in awhile I suggest you do now. Forget the horrendous DLC and just get the ones that interest you. I only have the Blood and Gore and the Greek States culture packs. And download either the Radious mods or the Divide Et Imperia mod. Nothing is better than watching a couple pila throws destroy half a unit.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												If you are a Total War fan avoid this game at all cost. The bad release, held back content for DLC greed, and over all bad form are just what the forums are full of. 12 patches later some of the launch bugs are fixed but you cannot fix what's wrong with this game. The AI is totally scripted and although you can break the linear campaign play by avoiding most political shanghia from "allies" you still get the same super stack factions that have to be scripted to do something stupid because they could just roll you off the map if they kept going. The building systems leave little to no variablity as you almost always need food and pub order just to build stuff. The the monetary system is so freakin ridiculously out of wack you end up with millions and have factions pleading for huge amounts of money for silly things just to spend down. A civil war that has no rhymn or reason just randomly pops. The combat is just blobs nothing like Rome 1 was. The AI cheats in several ways; not following the same economy as you, cavalry that has more moral than typical, ambushes when army was in clear sight...ect. Instead of the tactical battles that were the norm for this series you instead have a series of power ups that your generals "earn" so combat turns into a pause-fest unless you're quicker than snail snot ona hot day. They only difference in gameplay through difficulties are stat manipulations and nothing the ai does is situationally relative, hes just better.... All in all I knew the TW series was dying, I had thought Empire was it's death rattle. Sad to see it still spit up a few more titles before its collapse into this mindless arcade clicker. Thanks for the memories, of the early titles.....

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												This is probably the only review I've given for a game, and I've done so because I've never felt so ripped off in my life for buying this over-hyped POS.  I'll start the slow clap to CA for the fantastic marketing of this game. I've played since Medieval I, and was blown away with Rome I when it first came out. I think CA knew that a majority of their players felt the same way, and made Rome II to be something much more grander than the original with their siege of Carthage video and the new Rally Point teasers. I pre-ordered...and CA played me well I'll give them that.I played through all the patches, but I think it's safe for all of the players to assume that nothing CA can do will bring back the immersion and strategy that the prior TW games brought to the table. I swear to you, I've never even bothered to look at the general's traits because they don't matter. They die before they become significant. All that matters is grinding them to commander, general, infantry commander II, and great leader and bringing them to your "training" Providences to pump out level III gold units for the rest of your armies so that you can steam roll the AI. Rinse and repeat. I've played many factions, and every time Rome is annihilated very early before I can even fight them...in a game called Rome II. Seige AI? Ha...just send out your useless plebs to attack their ladder units, and then slaughter the rest of the army at your gates when they abandon their ladders. Battles? Just use your infantry line to hold the enemy (after you take their skirmishers out with your calvary) while your javelin units get at least 200+ kills and eventually lead to the route of the enemy unit. No real strategy at all. You can use a different faction, but the same strategy always works. You can't lose unless you purposely try to. The series has been dumbed down beyond belief. This is probably the only time I felt like I was scammed into buying a game based on past reputation and hype. CA, for me, has lost all credibility. I'm not saying I won't play again (because there is nothing else out there like the TW games), but I'll be sure to buy a game after it's "Gold Package" with all the additions is on sale for $25 (being generous), and the reviews for the game are above 8.0 out of 10 on the average. You'd be a fool not to do the same.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												At first, as you will know there were bugs, it was infested with them. Bad AI too.Apart from the dull soundtrack (which can easily be fixed with the 4 part music mod) and the dull colour pallet (which there will be other mods for) it is a good game. I had to change the collision on mine because I hated this clustering going on, but it was not unbearable, it was just slightly irritating. The good points are:Few crashes, they only happen with lots of mods (55)Best current AI on any total war to date. (It actually is)Great campaign in most playthroughs, but can get too easy.A few minor critisisms are the removed family tree (happy to see it making an appearence in Attila)You have to have someone leading an army and you can't just select a few units, send them out to kill a few rebels and come home or have 3-4 units of light cav wandering around your borders to scout for enemy armies. Lots of the units looks very similar their faces) and none really look majorly different. Voice acting is minimal, it could keep the game very fresh if people had different accents.Cities never tend to look very different, barbarian cities are all the same, same with greeks and romans, same with eastern factions. Characters feel expendable because they have no real meaning in your family, in Med 2 I would be both sad and scared when my King died, they usually had great influence in the world and my faction could easily fall apart after their death. I think what makes this so good is the superb modding community. Champloo, Wolfman and many more who made me play this game. Overally it gets 60% good, though if I had not seen the majesty of Med 2 and Rome 1, it would probably get a higher mark. I just hope Attila can do better.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Base Game: 710A fun eploration of this period of our history, but lacking the simple components of total war games that add to the base campaign and battle components. Would have enjoyed: family trees, balanced agents, a heirarchical government that is better presented, visible skill trees. This entry is also poorly optimized, not fully utilizing available cores and not taking advantage of the gpu. Also, dlc to death. Poor battle AI. The lack of city walls is also disappointing, but this may have been due to the poor AI performance during seige battles.Modded Game: 8.5/10The community has been amazing. Divide Et Impera is my current go-to for total conversion of Rome II for a richer, more challenging experience. More diversity between factions, more historically accurate units, expanded/revised building and skill chains. Overall, much better than the base game+dlc.I recommend getting this game on a summer sale, so you can it and all of the dlc for a more reasonable price. This game and the mods available make a very enjoyable total war experience. Modding is made very easy with steam's workshop, simple browse and click on what you want.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Base Game: 710A fun eploration of this period of our history, but lacking the simple components of total war games that add to the base campaign and battle components. Would have enjoyed: family trees, balanced agents, a heirarchical government that is better presented, visible skill trees. This entry is also poorly optimized, not fully utilizing available cores and not taking advantage of the gpu. Also, dlc to death. Poor battle AI. The lack of city walls is also disappointing, but this may have been due to the poor AI performance during seige battles.Modded Game: 8.5/10The community has been amazing. Divide Et Impera is my current go-to for total conversion of Rome II for a richer, more challenging experience. More diversity between factions, more historically accurate units, expanded/revised building and skill chains. Overall, much better than the base game+dlc.I recommend getting this game on a summer sale, so you can it and all of the dlc for a more reasonable price. This game and the mods available make a very enjoyable total war experience. Modding is made very easy with steam's workshop, simple browse and click on what you want.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2013
												...Months and months after the release...The game has improved dramatically. The release was rocky; I was one of the lucky ones who got to play from the release. To say the game is in a similar state as the release (Or, at least from my experience, buggy) has not played the game recently.The game has an inferior "feel" to shogun 2. I can't pinpoint what exactly causes this... I suspect that, perhaps, the in-campaign maps are not as stunningly beautiful as those in shogun. The game also has a few "logic problems". For example, when defending a point after fortifying it, the game has a tendancy to automatically force one into the least advantageous position. Come on! If I were fortifying a position, I'd do it from the top of a hill, all the better for my giant fireballs to crush people!This said, TWR2 is quite fun to play. CA has done a lot to fix the game, and my FPS are finally jumping up. A widely varied unit roster is good to see, in comparison to shougun. Some of the controlls have changed since shogun, as well. For example, a pike phalanx is told to attack by clicking through the enemy unit, not clicking "attack". Tactically, this is more intuitive, but can be rather confusing for veteran players of past TW games.I strongly advise buying this game...on sale. The gameplay has not improved enough since shogun 2 to justify spending 60 bucks on TWR2. 40, or perhaps 30 dollars would be closer.Wait till the summer/fall/christmas sale, buy the game, go crazy.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												So, let me toss my hat into this ring. Rome II released a fair bit buggy. AI was too aggressive against the player, but not each other. There was a weird glitch in Gameplay everyone complained about I never saw (And was fixed within the second week patch). When I first played it, it was funnish still, but all these new diplomacies out of reach due to overly bizarre AI was the main issue. Not so much anymore. AI follows a state based on their relationship status to you, which is based on if you're war with their enemies (+) or with their friends (-) and follows a fairly sensible pattern, where someone at 150+ relations won't declare war on you unless you attack someone in that is their defensive alliance (But if they are afraid/good enough friends, they'll peace out fairly quickly.) Someone at -200 is undoubtly going to declare war on you, even if they have to launch a naval invasion to make it happen. The AI does get afraid though, The selecuids at war with everyone suddenly found Galatian Barbarians running rampant over their stuff, and they peaced out with a massive gold gift to avoid further destruction. Combat AI is mostly good, especially in field battles. If your line is too short, they will flank you with their infantry. Sometimes they go with a lopsided strategy against your weak flanks to try to break them and sweep into the side. Cav will chase your archers round and round unless you counter them. They use scout cavalary to try to find your people if you hide in the forest rather than marching around aimlessly. Combat AI gets a little weird in city sieges. THey kind of understand how to defend, in that they'll move to fill gaps you break in the wall, defend the right areas, put archers to counter movements. Without siege weapons, you'll get punished trying to climb the walls. Attacking though it's a bit weird. First it'll move up ladders, and if that fails, they'll attack your gate (AI has siege gear, but never allowed it to get to my walsl before). Most of the time this still goes straight forwards, but this does allow your archers to pepper them freely, despite ladders on the walls. Though since the ladders appear to be made out of adamintine, that's probably for the best. Once trhough, they tend to just stream their entire force through. Archers, cavalry, infantry, everything. Combat stats are pretty nice. Morale is still a big deal like Shogun 2, though even the most untrained levy is not nearly as much of a pansy as the Rise of the Samurai Levy units which would take one casualty and panic like the world is ending. Some morale seems a bit ridiclous (Killing 119 Thorax Swordsman in a group and yet the last one still fights on) but most respond to shocks like hard shock cav charges pretty well. Generals are important to maintain morale and their abilities are really helpful. They also have other bonuses that vary heavily, like reducing unit cost or improving everyone's skill, or reducing enemy morale. Army Groups now are permenant things that build traditions as well that outlive their generals and can be reinstated if they are wiped out. These can represent a key doctrine certain groups employ. Combat can get a bit slow and sloggy though when you have spears in defensive position and all they have are is spears. BRING A SWORD. Will admit, combining Shield strength into armor and missile accuracy into missle damage on the stat screen is a bit weird.Campaign isn't like Rome 1 where Population is the only important stat and money is infinite. Population is still important, population growth allowing areas to gain new buildings to make more money. Money really varies though where you start. If you start as Parthia and take over Iran, that's a free money from the trade goods and Eastern bonus to towns (Local COmmerce bonus+10% bonus from Being Eastern.) Whereas Rome is very tempting to go full military, and you'll wind up bankrupting yourself in your war against Carthage, unable to pay for reinforcements and navies. Campaign other nice note: Nobody plays that similar. Geography and unit types are nicea nd diverse. Now, some, like Parthia, play totally different from most others. Parthia plays like a Steppe Horde that got some full plate knights. They also get bonus damage on all their ranged weapons. Even after a 15% bonus, Rome's slingers and javs still do way less damage than parthians, and that's not mentioning the archers. Slinger: Normal 18, Parthia: 21. Jav: 39, Parthia 45, Archer: 27 Parthia: 32. Cretan archers of some hellenic factions have the 32, but those are a tier 3-4 unit. Parthias get those archers from a tier 2 building... that also ride horses. Rome has Legionaires. Sparta has a diverse set of units based aroudn their social stratifications, Athens has a few nice cavalry, Macedon with their units, Egypt with their mixture of native Egyptians and greek things, Pontus and Selecuids with mixture of eastern and hellenic, Galatia as he invading gauls. Lots of fun. 86%, Would recommend.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												(This review is post 8.1 patch) After a bit of a terrible launch, Rome 2 is now starting to look like the game that was shown in trailers and the promo material.The A.I is starting to become smarter than it was; but it is not really a challenge for a Total War veteran. On the campaign map the A.I also spams agents quite a bit, so if you have cities near your enemies, prepare for your buildings to get burned down or your wells poisoned. The user interface can has became much better now. Numbers actually show up on unit cards now, and tool tips are on almost everything. But, the battle U.I is still rough in places. The unit cards don't really show that they're shooting, being shot at, in melee or routing. The icons for alerts of units being shot at by archers or javelin throwers can be mixed up with wavering/routing. The unit cards flash red when they're being hit by missile units and for, especially me, thought that that unit was wavering/routing, as I didn't have the battle advisor on.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I really wanted to Like Rome 2, but the one big selling point for Rome 2 was Coop Campaign, and it fails at every turn "LITERALLY"Desync after Desync...  (multiplayer campaign) Patch after patch of "FAIL"The game runs a little smoother then right after release, but not what it should be.The A.I. seems ok one battle, then completely worthless the next.Naval battles are a complete joke, I mean it, they are absolute garbage, my advice to you is to Auto Calc every naval battle.Again,  the CO-OP is completely borked beyond belief, even a year later. I'm not sure if the DEVs just gave up, don't have the ability or talent to fix it, or just do not care...  At any rate, the DEVs have created a pile in terms of multiplayer, one of the only reasons I pre-ordered Rome 2, and i'm not happy with campaign CO-OP in any way, shape or form.My System Specs "FAR" exceed what is recommended, and on DAY ONE the game ran like trash.Now a year later I don't have any real issues with performance, but Rome 2 is not optimized at all.This game for single player is ok, not stellar, not any sort big improvement, nothing special.CONCLUSION: Rome 2 Total War is worth about $20.00, so ANYONE that pays $60.00 for Rome 2 after looking into all of the bugs/desyncs/lack of optimization/junk multiplayer, is a "FOOL".If I would have known about these issues before I pre-ordered Rome 2, or even if I had beta tested Rome 2,  then I would have waited for a sale on Rome 2 when it hit $20.00..Unfortunately I did "ZERO" research on Rome 2, at the time it was being developed, and all of that I was busy with other things, and thought that they couldn't possibly "BUNGLE" what many people consider to be the FlagShip of the Total War series..   Buyer beware.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												As someone who pre-ordered, originally, I could not have recommended the game, as I essentially paid for a Beta in terms of bugs and polish. This still galls to this day and I would not pre-order a Total War game again.After many patches and post-polishing, I can cautiously recommend this as a decent addition to the Total War franchise. Its overall mechanics aren't super, such as the nerf to culture change, where you now have default culture that cannot be converted, leaving permanent unhappiness in conquered territories of a foreign culture.The battle mechanics are solid, although there are some clear carry-overs from Shogun 2. They never did families or the in-depth politics as promised. Despite that, the game is still fun, although it can get a bit stale when you get to a big empire stage against other similarly big empires. The AI does not always function as intended still, although the related game-breaking bugs have at least been eliminated.A lot more time was spent with attention to history this time around, no ancient Egyptians, you now get proper diadochi. Some factions rosters are a bit sparse, and non-playable powers aren't worked into the system of buffs/tradeoffs you get choosing a faction or family for the playable ones.Many of the faults and gripes can be fixed with mods, but it shouldn't be on the shoulder of the modwright to carry a game.Ultimately, get this on sale in a bundle, there's many hours of game to explore, but it's not worth full price, in my opinion. And the DLCs are some of the better and more fun content.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I don't know what everyone is complaining about, I love Rome 1 and have played it for years but Rome 2 adds so many new features and improvements. +New agent types and actions+Providence system that I think adds more strategy to the campaign. It forces you to decide what resources the towns produce, where Rome 1 had cities that were money makers/fortresses/everything.+Tech tree, simple, but there wasn't even one in Rome 1.+Food system, need to keep it up in order to support your armies. +Naval combat that is simple yet enjoyable.+Land and sea battles at the same time!!!+Leveling system for indavidual armies and generals, being able to name your armies is a plus too.+Seige battles are so much better, so far, AI has proven to be way better than Rome 1.+Culture mechanic, can be used as a weapon and adds more depth to city development, also gets around the terrible cultural difference that you can't get around in Rome 1.+Touches on some inner politics, not too much but adds more immersion with the actual generals/statesmen.+Garrison units, less micromanagement of city garrisons, more of a personal preference. The few complaints I have:-Rome 1 started with everyone starting with clean slates with diplomacy, had more of a sandbox feeling in how diplomatic ties developed. Rome 2 tries to force the diplomatic relations to historical accuracy.-Instant fleets, but not that big of a deal because the ships they get are terrible. An actual navy can easily destroy them.-From what I've seen so far, no family trees.Overall, Rome 2 has way more features than Rome 1. I still love Rome 1 but saying that Rome 2 dumbs everything down and simplifies the game is complete ignorance. There are some things from CA that I disagree with, but as a game, Rome 2 is better.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												First of all: I'm kinda a veteran in this game series and the major reason I bought this game was because of this, I was a fan of it. But after playing it a lot I simply cannot recommend it unless you get it for free, then you may kill some hours with it.First the pluspoints: Ofc the marine battles are kinda the best advantage over the old Rome: Total War (1) and they're fun, though really messy and hardly controllable with like 40 ships (unless you pause the game). The new region boni are nice as well, the interface is good and looks nice. There might be some other good points that I forget to mention but that's jsut because the bad points outweigh everything else so hard. Let's get right into them:First of all: The AI. Where should I start? It sucks in battle, it sucks on the campaign and sucks overall. It's diplomatic behavior is sometimes just plain stupid and senseless and it will never be able to lead a large scale war. Once you've established yourself as major power, the rest of the game is kinda grinding.Siege battles which pose the biggest possibility for epic gameplay are - at least as defender (let's be honest: that's nicer) - just totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. There's still a lot of bugs in the AI's behavior with siege ladders (like not using them at all or in a really stupid way) and it's strategy; well, 9/10 games will look like this: The AI will focus all it's power on one side, even when greatly outnumbering you, you use your garrison one 2, 3 keyspots where you kill all, if any up climbing enemies and after you killed them all, the AI will rally it's cavalry for a useless, stupid attack on your gates, just to get killed by towers. I'll leave it and that, even though there's more bad about the AI.The battles in general: Surely core of the Total War franchise, the battles still have a lot of bugs in this version (and I doubt there will be updates fixing them) which kill all the fun. One of the biggest (and probably easiest to solve) problems is the missing "Hold-Position"-button we know and love from Rome 1. This will lead to your formation breaking when you tell your units to attack and any kind of archers - let's say thay engage Legolas-style fights without his skills.The archers... Wish that was there only problem. Not only that they always have to set themselves up facing the enemy, possibly moving into the front battle when you want them attacking flanking enemies, they also have MAJOR issues targeting enemies with any kind of obstructions (including walls, buildings, rocks etc.) nearby. "Oh, I'm so gonna lure the enemy to this cliff so my archers will send a hail of arrows down there" - nope, not happening. "I will let the enemies on my walls and then make a shooting range out of them with my archers nearby, muhaha" - ye, try it. Will work in 1 out of 5 attempts, so go ahead.I don't know how many archer battalions (and also battles) I've lost due to unexpected, senseless behavior of these ranged units. You gotta watch them more than a pyromaniac with gas & lighter.And now my 3 major issue: Campaign AI and diplomacy. First one advice: Like in previous TW games, allies aren't worth the trouble. Basically, they won't ever rly help you (even though there's a nice lil' "ally target" feature in diplo screen), take away cities that you desperately wanted to conquer yourself (maybe because you just lost them) and they'll only get you into wars that you do not want. You like showing mercy and building up a team of vasalls? Well, ♥♥♥♥ you. They only pretend to be your friends. I do admit that they're less backstabby than in Shogun 2, but that's probably just due to them being too stupid to succeed.And there's the major problem with the diplomacy: Trading cities isn't possible (and there are no mods to solve it). Not only do I think it's making it less immersive, it also hinders realistic peace negotiations and worst of all, as mentioned above, allies will steal your cities, if you don't plan ahead or if you rely on their help in defense. "Oh, I just recaptured that city that surprise army conquered from you. You want it back? FU ♥♥♥♥♥, it's mine now. Just declare war on my and ruin your rep, I am after all your loyal, helping ally since ages ago."To sum it up: Don't buy it. Don't. It's maybe fun for a really short time but if you're keen on immersion and have some standards like I do, you probably won't enjoy it for long. I can garantuee you won't fight 10 battles without some really annoying issue that destroys all immersion.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												As a fan of the series it pains me to say it but Rome II was an utter disappointment upon release. I am sure the game has improved with patches over time. But I have to ask...why did it need patches to begin with? They claimed they invested more resources in AI but it sure as hell didn't seem like it upon release. I was so disappointed with the game's launch state I have not felt the motivation to come back to it after its many issues. The fact that ROME II has stripped so much of what made prior Total War games interesting was another disappointment. Gone were the little movies for assasinations etc. Gone were the battle speeches that we got in games like Medieval 2. There were some good improvements such as towns having their own garrisons so your other guys can go out and fight. But then your limited to how much influence you have in the world. At release I had one instance where I was the strongest faction and had some allies. But the diplomacy AI was so broken it seemed like all my allies were wiped out and then every little♥♥♥♥♥♥ant country declared war on me. Speaking of countries and factions...turns took way too long. In multiplayer you would even desync. I have owned every Total War title up till now with the exception of Attila. In fact it was Rome II's disatrous launch that made me indifferent to Attila. Again many of the issues I outlined above may have been patched since. But reading through the other reviews of the emperor's edition? It appears the game still has issues with long turns and loading times. The other big issue I have is the constant faction DLC whoring. The fact they had to have another edition to get the game in the state it should have been upon release is unacceptable. With the patches the game might be enjoyable but I would wait for a steam sale. With Steam refunds now though you could try it out and get a refund if you don't like it. Lets hope that steam refunds discourage a repeat of Rome II. I learned my lesson with Rome II. I will no longer be preordering any future Total War games. Your better than this Creative Assembly. Its up to you to make me fall in love with the Total War series again.

content:
Posted: April 19
												The initial problems of Rome 2 have been fixed for the most part due to patches. The high price of DLC means you will just have to wait for a sale, but the Imperator Augustus campaign that comes with the Emperor Edition far exceeds the original grand campaign because of the new tech trees and different sub-factions. Being able to play with almost all factions in the grand campaign allows for countless replayability due to the different play styles. I have been a long time fan of the Total War series and love this game. It alot more detail when it comes to public order and cultural influence than the first Rome and is much more accessible than Attila. I would recommend especially when it is on sale due to the long amount of hours and replayability this has.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I recommend this gameIf you like chess, go, or risk you will as wellWARNING     IF YOU'RE SLOW, so is the game. IF YOUR COMPUTER IS SLOW, so is the game [with the exception of downloading certain graphical mods , deselecting the ability to view other player movement and using the advanced graphics option (at the top of the page under graphics, under options under the menu that comes up when you press the esc key)]SUGESTION    Get it Now! while it's cheap, and if you are reading this when it isn't less than 30 dollars on steam get it another time while it's cheap and make sure you get it online in an area with a good internet speed and an ether net cord (cord for direct internet connection) because it's a pain in the you know where to download from a disc.  Spend money on the game the expansion packs seem worthless though with all the cool mods.  Play epic battles in campaign, limit the amount of time you spend on everything in the game, always make quick decisions while playing (in campaign and in battles) open another window before playing the game so you have the ability to multitask with the alt tab key between different things [if you don't but you want to multitask than you're screwed, (I like to play Rome while watching a movie with an HDMI cord and the projector function in the computer)]. MODS    Without certain mods Rome II may be unbearable for you, so don't invest large amounts of time into your first campaigns unless you know what you're doing.SUGESTED GRAPHICAL MODS!!!    TREE REMOVAL MOD (best mod!! allows for much faster game play + looks more realistic (can boost other graphics like terain atroscopic and texture to get the best effect)    SPLENYI' BETTER CAMPAIGN CAMERA(MOD FRIENDLY) + CLOUD REMOVAL (the version you want just says cloud removal)    LITTLE SETTLEMENTS [(don't worry big cities still have big walls in battle) (first 4 mods listed go well together)]    EXTENDED CAMERA MINI MOD (you might like this and it might be the best thing ever for you or not)    No HDR mod [helps battle frame rate and again you might really like this but probably not (reduces light dynamics)]     a world to explore (simple mod that just makes sense, especially in the beginning of your first campaign)2nd WARNING (mods)     Mods don't usually work unless installed before a campaign is launched    Mods don't always work together (although the graphical mods that I suggested I think work with just about anything)    Mods that are old don't always work - these mods show a yellow triangle infront of them after downloading    Mods of a feather don't flock together (usually) [mod overloads=good but don't usually work together or with certain mods (This goes for unit mods as well)]In General THE GRAPHICAL MODS I CHOSE ARE MUST HAVES, BUT with campaign mods there are many ways to go and no right or wrong campaign mod to choose. It all depends on what you want to do. Depending on which faction you are you may want an Italian mod or a mod that develops major factions (these mods -- and there are many -- are highly recommended due to the fact that the campaign is never ending and almost dissatisfying at the end because of it) or mods specifically for certain factions (this is especially important for troop mods). But keep in mind that when you're just starting out you should test a few good unit mods for your specific faction, grab a serious overhaul mod [one that is comprised of multiple (3 to 6) mods]  make sure you have the graphics mods I mentioned and to get rid of view enemy troop movement and don't make the AI too easy or too hard just start out with normal or hard level of difficulty. Just RememberREMEMBER to hold down the clicker before releasing and sending a troop to somewhere that it will atrophy or into enemy territory sending a troop to enemy territory is extremely easy due to several occasional glitches in the game also REMEMBER to close out of the little diplomatic window by pressing x before you click on the next faction otherwise you will think you’re on the next faction but you're really still on the same one additionally REMEMBER to delete mercenaries after a battle the same turn you bought them and to only buy them on the turn of the battle because their upkeep is ridiculously expensive make sure you REMEMBER public order and keep it in the green to do this REMEMBER that when clicking on city details (a little circle that has a building in it) after clicking on the city that you can stop taxing a specific province by clicking the box in the top left corner that is checked when they are being taxed also REMEMBER  that if you have enough built up public order or are still getting more public order you can increase or decrease your taxes by clicking on your treasury chest button (always at the bottom) and by moving the little red dot on the bar furthermore REMEMBER your food and don't let there be a food shortage or your troops and city troops will atrophy and be extremely easy to take over this goes for public order to except instead of losing troops you'll receive more and more and more rebel troops after a certain number of turns that can be seen by hovering a mouse over the face that changes color to show public order that is visible on the left when the city is clicked on also REMEMBER to create a strategy when you're researching tech don't just click something way down the line that you want but start by getting stuff that really good that only takes a couple or a few turns also try to pic things that are essential like I always like to research the technology that gets artillery first because they are essential for taking over capital cities and save you from having to fight battles against small annoying armies like rebels by destroying them long before they even meet your troops also artillery is useful in most fights REMBER to have the infantry to guard them though and to keep a close eye on them so you can tell them to drop siege equipment and to then run away before enemy infantry or Calvary get them REMEMBER that one of the best generals you can have are Calvary for almost all armies except in rare cases where you need a strong defensive infantry unit to help defend a city or something REMEMBER to be nice to other factions but when they really want something -- no matter what make the pay up the wing wang for it -- by in the diplomacy box under the compass at the bottom of the screen and after selecting on a nation to negotiate with you press payments and chose to either give or demand money REMBER to just select one and start dialing in a fare bargain the select the other box and the price asked for will carry over and if you have different incomes, which you always do, you will be able to go back and forth changing the dial until you find the perfect price and you should REMEMBER to pick a price just below what it says is high so some where a little below high on moderate and this will get him to accept without rejecting you and will get you the best deal REMEMBER in battles to use defensive formations and to have enouph room to move troops around and to flank and or surround a troop like you would in go also make sure you back your troops up like you would in chess and most importantly make sure you don't take risks to great like the ones you wouldn't like to do in a game of risk.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I want to love this game but it is so broken and the solution of using mods to fix this games issues just doesn't cut it. I enjoyed all of the total war games up to this point even empire with all its flaws but this game feels like rome total war 1 on arcade mode x2. Battles are over before they start and I can hold Athens against all odds with a single unit of peasants. African tribes stomp Carthage into the ground. The list just goes on with dlc after dlc and stupid easy ai even on hardest setting (as pretty much all that changes in you get more unhappiness and the ai gets a ton of cash each turn making it wave on wave of crap troops). TL;DR creative assembly how far you have fallen. don't buy, don't follow, wait for new game engine.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												As a fan of the series it pains me to say it but Rome II was an utter disappointment upon release. I am sure the game has improved with patches over time. But I have to ask...why did it need patches to begin with? They claimed they invested more resources in AI but it sure as hell didn't seem like it upon release. I was so disappointed with the game's launch state I have not felt the motivation to come back to it after its many issues. The fact that ROME II has stripped so much of what made prior Total War games interesting was another disappointment. Gone were the little movies for assasinations etc. Gone were the battle speeches that we got in games like Medieval 2. There were some good improvements such as towns having their own garrisons so your other guys can go out and fight. But then your limited to how much influence you have in the world. At release I had one instance where I was the strongest faction and had some allies. But the diplomacy AI was so broken it seemed like all my allies were wiped out and then every little♥♥♥♥♥♥ant country declared war on me. Speaking of countries and factions...turns took way too long. In multiplayer you would even desync. I have owned every Total War title up till now with the exception of Attila. In fact it was Rome II's disatrous launch that made me indifferent to Attila. Again many of the issues I outlined above may have been patched since. But reading through the other reviews of the emperor's edition? It appears the game still has issues with long turns and loading times. The other big issue I have is the constant faction DLC whoring. The fact they had to have another edition to get the game in the state it should have been upon release is unacceptable. With the patches the game might be enjoyable but I would wait for a steam sale. With Steam refunds now though you could try it out and get a refund if you don't like it. Lets hope that steam refunds discourage a repeat of Rome II. I learned my lesson with Rome II. I will no longer be preordering any future Total War games. Your better than this Creative Assembly. Its up to you to make me fall in love with the Total War series again.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I have played all of the Total War games and I found Rome 2 to be the worst launch of them all.   The game was buggy, the AI terrible and the turns took forever.That being said, since the patches over a couple of months, the game is much better performance wise, turns zip past about as fast as other games in the series, the AI is not as bad both in battles or in its strategy on the campaign. The graphics are really good, the battles are satisying if a little too short, and the campaign feels epic.Of course not everybody is happy with the design choices; a lot seem to want an updated gfx engine for the first Rome game.The developers continue to tweak the game based on community discussions, and things are going to get even better, I am sure.I dont think many people would be disappointed with their purchase if it was released today.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												My grandfather served in World War 2, helped save Europe, including Britain, from the fascists. Why is this important? Because if I could go back in time, I would shoot my grandfather in the head and help the Germans win the war. What did we get for saving Britain? A thank you? No, we get Rome 2. A Nazi Europe is a better alternative than letting the world suffer through this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ And even if the Germans still don't win, and this abonination gets "developed", at least I won't have to suffer through this 21st century holocaust. As of now, I've played for 45 hours. I have yet to enjoy it at all. I'm either stupid, or I have yet to accept my sadomasochistic tendencies, but I'm still playing. Trying to have fun for the $60 I blew. CA had never let me down before, so I foolishly preordered. But this time they ♥♥♥♥ed me. Don't get ♥♥♥♥ed by CA, Don't buy this.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												I started playing Rome 2 in March of 2016, I read that at launch it was a mess, but by now it is pretty stable, at least to me, as a new player of Rome 2 who didn't experience its begginigns, I'm yet to find bugs or problems like crashes (none in the 57 hours of gameplay I have at the time of writing this review). I have been playing the original Rome, and Medieval 2 for some time now, those were my first 2 total war games, and I love them, but I'm fastly getting close to equal the hours I have put to those games playing Rome 2, and that is because I find this game very different to them, yet, amazing.First thing I noticed before buying this game, was the ammount of DLC it has, and a lot of them are just ridiculous to be sold as such, like the Greek culture pack and blood. Blood, as a DLC, and not as a graphical option, really? Nevermind, I payed for those 2 on sale, and I will get most of the rest when they are on sale again, NEVER on the normal price, because I don't support what SEGA is doing here.Another thing I noticed that is different from the original Rome and Medieval 2, is the workshop integration. You can find some amazing mods made by the community, from small ones to improve your gameplay and experience, textures to improve graphics, and complex yet high quality overhauls like Divide et Impera. Like I have been saying, this game is really different from the other 2 I mentioned, it took me a little while to get used to the new system of conquest and managing cities, and now I'm loving it, and the battles are improved as well, that nice feeling you get when using the cinematic camera while charging to your enemy is just priceless. I recommend this game, I don't support what SEGA did here, again, but the game in itself is great. If you can, get it on sale, because the DLC is just not worth the whole price, I just whish this evil market strategy changes in the future.

content:

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Diplomacy! I have played many games in the Total War series. This is the first one (IMO) that allows you to deploy diplomatic strategy with good effect. This really gives you a new way of planning your expensionism. E.g. 1) I make strong allies, help them in war. Though they have a city I need for my region. By creating unrest with agents I get the city to rebel and I conquer without damaging. E.g. 2) When I have no intention to spread further in a certain direction (north), I help a local faction by teaming up and target (that's an option now) adjecent territories. I reinforce while he leads the attack. This way I gain a very appreciative friend, with a territory that closes my border (like a buffer). Now I can fully dedicate my forces south

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Rome II lacks the theme that games such as the original Rome: Total War and Shogun II had. Never did I once feel like I was in the time period. Rome II suffers from its simplified designs and arcade-styled approach. Everything feels lackluster and many of the game mechanics hurt the game, overcomplicating your experience. The unit rosters are poorly made and most are copy-pasted and reskinned. Combat feels rubbish, though the campaign experience is a tad bit better. I have to commend the amount of artistic content put into the map. All in all, Rome II is not a terrible game, but a very hollow one. It fails to deliver to what Creative Assembly had promised fans. I recommend skipping.

												I have played all of the Total War games and I found Rome 2 to be the worst launch of them all. number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Let me start by admitting that Rome II was launched before it was ready. Because of this, it experienced a rocky start and brought out the Rome II haters in full force. However, CA has worked hard by patching these issues as quickly as possible. I can honestly say that the game now runs EXTREMELY good on my computer and displays unrivaled graphics excellence in a turn based strategy game. Rome II is revolutionary in the Total War series by giving you much larger cities to fight in and the addition of amphibious landings which are nice additions to the series. I own every Total War game besides the first Shogun, and therefore have been fortunate enough to watch this series get better and better with every release. Conquring the known world never gets old! Rome II is unrivaled in its abilty to give you an awesome turn based empire building game and ALSO include beautifully rendered battles. When you attack or defend against a rival army, Total War games give you the ability to be the general on the battlefield and lead your troops to victory personally! Rome II also has a great modding community that allows you to play the game just about any way you choose! Rome II battles are a little unrealistic in the speed at which units move and the fact that transport ships are almost as strong as actual war ships I wish it would be slowed down a bit, and more strength given to warships, but there are plenty of realistic mods that do this for you. The Steam Workshop makes it easy to install and use these mods. CA does a great job balancing this game, but again takes away some realism because of this. Roman units are not as tough as they were in real life, but again there are mods that can fix this for you.I LOVE this game, and am always excited when I have time to play! Keep up the good work CA!!!Long live the Republic!SPQR

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												The amount of haters and naysayers here is astonishing. Yeah, sure the game had to be patched up due to bugs. Sometimes the AI doesn't make good moves and ends up undoing itself. Maybe it takes ages for the AI to set up siege. But the gameplay itself is very, very good. Controlling armies of Rome, Carthage, Egypt, Macedon and other superpowers of the time across ancient Europe and fighting it out for domination sounds good, doesn't it? And this game excecutes it well, by having sieges, coastal battles, ambushes and many other features. The campaign interface is a little confusing to start with, but gets easier to understand after the prologue. Also, even though some parts may not be historically correct, it's a game, right? It's not meant to be an educational experience. All in all, I found this game addictive, and that it played well, even though I'm on a laptop.8.5/10

												My biggest complaint having played since Shogun is that the units bonuses make no sense what so ever.  Italian Spearmen are by far the most OP units in the game, and can't be beat by melee specific infantry units. Would not recommend spending the money on it until its no more then $20 if that.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This Game is a mixed bag. Let's start with the bad thing. They are: the AI, which is very bad.... they tried to fix it but still is not good enough. Units during combat become chaotic and in turns in to a massive cluster f**k. The game had some performance problems but I have played it today again and it run very smooth on high settings (My rig is 3570k OC, EVGA 660ti 2gb, 8gb 1600 RAM CL9). The good thing about this game is... the scale. There is nothing like fighting with 3000 Romans versus a horde of 7000 barbarians. It also innovates from the previous iterations of Total War. It adds features like Land and Naval combat on one map. It has some limited politics but not as in depth as Crusader Kings 2. Overall I hated this game when it came out but the recent patches seem to have addressed most of the issues and now I found myself playing for 8h strait. I don't know much about multilayer as I haven't spent much time playing it. I don't like the fact that they put soo much DLC out for example they knew that people will want to play as Sparta so they decided to charge for it. If you are a fan of games like Crusader kings 2 or Civ 5 only buy this game if you miss the lack of advanced combat. Thank You for reading this review. It is my first review and I hope I can make more in the future.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is a fine example of the classical stuggles that occured before the Pax Romana. It also shows the passing time with uses of the older Roman tri-line formations consisting of; Hastati, Principes, and Triarii, while also including the later Marion reforms with the induction of the modern uniform legions. While I love Rome this game does have it's faults. I would give this game a 7/10. It introduces new and cool things but it is not as polished as Shogun 2. There are many bugs and frustrating gliches in this game which makes it very hard to enjoy. Also ♥♥♥♥ Oathsworn. They are the strongest unit in the game in my opinion. Theu have extremely good stats overall but they have a ridiculously high melee defence making them all but unkillable in close combat. Great Job

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Brand new to the game, but I actually kindof like it. Granted, I have not played RTWI or anything else in the Total War series. However, Total War as a whole is very interesting. The biggest downside for me personally is crashing and replay glitches. As mentioned, this game has some serious bug problems. It also crashes (for me) unpredictably. EDIT: Crashing seems to have been fixed in the last updateIn terms of gameplay (I assume the whole Total War series works this way), it feels like a hybrid between Civilization and Age of Empires. Like Age of Empires, you can command your troops on the battlefield and organize formations in real time (except even better: you can pause it offline! Drives me crazy in Age of Empires!). Like Civilization, you can persue diplomacy, setup trade, and manage military positions from one province to the next in turn-based campaign. There are a few elements which really cannot be compared to either. Cinematic camera and inter-character communication is one of them. It does really feel like something from the movies. This game is probably even more combat dependant than Age of Empires, and far more combat dependant than Civilization. You are pretty much forced to wage wars of expansion, not just sit back on your haunches and make the world your friend. In Age of Empires it is theoretically possible to win by creating a wonder and develop such a powerful defensive network that few dare attack, and those who do suffer (I have never seen it happen except VS AI). In Civilization (AI games, I can't do online for some reason), you can use science, "diplomacy" (i.e. monopoly on city state puppets), and culture to avoid war, just as long as you have a significant military to intimidate the opposition. In RTWII, you pretty much have to take stuff over as part of the overall victory condition. I have to say, I have never played anything quite like it. A very interesting franchise, when it works.[I am not going to give it a /10 rating, because I have no idea what it would be]

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Before everything: DO NOT buy this game, buy the excellent original Rome and you won't be disappointed.The original Rome: Total War was ten times better than this product of pure greed and reliance on old glory. Shogun 2 was the last good game of the franchise.The permanent army experience and naming feature is the only reason I still sometimes play this game. It allows me to role-play and create my ''Legio Marinae Corpus'', ''Leonidas' Spears'' or ''Alexander's Own Horse Guards'' etc.  Again: it is the ONLY reason I still, SOMETIMES, play this game.I have played every Total War game ever, so I have quite some experience with the series.With these basic statements in mind, we can continue onwards.No more pre-battle rousing general speeches. No more ''forward! - oi!'' unit responses.No more the g*y green Brutii or the boisterous blue Scipii and, of course. the ravaging red Julii.No more ''g e n i t a l?'' for ''general?''No more universal, international mercenary convention regarding green uniforms. No more the screeching women, Amazons in Estonia, falxmen, bastarnae.Joke aside, although some of the above are really missed...Now for the real fallacies:Selling factions for ridiculous prices that should have been ingame.IF YOU WANT TO SELL INDIVIDUAL FACTIONS, make the game cost 30 euros and every faction 1 euro. I would NEVER, ever play with, for example, the stinking Gauls, or the Parthians, so THAT would be a good move. But NOT paying 50 euros for a game with 10 factions and then selling 20 other factions at 6 euros per faction. No, no!No more city swapping in diplomacy.Still lvl 9999 armored hoplites and scythed chariots/elephants/entire cavalry divisions in risen slave armies and in bandit armies. SLAVES SHOULD HAVE INCREASED MORALE, MAKESHIFT SPEARS AND SOME SWORDS, SLINGS AND CLUBS, NOT ELEPHANTS AND GOLDEN HOPLITES. Bandits should be a tad little bit stronger than that.Greedy DLC spamming with features that should have been in game already.Sea battles decided by numbers. Still the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ diplomacy.Family system easily understandable by 5-year-olds (almost non-existent). Politics system ditto. A 2000 legionnaires-strong unit is still called ''legion'' and is the largest tactical unit available.A 160-men legionary unit is still called a ''cohort''. The blood&gore DLC, although it costs mere eurocents, made me the most angry. Seriously? SELLING blood, wounds, animations for weapons dealing wounds, and blood-stained tunics and shields OUTSIDE THE STANDARD PRODUCT? With modern technology. graphic cards, graphic standards in games? GREED! GREED! GREED! SHAME ON YOU!I am not buying another CA game until they return to what they were, which I highly doubt. Do not buy this game even on a discount. Their sales have fallen by 70% because they are a pack of greedy scoundrels. Do not support them! Do not let them live on the glory of the good, old games.Oh, yes, the good things about the game:Sea-land battlesUnit graphicsand, well...Cavalry yelling ''macaco''Infantry yelling the incorrect yet good-sounding ''legio parati''.The permanent army status, gaining experience and traits for the whole army, ever onwards.The horn sounds when you give order to attack. Epic every 20th time. Other 19 times: lousy, dysonant.That about does it. Now go and play Rome: Total War. The first one!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Brand new to the game, but I actually kindof like it. Granted, I have not played RTWI or anything else in the Total War series. However, Total War as a whole is very interesting. The biggest downside for me personally is crashing and replay glitches. As mentioned, this game has some serious bug problems. It also crashes (for me) unpredictably. EDIT: Crashing seems to have been fixed in the last updateIn terms of gameplay (I assume the whole Total War series works this way), it feels like a hybrid between Civilization and Age of Empires. Like Age of Empires, you can command your troops on the battlefield and organize formations in real time (except even better: you can pause it offline! Drives me crazy in Age of Empires!). Like Civilization, you can persue diplomacy, setup trade, and manage military positions from one province to the next in turn-based campaign. There are a few elements which really cannot be compared to either. Cinematic camera and inter-character communication is one of them. It does really feel like something from the movies. This game is probably even more combat dependant than Age of Empires, and far more combat dependant than Civilization. You are pretty much forced to wage wars of expansion, not just sit back on your haunches and make the world your friend. In Age of Empires it is theoretically possible to win by creating a wonder and develop such a powerful defensive network that few dare attack, and those who do suffer (I have never seen it happen except VS AI). In Civilization (AI games, I can't do online for some reason), you can use science, "diplomacy" (i.e. monopoly on city state puppets), and culture to avoid war, just as long as you have a significant military to intimidate the opposition. In RTWII, you pretty much have to take stuff over as part of the overall victory condition. I have to say, I have never played anything quite like it. A very interesting franchise, when it works.[I am not going to give it a /10 rating, because I have no idea what it would be]

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game.I was a big, big fan of Rome 1, and really enjoyed Empire TW too. However, this is just not as good as the original Rome. It feels like for every step forward graphically, there has been a step back in gameplay terms.The family tree and associated events are missing, robbing the game of character and your attachment to particular units. You can now only move an army if a general is in command, which is overly restrictive as you can no longer split armies. Upgrading cities and technology makes no sense - it tries to be Civilisation but without any resource requirements. Also, most annoyingly, the distance from which reinforcements can join your battle is immense - armies from anywhere within the province a battle is taking place can join as a reinforcement. As some provinces are more than a screen in size, this feels particularly silly. That army from across a mountain range you need to scroll across to find? Yep, simply because it is in the same province you can expect to see it advancing upon your position in a few minutes.Odd and average.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												It's a bimbo of a game; so much beauty but no brains. CA has gone wildly astray with both Shogun and now Rome II. The game has a massive map, beautifully rendered cities, but it doesn't use them to create a compelling strategy game. The tech tree is dumbed down, the diplomacy system leaves much to be desired and the urban and infrastructure development is very shallow. Developments to eg public order and dynasties have potential to make a difference but are poorly executed.The result is that you go from one stunning battle to another, but that is all there is and you can get pretty bored of that. If CA would use the beautiful citiscapes to create a new interface on civic managmenet with a detailed political, economic, tech and social/dynasty systems the game would be much more immersive and enjoyable. As it is don't bother with the campaign, just enjoy the battles straight from the start menu as that is all the campaign has to offer anyway.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												TOTAL WAR ROME 2. It should be renamed CA's POS! Even post 8 patches there are still glitches like the black box and there are still major fps drops; but the thing I hate the most is that CA is releasing freaking DLC for this game while most people still cannot play it because of its unoptimization. CA claimed that this game would "be able to run on virtually any machine:" well whoever said that must've been fired, because this game is the complete opposite. I sat all night long playing Total War Shogun 2 until my dream game, the sequel to one of the best Total War games, came out; then my eyes were assaulted with the horrors of Total War: Rome 2: there were framerates constantly dropping from 30 to 15 on low settings (on my moderate PC), unfathomable bugs, and an overall experience that put me one step away from the series. Therefore, after long patching, I believe you should not purchase this game, not just because of its glitches but because of its somewhat mediocre gameplay overall: Battles are 90% men marching and 10% actual fighting, the campaign and battle uis are both terrible and hard to use (the best thing you can do is move your cards wherever you want). My final rating is 6/10 DO NOT BUY THIS POS GAME

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												First of all, I am not rating this game based on CA's strategy to pour out useless DLCs. Most of the DLC are next to useless, and priced so high, but you can choose not to purchase them, so the DLCs should not be taken into account. Unlike Crusader Kings 2 DLC that introduces new mechanics, TW Rome II DLC usually only introduce new units, new battles, and new campaigns. The campaigns may have new mechanics, but the mechanics only limited to that particular campaign, so I conclude that DLCs is not so important.Now on to the game.VisualsVisuals are pretty, the details of each units, buildings, and terrains are great. This is a Total War game anyway, so some individuals in units will look alike, but that should not concern you. Differences between units are quite good. Only few units in Roman are look alike to each other. Tactical GameplayBattles are great, there is nothing to worry about that. Early builds "mash-up" are not existing anymore. Though there are some concerns of AI pathing, especially when trying to sally out from your fortress, or getting through the breach in the walls. In these two particular situations sometimes the AI still gets to bunch up and refuses to get into the breach, which in siege battles have serious repercussions. Ladder/siege tower mess has been fixed too, units are not stuck again in the walls and have difficulty navigating the walls like previous Total War series. Individual units also have good abilities which can be used in battles, for example Testudo Formation in Roman legions. Archers and ranged projectiles units sometimes also have options on their ammunition, increasing ways to play the battle.Naval combat is not really my expertise, but it is good nevertheless. The usual wind is there. Most of the naval combat are resolved by ramming, so position is key, which are shown well in the game. Boarding actions are also shown in better hand to hand combat animation, and as always, ship sinking is shown beautifully. Strategic GameplayThere are not much changes from the previous series, that have to be admitted. There are some new ways : for example you have to build the cities and its villages, not only you build the cities. There are also a Civil War mechanic, and some small Roman politics. These all changes are small, and in no way compared to Crusader Kings II politics machinery. You can kill, bribe, etc. like in Crusader Kings II but the effect is somewhat lighter. The AI is also annoying, and seems a little bit stupid. Most of them kept asking for gold in exchange of peace treaty, while in fact your nation is the strongest military. It makes no sense, smaller nations will ask for peace treaty/NAP and give bigger nations tribute, in this game small nations force bigger nations to give out gold. Though in diplomacy sense, it is way improved than the last Rome Total War series. You don't have to send a diplomat agent anymore, and the actions of your nation to other nation will also be viewed positively/negatively by other nations.Conclusion :For Total War players, at the current build it is great to play, and great to have.You don't have to buy the DLC, I got one DLC from some bundles. Maybe I will buy them in future, but not now, they are priced too high for nothing, especially the blood and gore that should be in the game at the first place.

												Fun in a variety of ways, but very time consuming.  If you like playing the turn-based game, you can do that and let the computer manage individual battles.
