content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												After waiting 2 years of optimization and a sale on the emperor edition, i finally bought Rome 2. I've been playing total war since Rome 1, i avoided Rome 2 because i anticipated the terrible release after the lukewarm beta leaks.I read a lot of people ranking Rome 1 , Medieval 2 and Shogun 2 above Rome 2 even after the Emperor edition.Those people are ragers completely stuck on the terrible Rome 2 release, and obsessed with Rome1/medieval 2 mods.Rome 1 and Medieval 2 engines are completely outdated and no amount of "historical accuracy", scripted mechanics that bloat the engine, or unit reskinning, can make up for core programming obsolescence.At the time of this review, Rome 2 is the best TW on the market. The map is beautiful, the combat works well, the UI is good, the new province mechanic is very smart...The graphics even on ultra are a bit disappointing but ENB mods will fix that.Buy it !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The worst thing about this game is that it had the potential to be the best Total War in the series. As it is, it falls short. Ignoring that, however, it is a pretty decent game. Although there are only around 10 or so factions that you can play as, there are a huge amount of minor factions on the campaign map which adds a lot to the atmosphere and diversity of the game (as well as the time it takes for a turn to finish lel). This was a welcome addition in Empire and it is good that they have kept it in successive games rather than reverting to the swathes of "rebel" settlements that plagued Rome 1 and Medieval 2. Graphically, it is pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ I personally think Shogun 2 looked better. I don't quite know what it is but there is something "off" in how it looks. Music is pretty decent, not as good as the first Rome's but it isn't bad. The campaign map does look delicous though.Now for things I don't like. Ship combat is severly ♥♥♥♥ed. Ramming a ship head on does basically the same damage as ramming it from the side, which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This basically nullifies manouvering as AI ships just come straight at you and there is nothing you can do to curb the damage. I intensely dislike how they removed buildings outside of the main province centre. I loved how in Shogun 2 and Empire you could raid farms, mines, lumberyards and ports. I also don't particularly like the "streamlined" province management which has one big city and then several smaller villages. In theory it is great but it means cities like Syracuse, Rhodes, Sparta and Memphis are basically reduced to villages while large cities like Capua are completely ♥♥♥♥ing removed because they needed to put in some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little village that was on the coast. Too many rebellions. I have to dedicate far too much of my military resources to wiping out rebellions. There is also little reward for completely destroying a rebel army. You'd think that slaughtering an army to the last man would increase public order for a little while but no. It is also pretty inconsistent and nonsensical. My single worst province is Italia which has right from the start been a♥♥♥♥♥♥that is constantly having rebellions. Illyria on the other hand has been a model province and has been extremely happy with my rule. One might think that I was playing as a Barbarian faction but no, I am playing as Rome. All in all, it is a decent game. Patches are still coming out fairly regularly although besides the public order issues (none of which the AI suffers from of course) and the ship damage few of the annoying issues can be fixed.  7/10.>Italians>White

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Being a long time fan of Rome: Total War, I went into this game expecting a great experience. After a sorry start Creative Arts has really made a game that, in my opinion, is the best stratgy game I have ever played. You really can get emotionally involved. For example, when an experienced general, whom you have put alot of effort into dies, you can't help but cry a little. You really feel like you are living and dieing with your men and you want them to survive. The graphics are fantastic too, both on the battlefield and on the map. Agents can do alot more and the diplomacy options are simple to use but at the same time very complex in the sense that you have several ways to subdue your enemies and allies. The economic system is great too. You have to balance your military buildings with your economic and you need to ensure that you have enough food for your population and growing armies. As far as unit balance goes it may need a few tweaks but overall you don't feel like your being treated unfairly. All in all a great game. 10/10.

												I played Rome: Total War, Medieval 2: Total War, Empire: Total War and a bit of Shogun. But I have to say that this one is the best right after the original Rome: Total War.Here is why:The old Rome was a genius blast with an atmosphere drowning you deep into the anctient world. I played a hundred of hours, different factions, different approaches..Of course, with the great plus of nostalgica i prefer the old Rome. But!This game is also a very enjoyable piece of work. I play the game with the radious mod, which gives more detail to the armies and the campaign itself.The variety and deep of the game without letting you getting confused is what i appreciate most. Or watching your little soldier fight to death. Pros:- Very detailled (not only modded)- Awesome fights- Need tactics on the campaign map and in fights- light diplomacy- A lot of modsCons:- Maybe not deep enough for some people. I love these kind of games because you can do much more stuff than just fight. I recommend this game to everyone who wants a strategy game that does not goes "too" deep into it, leaving enough room for some bloody action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Rome 2 was a horrible game when it released. It was full of game breaking bugs such as dead AI, turns taking more than 5 minutes to complete, huge FPS drops from doing something simple like clicking on a city and so many more. Now that it has received almost 20 patches and is finally fixed it is no longer one of the worst games ever released - it is merely the worst Total War game ever released.What I like: The graphicsWhat I dislike: Literally everything else. The "politics system" is neither politics nor a system, it's a broken idea that doesn't do anything. You can go through an entire game without ever opening the politics tab and you won't notice. The music is bland and boring and doesn't bring the game to life like in Rome 1, Medieval 2 or Shogun 2. No family tree, making important people within your empire faceless, nameless and pointless. Generals and important people in your realm are non-entities. In previous Total War games losing a beloved faction leader or general could break your heart. In Rome 2 there are no beloved faction leaders or generals and when you do lose one they are instantly replaced by some other faceless non-entity.The list of things this game got wrong is almost endless. I find it impossible to become immersed in its setting, I feel nothing when playing it. I've tried very hard to like it as I spent £34.99 on it and have been a fan of Total War since the days of Medieval 1, but I simply can't. It is truly horrible.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												I loved total war shogun 2 so i decided to pick this game up on sale and have enjoyed it.  While most of the game is ok I do have a few major complaints.  First off is how long it takes to transistion between turns due to ai moves this is most notable in the beggining of a campaign due to the sheer number of factions.  Secondly armies seem to take forever to move compared to shogun 2 (number of turns not actual animation speed which can be sped up).  Third it does seem like there is a bit of imbalance in terms of a small number of heavy units being able to route much larger armies.  The province system also feels a little cluncky compared with land management in shogun 2.  My last issue is that sea combat feels like it was a last minute addition when compared with the amazing feel of land combat.  A little thing that felt wrong was the lack of you generals opening cinematic speech.  If you are new to the series go play shogun 2 it is an amazing game which this is not the only thing i thought was better was that each faction has its own units other than that shogun 2 wins on almost every count.  I would only suggest picking this up on sale and after you have played shogun 2 to the point that if you ever see an army of naginata samurai and archers again youll go screaming through town in your underwear.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												If this was the first total war game in existence i might have recomended this game.Why you shouldnt buy this game- Poor AI.- Poor graphic optimization.- Poor modability.- Stripped down City building.- Stripped down combat, and tactical control over units(ability to group and decide formations)- They decided to implement a combat style that revolves around control points when assaulting cities which if implemented correctly could have been good.- Poor naval combat.- Poor balance of units.- DLC all over the place with units and features that should have been on release.Why you might consider getting this game, if your a total war addict just like me and loved rome1.- Mods can provide an refreshing experience even though its a harder game to mod than rome 1 or even medieval 2.- Even though naval combat is poorly implemented with mods you might achieve a good degree of fun.The vanilla experience of this game is terrible, even the multiplayer is bad in this game compared to the previous titles.In my opinion if your looking for a good and modern total war game to play go ahead and buy shogun2, but if you really are looking for a rome 2 id suggest going for mods of rome 1 they outshine Rome 2 by miles.And notice the date of this review they still havent fixed or improved the game to the point of being good for release.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Happy to see most of the pathing fixed over that last few months with the apparent exception being the seige equipment, whom must be handled carefully lest they become mutinous and ignore all command and reason. Still very pleased with the provincial system of Rome 2. The recent update has only made things better. Now it's much easier for your nation to avoid devolving into a riotous mass without a temple in every city and town.Only other complains are related to the way some territory lines are draw, such as a town holding ownership over a small stretch of road on the far side of a dense forest; the ability for computer players have their sailors stop an enemy ship in the ramming animation, only to board it killing all on board;  and finally, the ability for pikemen to materialize their massive spears and force push heavy infantry back to the far end of the spear whilst being stabbed in the chestAs a side note, the glitch where sailors will return to their ship after boarding, by jumping clear over a third ship that has rammed its way inbetween is amazing. Their bionic legs are truely a sight to behold. Thank you for this and thank you for continued support for this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Summation-AI-Graphics-Variation-Campaign Map-UI-Gameplayif you want gameplay get shogun 2 or medieval 2 or an old Total War and mod it.if you want the era get rome 1 and for graphics mod it.if you want graphics get shogun 2.Rome 2 does nothing better, it is a horrible blend of all the total wars with 'streamlined' elements.Rome 2 Total War failed to enchant me in the same way any other total war game has done.I have 91 hours on record which is low compared to other total war games. Rome 2 offers nothing which other total war games and even mods dont do better. The main issue is, undoubtedly, the AI - it is so incompetent and just downright stupid the entire game becomes a grind with no challenges ever raised other than the question of if your rig can handle the huge amounts of rabble the AI insists upon fielding. The armies it composes while no longer 90% slingers are terrible. Every army, no matter the faction, is composed almost 60% of skirmishers, 30% of the lowest tier of spearmen and then 10% other units are usually artillery with amybe one or two units of cavalry and all the AI generals are infantry which is the worst general type until possibly late game because it is your only access to high tier shock cavalry.Now an army of skirmishers isn't always terrible it can be used effectively but the AI doesn't do so. It sends its skirmishers unsupported towards you to try to barrage you but unless you are afk then it just lets you charge them with your cavalry or even heavy infantry. From there the rest of its units will engage the meat grinder and you ar invited to rear charge them as you meet no opposition in doing so, the only unit you may have trouble with the the one oathsworn general which can be annoying to break. Every battle goes like this.I said the graphics were a negative, which i'm sure many people will be surprised at. They are not bad persay however they are also not even in the same league as Shogun 2 and i prefer Napoleon's graphics over this. The main reason is everyone looks smudged, even on max with unlimited texture memory and whats more it looked better in the demos they previewed. I appreciate there is a lot more work to due because there are a lot more factions but they are not as phenomenal as was promised and they are very lackluster compared to Shogun 2. Not only are they worse technically the unit cards are awful, they are some of the ugliest artwork i have seen in a long time.Not only are the graphics worse than Shogun 2 the sound design is no where near as good, the music is worse than rome 1 and the combat sounds do nothing to inspire.The game is clunky at best - the UI, in attempts to streamline it, has been made into an inefficent mess which is painful to use. The 'tactical map' is pointless and serves no purpose - the minimap is just as good and the maps are still so small that you can see everything anyway. You cannot view routing enemy units with any form of map which is infuriating since it is more imnportant than ever to kill every last man in the unit because of huge replenishment rates. There is no fire at will option for units with pila removing any utility they had and making counter charging mandatory which just results in both armies clashing in the middle haphazardly.Ships are so unresponsive - you try to turn, ram or board and they bob slowly before spontaneously combusting because or everyone leaping off because no observable structual damage had occured. The AI boards you even if you tap them and if you attempt to ram them then you better instantly kill them else they're going to board you. Naval battles may as well be removed and thanks to quick march i found myself never even making boats especially due to the inordiante upkeep costs and everyones pocket inflatable massive ships which are larger than dedicated boats and far more efficient for crossing any body of water you need to because the 'fast rowing' allows you to traverse the entire medditerainian in 3 turns.The building system has been made into a joke. You no longer have any reason to upgrade past tier 2 buildings since the benifits do not outweight the negatives in most cases and money is not even a factor. I was earing well over 25k after <50 turns and while the 'economic victory' demands 80k/turn you really stop caring at around 25k and frankly i stopped even bothering to look at what my cities were doing which is a huge shame since for me 1/2 the fun of total war was the strategic element perviously i loathed automanage but now in Rome 2 i pine for its return although i have no doubt it would be completely useless.A problem i have had with not only Rome 2 but other recent total wars with this is the limitations on how many buildings you can make in each city. It does not add any strategic element, you do not have to carefully consider where you need to place your buildings and have no reason to build anything other than markets everywhere because it isn't worth a slot to make a barracks near the frontlines especially in Rome 2 where they are shifting so fast it is pointless to try.However the shifting battle lines isn't due to any AI actions or surprise attacks, the battle lines shift in one direction: towards your enemy. Every turn i conqure 2/3 cities, and this isn't even after 80 turns or so, because the AI not only poseses no threat but the replenishment system is absurd. Any losses i suffer from a battle are instantly replenished because with only 25 food i have +40% replenishemnt and while that not only breaks gameplay it makes no sense, where do i find elite praetorians or spartan heroes in the middle of britain?Although there isnt much differnce between any of the factions so it doesn't surprise me. The one thing Rome 2 could have had over Shogun 2 was faction variation but the variation that there is is pitiable - Every faction which uses swords also has pila even the greeks have pila and they all function in the exact same way. The differnce, other than asthetic, between the gauls and romans is that the galic units are just worse variations for the same cost. The all serve the same purpose and function in the same way. The greeks are the same only use spears instead of swords and forgo their pila. Mobility and utility are all gone you have three unit types: ranged, heavy infantry and cavalry.The politics system is laughable i honestly dont even know how it works and it seems to do nothing at all. It serves as a medium for the other AI houses, of which there may be no members, to randomly assassinate your generals. Though not that it matters since they can be conjured for free anywhere and none of their traits do anything meaningful. The final nail in the coffin to me, and a huge slap in the fact to Total War's great modding community, is the current DLC practices. This has to be mentioned and it does matter, it is not a matter of dont want it dont buy it, it directly effects the game and in a negative way. Faction packs are an outright insult to modders. Charging for content present is unacceptable and should be punished. I don't blame CA for this i blame SEGA and as a side note i would abvocate avoiding any SEGA game of recent date CoH2 and now this have made me lose any faith i may have misplaced in SEGA.And god damn it people stop praising them to high heaven for patching the damned thing! We are entitled to a working product and they are obliged to patch it! It is not some great act of charity!The worst total war for a long time. It pushes no boundries which at least emprie tried to, its graphics are worse than shogun 2's as is the sound design, it has terrible AI and gameplay which somehow modders seem more capable of creating, the campaign map is so simple and mundane it becomes a chore, and it has horrendously prolonged campaign victory conditions.(nobody read this did they :( oh well im typing it while mining and i dont blame you)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I dont understand all the hate for this game. I've been playing total war for abut 3 or four years now. I have Napoleon, Medieval 2, Medieval, and Rome 2 total war. This is second in my list (Behind Medieval total war).  Im going to break this review into four parts: Battle, Campaign, Graphics, and Overview.Overview:Rome 2 total war is an amazing game. It's loads of fun that will keep you glued to your screen for hours. If you get it though, get it on sale. Because $60 is too much for a two year old game. Plus, you NEED the greek states pack to fully enjoy this game. That add Athens, Sparta, And Lipidus* (*Really bad seplling, soz). And that eads me onto my next point, beware of the DLC. They nickle anddime you to death.  Like, they have a tab on the main meu dedicated to dlc you havent bought yet. And on the campaign tab, they have all of there DlC Campigns listed with the grand campaign to remind you to buy ore DLC! (as if the game isn't already expensive) But get over that, its an amazing game.Battle:Battles are a lot of fun. If you do a custom battle, you can select any map, by simply clicking somewhere on a map of the entire campign map (basically, there is hundreds of maps) There are bunchs of factions to choose from, adding to the customizaable aspect of custom battles. The unit cards are creative, they aren't scrrenshots of the unit, they are cards made to look like art from that time. The UI is easy to get used to, and very helpful.  As usual, the battles are very stratigic, and fun to watch you legionares slay barbarians in droves. Dont let the odds fool you. Ive won battes Ive should have lost many a time, and im terrible at battles! Naval battle are the best. I actually enjoy them. They are short, lasting 2 - 5 minutes on average. I could go on and on, but in short, battles are amazing an work really well.Campaign:The Campaign map looks great. It actually feels like you are looking over the world. The campign is fun, but takes some getting used to. the UI is very confusing, but once you figure it out, it flows well. Diplomacy is strange, like I'll be Rome, and a tiny facton wont want to do a non agressive pact. but once you bribe them with money, they comply. Wars work well, with new stances making it more stratigic then past total wars. Its hard to conquer other nations, but ROme wasn't built in a day!Graphics:Very Very taxing. the reccomended specs are lies. i can hardly run this on high, much less very high, ultra, and extreme, and i have a very decent laptop. but, the game looks amazing. That's all i can say. It looks amazing.Rome 2 has its flaws, but they are few and is a very good game and comes highly reccomended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Being a long time fan of Rome: Total War, I went into this game expecting a great experience. After a sorry start Creative Arts has really made a game that, in my opinion, is the best stratgy game I have ever played. You really can get emotionally involved. For example, when an experienced general, whom you have put alot of effort into dies, you can't help but cry a little. You really feel like you are living and dieing with your men and you want them to survive. The graphics are fantastic too, both on the battlefield and on the map. Agents can do alot more and the diplomacy options are simple to use but at the same time very complex in the sense that you have several ways to subdue your enemies and allies. The economic system is great too. You have to balance your military buildings with your economic and you need to ensure that you have enough food for your population and growing armies. As far as unit balance goes it may need a few tweaks but overall you don't feel like your being treated unfairly. All in all a great game. 10/10.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												After playing this game for over 350 hours from the very beginning, I'd thought I'd give my personal views on the game. As I'm sure many of you are aware, the release for this game was by far the worst of any CA games with poor AI (especially with the capture the flag mode in particular), crash issues and a generally poor game performance. I've stuck through it though due to my experiences with previous titles like Shogun and Medieval, and the perseverance on my part has been rewarded, sure there have been high and low moments like the excitement with the release of the campaigns and the disappointment of the Animals and the Women of Mars DLC, but the version you will be buying is a great leap from what this game was in the beginning, but note it isn't perfect as the AI still needs some tinkering, especially in regards to siege battles, but it is a very playable and fun experience.Overall- Pros: 1. Without DLC the variety of cultures has a good diversity from the Iceni in Britain to the Parthians in the Middle East2. The Emperor version and it's revamped Political and Civil War systems allows better immersion into the game3. With a very active modding community on steam workshop, you can find even more things to play and have fun withCons: 1. Despite the vast ammount of work put into fixing it, the AI in battles and campaign can be problematic2. A large ammount of very interseting nations such as Sparta and Thracians are restricted as DLC, as such some of the more interesting factions are out of bounds for those who are either anti-DLC or incapable of purchesing them.Personal Score: a decent 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												After playing this game for over 350 hours from the very beginning, I'd thought I'd give my personal views on the game. As I'm sure many of you are aware, the release for this game was by far the worst of any CA games with poor AI (especially with the capture the flag mode in particular), crash issues and a generally poor game performance. I've stuck through it though due to my experiences with previous titles like Shogun and Medieval, and the perseverance on my part has been rewarded, sure there have been high and low moments like the excitement with the release of the campaigns and the disappointment of the Animals and the Women of Mars DLC, but the version you will be buying is a great leap from what this game was in the beginning, but note it isn't perfect as the AI still needs some tinkering, especially in regards to siege battles, but it is a very playable and fun experience.Overall- Pros: 1. Without DLC the variety of cultures has a good diversity from the Iceni in Britain to the Parthians in the Middle East2. The Emperor version and it's revamped Political and Civil War systems allows better immersion into the game3. With a very active modding community on steam workshop, you can find even more things to play and have fun withCons: 1. Despite the vast ammount of work put into fixing it, the AI in battles and campaign can be problematic2. A large ammount of very interseting nations such as Sparta and Thracians are restricted as DLC, as such some of the more interesting factions are out of bounds for those who are either anti-DLC or incapable of purchesing them.Personal Score: a decent 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2013
												DJ's two-penneth and first impressions for those interested in the Total War franchise.  If you're not interested, then why'd you click it? The AI does seem a little oblivious to the world around it.  I'm not convinced by the battle speed, as I find I keep pausing  more than I ever used to in previous TW editions simply to issue orders and keep up with the dim AI.  I do get a sense of my gang's bigger than yours is the AI method and that's it.However, more positives than negatives for me - excluding launcher/fps issues.So far I quite like the emphasis put on the agents this time around.  I'm used to the spies to see the 4 corners, but I've literally only just learnt that you really do need them, as my campaign is about to crumble.  I have in the dying throes of my campaign now generated a truly mental water-poisoner to soften up a garrison before your seige (93% chance of success!) and a strong champion attached to your general enhances the melee ratings of your army etc.  Not sure about the diplomat yet, I think I needed her for 'religious conversion' as with medieval?  Next time I will be more prepared.I like the effort CA put into city growth/food/public order.  Steep learning curve, but actually it all makes sense once you realise it has a wealth of 'tooltips' to break up the bar graphs.Diplomacy seems harder, i've negotiated trade routes and within the next few turns almost the entire world has declared war on me within 15 turns of starting as Egypt.  Must learn about that... doesn't seem quite right to declare war on someone you've never met or live near.  My enemy (1) was not their ally/soverign state or anything.I like the enhanced graphics with some tweaking - the  'prettyness' of the heat haze over the pyramids for example, the fauna and flora is quite relaxing whilst campaigning.The campaign turns are taking a good 10m as there's plenty to do (and the fps type glitches slow matters) that seems compulsory this time around.  Not sure about the political part yet as yet to play as Rome.  Promotions of your family memebers does what exactly?Overall lots to learn and strategy techniques to refine regards the city/empire building which will keep me playing.  Battles are battles and the essence of TW, i'm hoping the topography will be more impactful this time around when I reach europe.  Only done a few sieges/defences and meh, but i'm hoping that's because I haven't the level ups yet for epic seiges.Armies walk on water into navies I don't like, and the reinforcement range seems to big to me.  Three auto-resolve battles between the same two opposing armies in a single turn is meh... one of you just die off will you!  Likewise the new 'tactics' option seems mute.  Stances for armies/navies is new, raid/ambush/tab march, but means an endless cycle of remembering to change it when you right click and nothing happens because you put it in a 'stance' last turn.Oh yeah, the [insert] battle cam is awesome.  I really like that, very immersive and for the one liners it's fantastic.  The audio actor/actress scripting is top notch for the game.  Multiple accent attempts too!Well played CA, there's enough refreshment to keep me amused and away from Napoleon & Empire for some time to come.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												So much hatred for a pretty good game... Well, the whole thing begins with lots of bugs, but as patches were out they fixed many of them. It's a decent "Total War" game with much better graphics, but less freedom. What I really disliked was that there are no world events, though this feature was already out from "Empire: Total War". AI diplomacy is too weak, for more factions to make up for the extremely challenging Mongols and Timurids in "Medieval 2". It makes you feel that history is too generic and does not touch you. Battles and tactics are once again outstanding, and I really liked the idea of joint land and naval battles. It even features an impressive soundtrack, even though many have reviled it. It is a bit unfair to give such a superb strategy game a dismal 4.0 out of 10, just because it does not meet some pretty high expectations. After all, it's much superior to "Rome: Total War" to begin with. I wanna give it 8.0 form10.0

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												 Personally, I believe the game is now stable enough to buy, play, and enjoy...to a extent.Good:-Some degree of difficulty when set on hard, most surrounding nations will make things hard by declaring, although a little annoying but some can be sensable.-AI wont rush directly at you at the start, they'll usually start forming their units or wait for reinforcements THEN charge in semi-organised mass at you-Province system is pretty decent-Defensive Alliances, military alliances, trade agreements, and non agression pacts make this game's diplomacy more fun and sensable.-Cool combined naval and ground attacks-Campaighn map is relatively lag free ( That I've noticed, can't say the same for battle map )-Great maps, beauitiful city layout, plains layouts, and anyother map looks really good.-A lot of different factions with different units unique to them-A fog of war, forcing you to have to go meet the other factions-Decent sized map with a lot of cities-Large armies-Active and great modding community to fix some of the things wronfg with the game (Such as morale, battle AI, etc. )BAD:-Siege AI stands outside walls or on beaches and takes javelin fire very rarely retaliating.(This seems to only happen on certain maps for me, Like on Karalis they will stand around and do nothing, yet in Roma they seem to be unstoppable.)-Morale for professionable units is kind of annoyingly low, even if they are winning they will still rout.-Battle map lag, makes directly commanding battles annoying-Auto resolve does not account for fortifications when doing auto resolve on sieges, so if you have a weak force in a city with great fortifications, you have to fight it out.-Political system is useless, I was hoping to have to juggle the Senate and actively try to find their approval and engage in politics, you really don't need to bother with the Senate.-AI doesn't seem to pursue diplomacy logically. Like if you have Carthage devastated and you are about to take the last city, but want peace so you can use a Legion elsewhere, they will most likely refuse.Overall, I rate the game a seven. Not as great as Medieval 2 in my opinion, but stable enough to buy for 20-30$. You still might wanna wait for a sale, but it isn't as much of a waist if you but it for full price. Ny suggestion, go watch a few recent Lets Play's and make your final descion on that.

												This game is awesome. I don't know what people are complaining about. I see a bunch of reviews about how "Shogun is better." Better graphics, new mechanics, AI, factions, realism, more immersive gameplay, diplomacy etc. with which to build an empire!Although a bit of a letdown when it first released because of a hasty release with bugs and such, pretty much all issues have been fixed or are being worked upon, ensuring a gameplay experience without any technical problems.Personally I'd prefer the diplomacy options to be a bit more refined, especially the way allies and vassals behave and can be controlled or asked for help.Quite some content is additionally available as (unfortunately payable) DLC's, but quite some Free-LC's have been available as well,adding new content.A bit overpriced, especially if you get all the DLC's, personally I'd suggest to just stay with the vanilla version +fixes and Free-LC's, they are more than enough to grant hours of gaming fun, as well as battles and campaigns that are never the same.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Total war: Rome II started out in rough condition, but after a year of solid patching culminating into the Rome II: Emperor Edition it has become one of my favorite games ever. If you are new to Total War, Rome II is a massive scope historical strategy game centered around the birth of the Roman Empire starting at 272 BC. At this time, there are massive amounts of cultures and conflicts with different people vying for power and for survival. Even Rome starts the game with humble amounts of land and power. It will be up to you to recreate the glory of the empire OR extinguish the dream of power for the Romans and have your own people dominate the world.Rome II has a massive amount of factions (around 120) with 32 being playable! not only are there so many factions, but there is considerable diversity between factions, especially between different cultures. Greek factions (including Sparta and Athens) boast powerful hoplites, spear infantry with very heavy armor who have the ability to form a hoplites wall which boosts there defensive capabilities significantly. Rome has it's famous legionairies who can form testudo formation where they lock their shields in a dense formation making them resistant to incoming archer fire. Eastern factions field powerful cavalry such as heavy armored cataphracts who devastate anything on the charge. Nomadic factions have entirely horse armies fielding mostly a giant horde of horse archers showing their preferred way of combat. There are so many unique units and armies to face depending on where in the world you are fighting.The campaign map is extremely large which is pretty typical for Total War games and has a "province" system where there can be anywhere from 2 - 4 cities within a province. There are many types of buildings  each colored coated ranging from city center(orange), military(red), industrial(brown), agriculture(green), sanitation(cyan), ports/docks(blue), temples(purple), and city commons(yellow). City center buildings are the main building and is present in every single city but can be upgraded to provide various bonuses (including more resources if that region has a strategic resource). Military provides the ability to recruit powerful units into your armies and provide garrison soldiers if the city is attached. Industrial provides mostly large amounts of wealth at the costs of food and public order. Agricultural building provide mostly food (in which your empire and armies would starve without) with a bit of wealth. Sanitation provides public order, some wealth, some culture, and many of bonuses depending on the faction. Ports are only available if the city is a port but can be branched to form military ports where you can train powerful fleets or trading ports where you can make more money. Temples are largely used for improving culture (culture problems can lead to large public order problems) and flat out public order bonuses at the cost of food. City commons are highly branched ranging from libraries (improving reseach time), gladiator games, wine traders, slave markets, and many more.The battles in total war are the hallmark of the game. Battles are massive in scale and provide a large range of tactics to defeat your enemy. Your armies are divided into units, comprising of 80-160 soldiers in a unit (depending on the unit size selection). You can have 20 units in an armies and up to four armies can be present for both the attacher and defender each. Do the math and you can see battles with over 10,000 individual units that you can zoom in and look at fighting for their lives. After the fighting occurs you can see the carnage wrought by your generals or your enemies as thousands lay dead. Truly awe inspiring and glorious. As far as tactics, there are stratagems available on both the grand campaign map and the battle maps. On the campaign map, you can move your armies into various stances such as raiding, defensive (where the army forms a fort), ambush stance (where you can make your army invisible to other forces and can ambush them if they fail to detect you), and forced marched which allows armies to move twice the distance BUT are guarenteed to be ambushed if caught in this stance! There are also bridges, forests, mountains, rivers, and other choke points on the grand campaign map that you can use to give yourself an advantage. On the battle map, there are large differences in terrain including dense forest, hillls, desert, rivers, bridges, and snow to utilize to help your armies achieve victory. Bridge can hold off massive amounts of troops using only 1 unit, forests can hide units allowing you spring quick ambushes, hills provide bonuses to those at a higher elevation and also you can hide units behind a hill if the enemy does not have line of sight. Snow and rain make units tire faster and have trouble recovering, fog makes ranged units' accuracy lower, etc. You can always use the terrain to your advantage!In summary, this game has incredible replay falue fielding so many factions where most are very diverse in terms of units, buildings, culture, events, and starting location. The province system forces you to spread your own culture, take strategic resources, and specialize/synergize your cities into maximizing your economy. The campaign map is highly detailed with many terrain factions to use when facing enemies. The battles are unrivaled and are extremely addicting fielding thousands of soldiers. Excellent DLC content with other campaign maps.As for negatives, there are no faction intro videos like other total war games. The game had a bad release due to various bugs and glitches and blatant oversights (though almost everything is fixed in my opinon). End game is too easy even on the highest difficulties. Lots of DLC that is enjoyable but you have to pay extra money for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												EDIT: I initially wrote this review two months after Rome 2 was released, which I think is obvious given my reaction to it. Total War games are, since Empire, not known for being in a particularly high-quality state at launch, but Rome 2 really took the biscuit. It was dreadful.Anyway, fast forward seven months. It's almost the end of June now, and Rome 2 has received 13 patches to date, as well as two main DLC expansions and several "free-LC" updates. The second of those major DLC expansions, Hannibal At The Gates, brought me back to Rome 2, and I have to say that the state of the game is far improved. Those awful "capture the flag" bits are gone, the technical performance of the game is better, there are more factions, more units, more features, more everything. The HatG mini-campaign is (annoying Agents aside) about as close to a perfect Total War campaign as I could ask for, and the factions are more balanced. Those unbearable turn-load times I mentioned before? Dealt with. Basically almost everything has been improved.There're still some glaring errors- siege AI remains fundamentally thick-headed, naval battles are still dogged by the AI insisting on clumping all its ships together in a mess when it regroups, and the policy of charging for factions still makes me sick- but the game is in a state where it can be played and enjoyed. That mod that brings the original Rome music into the game is brilliant too!I've left the original review below.* * * * * * * *Given how much I was looking forward to this after the first Rome game, Rome 2 is disappointment in video game form. Technical issues have abounded from day 1- it looks like I've got over 100 hours logged, but most of that was spent waiting for the AI to take its turns. Though this and many other issues have since been patched, it's a mark of how important it is for a game to launch with at least a pretence of smoothness: I haven't gone back to Rome 2 in a month. It's not just the bugs that have killed my enjoyment, it's some quite fundamental alterations to the way the game plays as well as some baffling design choices. As usual, the game lacks difficulty after a certain point, and the game's attempt to introduce a mid/late-game challenge is to spawn rebels with inexplicable amounts of troops instead of, say, actually building up enemies to be a threat. Agents are more of an irritation than anything else; the AI seems to prefer a bunch of smaller armies instead of larger ones that makes fighting them more akin to a game of whack-a-mole than anything else; multiplayer has been utterly eviscerated since Shogun 2. There are some bright spots: the new cinematic mode makes engagements a joy to watch, for instance, and the army traditions help breed attachment to your forces and can lead to some nice emerging stories. Unfortunately this is nowhere near enough to make up for the disappointment of everything else- the AI, the design choices, the multiplayer, the loathesome attitude towards DLC. Avoid if at all possible.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Moderately fun, but far too frustrating to play vs the older Total War games.  In the end it made me break out the original Rome Total War and load that up.The good:- The new way of managing regions by using sub-regions is interesting.- The new army system is interesting, and the stance system makes more sense then trying to find the right forest to hide your army in.- The port seige and mixed army/navy battles- AI does a much better job of trying to counter moves intelligently in battle.- graphics are awesomeThe bad:- The army system means that you can no longer have a small sub-army controlled by a captain cover a separate path, or travel by itself between regions.- The controls are frustrating to learn- Units didn't seem to always obey the commands I gave, even before battle was joined.- New system means that cities now have to specialize in something- Have to reinforce/build troops directly at the army- No control over what types of garrison forces are placed in cities.- I had to have graphics turned down to medium on my R9 270 in order to get an average of 22fps, so it didn't really look any better graphically than Shogun II.Total:I would give this only a 5.5-6 out of 10, whereas I give most of the other Total War games 7-9's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												almost 500 hours in and not a single campaign finished, recent patches have made it playable however its the mods which help make it bearable more than the patches and whenever CA patch the game it ends up breaking the mods.This game may be ready in about 6-8 months however right now its just a game which is neither good nor bad. Its just there for whoever wants to kill 15-20 minutes from time to time. The main problems are.- Terrible collision system due to the warscape engine, unit models move in and out of each other, clipping and sliding are a great part of every combat interaction, especially with cavalry charges.- Battles feel arcady, no realism, units rout too fast, pikemen have no real formation and if they try to attack another unit then they have to adjust the whole unti to become perpendicular and face them perfectly before they can begin combat.- Units as a whole are very poor at retaining their formations, so much so that cavalry cna easily charge straight through. - I'd say the political system is terrible however for that to be true you need to have a political system in place. In Rome II there's a series of buttons which all do nothing since civil war is inevitable and can not be avoided regardless of what choices you make and when civil war kicks of its just 10 armies spawning at your capital and you have to call all your armies back to fight this new random unrealistic threat  and CA has explicitly said that this part of the game wont be changed !- No family tree, no decent general development.- The UI is clearly rushed with no thought whatsoever, anyone who hasn't played this game would look at it and say its a placeholder and CA's current work ethic is contrary to their claims, instead of giving the game a real politics system they're busy releasing small unit packs, something which modders can already do (and to a degree, better than CA)- No decent expansion packs, small mini campaigns such as Hannibale at the gates and Caesar in gaul include unlocking unplayable factions (which modders have alreay done), a few cosmetic changes like a few new models and new research names along with campaign maps smaller than the vanilla campain map while adding NO NEW FEATURES WHATSOEVER. I and many others do not expect things to change soon,there are far more problems that this, take it from a person who has spent almost 500 hours playing this game and about 5  of those hours were playing the vanilla. As i said the mods make it playable and add life to a dead game but its also a tricky business and not everything can be modded since CA has hardcoded some things making it impossible.Final verdict, I DO NOT RECCOMEND THIS GAME IN ITS CURRENT STATE. Wait about half a year and if you see the devs making significant changes to address the concerns that ive placed here then feel free. These are not just my complaints these are a summary of every total war fan today.you may disagree on what ive said but one thing is certain.THIS IS NOT THE TOTAL WAR THAT YOU LOVED AND CHERISHED. THIS IS A MUTATED AND ILL VERSION OF THE MUCH LOVED GAME SERIES AND CA ARENT GOING TO PULL OUT THE DEFIBRILLATORS ANYTIME SOON !but please do tell me when they do, dont worry i'll wait -_-

												Simply boring overall.  I also experienced a video memory leak after playing just a hour or two.  Tactically I found the command interface sticky. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Hmm I see still no neutral way to comment on game, so guess Ill have to use the thumbs down.Ok first off, this isn't so much a bad game. This game could very well have the best graphics of any Total War game Ive ever played. Ive also been very impressed with Creative assembly and their Total War sries for providing great strategy games, historical notes, and a realness to the campaigns that just isn't on other RTS games. Sadly, this game has alot of problems that other TW games dont have, thus the thumbs down.The cons of this game:Soldier cards while in battle. They're black shapes of men, like ancient artwork. Which is really annoying in battle. Cause, while Im trying to move my troops around to engage, and hopefully, get the best results from the engagement, I got to keep hovering over the troop cards to ensure Im not sending my slingers to the front and my spearmen to a slingers position. The fact that, 2-4 versions of the spearmen are available, and only difference is how they are holding the spear, only adds to the confusion.The Grand Capmaign. Where to begin with that? Ill start off with, the map. Feels like the Ice Age is over and the cavemen are now starting to form tribes, despite the fact the starting year is listed as 272 BC. Next, the map is only so big. Yet, there is SO many Ai tribes, with strange, unheard of names and every shield emblem imaginable.  Its hard to believe the map is even big enough for all of them. The campaign also needs help explaining the different researchs, how to increase food production, etc. Felt like the more I researched, the less production! And, didn't seem to be any farming building to build. Yet, my soldiers were dieing of food shortage.Battlefield camera controls. They stink. As you go left and right, it swings you in a wide arc, making it hard to be sure your even moving towards the units you wished to move/command. Which then makes it tough to do your battle plan and ensure you dont take heavy loss's.The units seem to not be numbered. On medieval TW or Empires TW, you might recruit a unit of 45 calvary. On Rome, you dont seem to have a set number of soldiers in any unit.The few pros I did find:The battles are a bit realistic. I saw a horse riding away from the battle, riderless. Empires and Medieval dont have that.Each general character you recruit, his army is given a name and can choose an emblem, which does not happen on Medieval or Empires.Overall, not worth the $60 price it has. $20 is the highest I would ever pay for this, if I ever chose to buy this game. Its not a bad game and at least worth a try. But its not the best Total War game and I wouldn't recommend it to new Total War fans. I'd recommend Medieval Total War 2 for swords, spears, and archer warfare or Empires Total War for much better experiences.Note: I bought Medieval Total War through Amazon, not Steam, thus why Medieval TW aint on my Steam library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Warning; This review is only inteded a certain demographic.-Those who intend on inted on purchasing the game late-Those that want to buy it and much of the DLC on sale (somewhere along (50-80% off)-Also this is from a player who is a total war vet and also played the last games-Otherwise you might find this game and review quite appaulingThis game when if first came out was launched in a very incomplete state, the Co-op campaign was completely bugged out, many of the essential features like the ability to throw pila while stationary were completely missing and the battle ai was so damn drunk you could easily walk around them and capture the city square without them even noticing. But now since CA did a major facelift on this game I think I can say that this game is for the most part complete.Some of the things they added from the last iterations -The ability to view the entire campaign and battle maps by using the tab key-Added greater diversity of game machanics e.g. melee attack, armor penetration, health. -It's much easier than before to keep a coherant line you can even assign subordinate ai commanders to take over and soft lock formations.-The amount playable and non-playable factions in the game is both refreshing and even somewhat overwhelming and each one brings with it it's own unique playstyle adding months of replabiliy. Like for instance if you play a Germanic faction you must try to create a coalition in order to gain power.-As always the graphics for this game is beyond astonishing especially if you have a decent computer. You can make out even small details like the insignias on units to the small projectiles being thrown throughout the battlefiels. However, some cons that still need to be adressed in my opinion-The family tree and political system in this is a complete joke, most of the things you really have to worry about is just the commander traits and army traditions.-Compared to other games like EUIV, the diplomacy options have improved but still lack big options. -Many of the on map resources seem to be too common to have any real value. Unlike Shogun 2, most of the buildings in Rome 2 can be constructed in about anywhere. -For various reasons many of the major factions seem to be too passive for their own good in some playthroughs. In a playthrough of Rome, I was able to get to Carthage several times withought any real resistance. (Experience may vary). Overall I consider this a pretty good game overall, but still shy of the level of depth of Shogun II. I would defenatly recommend this to people who want more of a variaty in unit selection and enjoy the ancient era.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I am a long time Total War fan. I've own and have played all of them (including other Creative Assembly titles like Viking: Battle for Asgard). I've over the years become a loyal customer since I felt like I always got my money's worth.Rome II has ended that and made me lost my faith for Creative Assembly altoghether. I had patience when they were sorting out the bugs at launch, month after month after month. Now it is mostly playable, but is it fun? For the most part: no. There's no driving force behind the game, nothing that keeps me wanting to come back for more. Some other reviewers have already gone into detail, but some of the issues are of a graphical nature, but also that just that conquering new provinces on the campaign map becomes dull. I also tried out the multiplayer coop campaign with a friend, but just as with Shogun II it eventually becomes unplayable due to glitches and bugs mostly relating to desynching.I don't know what has happened to Creative Assembly during the years, but they no longer seem to be the same. Now I also noticed the new Hannibal title has day one DLC, which makes my stomach turn even more. My recommendation? If you want a grand strategy game, this isn't it. Go back to the older games, or look for a Paradox Interactive game. Creative Assembly has lost it's place as king of the hill and they are going to have to work hard to come back to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												New Total War Players; If you are thinking of getting into the total war series i would suggest Attila unless you really want the Roman era  Buy this on sale if your looking for an army management game with strategic battles.  It can be complex at first but extremely satisfying when you overcome difficult battles.  Diplomacy is in the game but it isnt complex or intelligent enough to make it seem real.   You make peace, you trade, you WAR.    Your goal in this game is to conquer the world, not build the first space ship.Old Total War Players;   I am disgruntled that they haven't implemented any successful type of unit movement or physics system in the way units interact with eachother or the environment;  Managing units climbing castles, or on the castle walls is a nightmare.   The physics of the armies charging into eachother in Attila (and all recent TW entries) seems to have taken a step back from the Medieval 2 version where two giant armies charging into eachother would create a thunderous explosion.   Now the armies seem to stutter step their way into the opposing army and then they kind of stand around and watch eachother while a few guys kill eachother.   I enjoy these games enough to keep coming back but never until the prices are 50+% off.     Total War has an expensive DLC regime that is expensive and "unfriendly."   There is something wrong at Creative Assembly when new entries take a step back in many areas while they still can't improve on some of the weird problems that have been around for 10+ years like wall battles during seiges, general unit movement and interaction, and unsophisticated AI.  I would be more forgiving AND loyal if they didn't turn around and fleece me for DLC that doesnt really improve anything.... its just a new coat of paint

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This is a good game, not great and probably not living up to its advertising, but still quite enjoyable.I am one of the lucky people, who never had any technical problems, well aside from AI not being able to attack fortified settlements - particularily from the sea.The graphics is amazing, the gameplay is somewhat simplyfied, which is somewhat enoying. The forced march stance, as well as the ability of army to sail the seas is particularily stupid decission. The traditions of the armies and the whole system of provinces on the other hand, were quite briliant solutions, though personally I would like to see more buldings.Unfortunately the single worst thing about this hame is its DLC history (and future seems no better). CA or sega refuse to understand, that any modder worth the name, is well capable of changing few textures or (if given tools to do so) slightly change the campain map. The dlc's that are currently being sold are little more than that. It is very unfortunate, that the franchise and the firm responsible for such a great expansion pack's such as Barbarian invasion, kingdoms, or more recent "fall of samurai" is now wasting both our and their time making stupid lame DLC which add few units and change few skins - something bellow avreage modder is able to do - instead of changing the gameplay, introducing new mechanicsas we should expect from them.I however still recommend this game, it is a good game, and whoever is claming otherwice is either lier, or had a technical issues that are likely to be solved by now. I however strongly advice against buying any DLC's because the only way of stopping selling of useless crap is by not buying it.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I bought 2 copies of this game only so I could play co-op campaign with my brother.  However, I found out too late that since he has his game on a Mac and I have mine on a PC, we can't play because we have different game versions.  When you're at the game's main menu screen, you will see a number in the top right corner.  Our numbers are different, and therefore we can't connect in a multiplayer battle or campaign.This is advertised as multiplayer, and that might be true for the majority of players, but it doesn't work for Mac vs. PC multiplayer games.  Some more experienced Mac people might be able to do a workaround, but be warned.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2013
												total war: rome 2 definetivly brings the strategy game back to life!it combines the slower paced provincial government (mostly the construction and managment off various buildings throughout the empire) and cpmmanding armies to kick♥♥♥♥♥* the construction part off the game is very detailed; its possible to choose from 4 main categories; town centre, military, civil or aggricultural buildings. each categorie has smaller sub divisions which allows you to choose what is best for your expanding empire. research and greater stability will get you acces to higher level upgrades.*for the military part its a deffinitive advantage to learn the combat system (generally ranged in back, spears/sords in front and cavalry at the side and grouped attacks on smaller detachements) and fight your own battles. the auto ressolve works fine, but also dpends on commander skill. so a layer may be actually beat an enemy the AI can not. it certainly works well (in dry weather at least) with the units responding well and the distances not being overly long. the troops also seem to be well balanced and the bonus system (as reward for victory) is well thought out and very usefull to an able and foreseeing commander.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												After having tried out tons of mods, I can safely say the community has saved this game from being a total waste, so I'm rewriting my review.I'll say it now, had it not been for those mods, I would have ditched this game a long time ago. I would be sad that I have more playtime in Rome 2 than Shogun 2 now, but only because I tried so hard to make this game worth having in my library. I'm somewhat glad to say that I've succeeded, but I'm still disappointed I had to resort to mass modding to make the game enjoyable. After the amazing experience that was Shogun 2, I expected so much more from CA. Playing Rome 2 after having played anything earlier in the series like Medieval 2, Rome 1 or Shogun 2 can be a bit of a let down. Thinking of the advantages Rome 2 has over those games I can only think of...better looking units/graphics? The province system? I guess the Campaign map size is more or less the same size?Still, time has passed, the bugs have been mostly squashed, mechanics have changed, there still aren't any family trees or agent cutscenes, but there ARE tons of awesome mods by the community to change the ancient world in your own image. If you can get this game on sale, I say go for it. For full price, I'm not sure I can still say yes, but the mods really are worth it in the long run.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Well, I will try to be as short as possiblePros:+ Modding community+ Good atmosphere, revisited time period+ Detailed battles with many options as formations, traps, etc, etc+ Replayable. Different and interesting missions and objectives (up to some point) which are specific to each faction are a sure guarantee that you are going to spend a lot of time playing this game.Cons:- After all those patches, A.I. is still incredibly stupid when it comes to battles. It just acts suicidal every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time. It is almost impossible not to win a battle given how easy the AI is to lure into ambush or how it does not attack certain units with their corresponding opposing troops (like cavalry - pikemen/spearmen). Instead, they just rush everything head on, expecting miracles. I really can't comprehend why CA could not implement this simple rock/paper/scissors mechanic in the game after years of patching.- Lame diplomacy. I know a lot has been written on the topic by what bugs me most, again after years of patching, is the lack to give away a region to anyone - even for free. For example - I play as Rome, maintain good relations with the Raeti and the Nori, I decide to turn my focus to Carthage and Iberia so I rely on my allies to keep my back (with some help, of course). After they lose some of their regions, I decide to intervene with my nearby stack so I recapture a territory that was belonging to my allies just a few turns ago. Astonishingly, I do not have the option to return the region to its rightful owner and instead I have to spend resources and time developing that region or just leave it be reconquered by my enemies (which of course is something I would not want to do). Same happens even if I tried to give the region to a client state/satrapy. On top of it, if playing as some barbarian factions, it is possible to "liberate" a region, instantly forming a military alliance with the liberated faction - which means the option of capturing and immediately ceding a region is somewhere in the game - just not given to us all this time, not even possible to be modded out. Do we need to remind CA how many times in the course of history, after the end of a war, territory was readdressed between belligerents? Instead, in Rome 2 owning a region is only a direct consequence of military occupation. B O R I N G- Broken trade. Now, again, would someone explain to me why (yes, again after years of patching) the trade issues with Sparta and Dacia were never sorted out? It is not a bug per se, but just an incredibly lacking in terms of common sense and logic game mechanic. For those who are not familiar: the game requires you to have a direct route to your capital in order to trade with a faction. Sounds logical as long as you do not play as Sparta and try to keep Athens as an ally or a client state. Because, if you do play as Sparta, you can go out, capture the entire Mediterranean if you wish, but as long as Athens is not yours - you cannot trade WITH ANYONE EXCEPT FOR ATHENS (or the corresponding faction that owns Athens). What if I wanted to keep Athens as an ally? Nope, you are not even offered to have trade-passing rights, so even if Athens was an ally or a client state - even then you cannot trade with anyone except them. Of course, that would be a minor nuissance if you could change your capital - but then again - NOPE, you cannot do that for reasons incomprehensible by human logic... With Dacia things are a bit less annoying since it borders a lot of other regions. But you cannot trade across the Danube even though historically rivers were used mainly for that - trade. Instead you have to circle around in order to start trading with those factions south of the river (or north of the river if you are coming from the south)I still recommend the game. I enjoy it. The modding community is great, and the game is quite flexible in terms of modding. However, the issues listed above are sometimes driving me crazy especially knowing that after all this time they still haven't been fixed (and they were all discovered when the game was released). What is even worse, CA has announced that they are not planning in implementing the "give region" option because "it was not historically accurate". Just wtf when it is exactly the opposite.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Hmm I see still no neutral way to comment on game, so guess Ill have to use the thumbs down.Ok first off, this isn't so much a bad game. This game could very well have the best graphics of any Total War game Ive ever played. Ive also been very impressed with Creative assembly and their Total War sries for providing great strategy games, historical notes, and a realness to the campaigns that just isn't on other RTS games. Sadly, this game has alot of problems that other TW games dont have, thus the thumbs down.The cons of this game:Soldier cards while in battle. They're black shapes of men, like ancient artwork. Which is really annoying in battle. Cause, while Im trying to move my troops around to engage, and hopefully, get the best results from the engagement, I got to keep hovering over the troop cards to ensure Im not sending my slingers to the front and my spearmen to a slingers position. The fact that, 2-4 versions of the spearmen are available, and only difference is how they are holding the spear, only adds to the confusion.The Grand Capmaign. Where to begin with that? Ill start off with, the map. Feels like the Ice Age is over and the cavemen are now starting to form tribes, despite the fact the starting year is listed as 272 BC. Next, the map is only so big. Yet, there is SO many Ai tribes, with strange, unheard of names and every shield emblem imaginable.  Its hard to believe the map is even big enough for all of them. The campaign also needs help explaining the different researchs, how to increase food production, etc. Felt like the more I researched, the less production! And, didn't seem to be any farming building to build. Yet, my soldiers were dieing of food shortage.Battlefield camera controls. They stink. As you go left and right, it swings you in a wide arc, making it hard to be sure your even moving towards the units you wished to move/command. Which then makes it tough to do your battle plan and ensure you dont take heavy loss's.The units seem to not be numbered. On medieval TW or Empires TW, you might recruit a unit of 45 calvary. On Rome, you dont seem to have a set number of soldiers in any unit.The few pros I did find:The battles are a bit realistic. I saw a horse riding away from the battle, riderless. Empires and Medieval dont have that.Each general character you recruit, his army is given a name and can choose an emblem, which does not happen on Medieval or Empires.Overall, not worth the $60 price it has. $20 is the highest I would ever pay for this, if I ever chose to buy this game. Its not a bad game and at least worth a try. But its not the best Total War game and I wouldn't recommend it to new Total War fans. I'd recommend Medieval Total War 2 for swords, spears, and archer warfare or Empires Total War for much better experiences.Note: I bought Medieval Total War through Amazon, not Steam, thus why Medieval TW aint on my Steam library.

												After its buggy release that was pretty much unplayable for me I stopped playing for over a year and went back to the much better stable TW games. It was not just the game breaking AI and capture the flag problems but the terrible optimization that made it impossible to play on my laptop.Now after 16 big patches its a different game, runs smooth and is now my favorite of the series, there are still a lot of features missing that were in previous TW games (some of which are returning in TW: Attila) but on the whole its a solid game now and the Mod community have built a large library of enhancements over the last year.Its well worth trying now if you have been put off by the negative reviews it got on release.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												This game is fantastic except for the fact that they got rid of the family tree. not cool man. I like building a dynasty/legacy. the general mechanic sucks in that way. mods that go up to 12 turns a year make it a little better. the battles are great. AI is solid. the character models are gorgeous, which oddly enough is a problem. they are so gorgeous, but there are so many of them, and they are so unique and awesome looking that it makes it hard to pay attention to any of them at any given time so it just sort of becomes a huge overstimulating mess if you zoom in to watch any part of the battle. also, the battles are way too fast paced. even enormous battles sometimes last about 10 minutes, which again, makes it really hard to enjoy any of the visuals. also, every total war game before this one had better castle seige mechanics. the cities in this one, just seem WAY TOO BIG. the battles always happen on basically 1/10th of the entire city, and the AI annoyingly takes advatnage of this and sends units to the opposite side of the city to attack, making castle seiges just a total pain in the butt. Shogun 2 is better than this game in pretty much every aspect. however, i could not help but enjoy playing as the macedonians and re-taking over the success states. this game is fun, its just disappointing due to the fact that literally every game before it was better. if you love history and the total war franchise, shogun 2 is the best one. this one is good, but arguably not even as good as medieval 2. now they made a medieval 3 and did not make it as a big money grab and actually took their time with it and did not make 50 DLC's...then i would pay attention to this franchise again. i recommend rome 2, but shogun 2 is better. be Athens and conquer trade in the mediterranean. super fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												If this was the game CA released to begin with, it would've ranked up as one of the best in the series. Beautiful visuals and an enormous attention to detail, interesting and varied unit rosters for each faction, a thematic soundtrack, a yuge and engaging campaign map full of dozens of nations and tribes with legit working diplomacy (an enemy of your enemy will actively seek to trade with you or seek a military alliance for example), battle AI that managed to surprise me by using formations effectively and actually trying to outflank me and finally (in my opinion) a more visually interesting and streamlined UI.It's not perfect by a long stretch; true to the series it can be too easy (especially as Rome) and upping the difficulty doesn't make the AI smarter, it just lets them cheat with more money and better stats, 1 year per turn means your generals drop dead from old age before you've even had a chance to properly level them up, the AI will sometimes not attack you during sieges or tire its units out by running them all over the map for no reason and the performance is pretty awful for a game of its age, although I did find upgrading my Radeon drivers to Crimson 16.9.2  boosted my framerate by nearly 20fps!If you're a fan of the series but have put off buying Rome 2 because of the awful state of the game at release, you're a fan of the time period, or you just fancy building an empire - definitely pick this one up. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												After 3 years, I'm still coming back and playing this for hours on end. I finally won my first campaign as Parthia, because I would always just start new campaigns. I'd say the strongest point of this game is the start of campaigns, when literally anything could happen, any AI faction could rise up and become a major player. You can play the same faction infinite times and your experience would be different each time.However, the biggest problem I have with the game, the reason why I was never finishing campaigns, is how stale the endgame is. It gets super repetitive once there are only a handful of factions left, and there's hardly any diplomacy at that point, just conquest after conquest. The politics "mini-game" seems tacked on, or not fleshed out to its potential. And Diplomacy can sometimes seem strange, factions refusing to trade with you even though you have tons of resources and they have none. Every once in a while a faction will declare war on you right after agreeing to a treaty.But in the end, the strengths of this game come out on top. Battles are epic, especially when they're between two powerful and advanced factions. The growth system for cities is ingeneous, and the wide variety of cultures at play insure a unique experience for each faction (outside of the Greek city-states). This went from one of the worst Total Wars at launch to one of the best. It's in my top 5, maybe arguably my top 3 with Rome and Shogun 2.9/10, would recommend.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												After waiting 2 years of optimization and a sale on the emperor edition, i finally bought Rome 2. I've been playing total war since Rome 1, i avoided Rome 2 because i anticipated the terrible release after the lukewarm beta leaks.I read a lot of people ranking Rome 1 , Medieval 2 and Shogun 2 above Rome 2 even after the Emperor edition.Those people are ragers completely stuck on the terrible Rome 2 release, and obsessed with Rome1/medieval 2 mods.Rome 1 and Medieval 2 engines are completely outdated and no amount of "historical accuracy", scripted mechanics that bloat the engine, or unit reskinning, can make up for core programming obsolescence.At the time of this review, Rome 2 is the best TW on the market. The map is beautiful, the combat works well, the UI is good, the new province mechanic is very smart...The graphics even on ultra are a bit disappointing but ENB mods will fix that.Buy it !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												After having tried out tons of mods, I can safely say the community has saved this game from being a total waste, so I'm rewriting my review.I'll say it now, had it not been for those mods, I would have ditched this game a long time ago. I would be sad that I have more playtime in Rome 2 than Shogun 2 now, but only because I tried so hard to make this game worth having in my library. I'm somewhat glad to say that I've succeeded, but I'm still disappointed I had to resort to mass modding to make the game enjoyable. After the amazing experience that was Shogun 2, I expected so much more from CA. Playing Rome 2 after having played anything earlier in the series like Medieval 2, Rome 1 or Shogun 2 can be a bit of a let down. Thinking of the advantages Rome 2 has over those games I can only think of...better looking units/graphics? The province system? I guess the Campaign map size is more or less the same size?Still, time has passed, the bugs have been mostly squashed, mechanics have changed, there still aren't any family trees or agent cutscenes, but there ARE tons of awesome mods by the community to change the ancient world in your own image. If you can get this game on sale, I say go for it. For full price, I'm not sure I can still say yes, but the mods really are worth it in the long run.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2013
												total war: rome 2 definetivly brings the strategy game back to life!it combines the slower paced provincial government (mostly the construction and managment off various buildings throughout the empire) and cpmmanding armies to kick♥♥♥♥♥* the construction part off the game is very detailed; its possible to choose from 4 main categories; town centre, military, civil or aggricultural buildings. each categorie has smaller sub divisions which allows you to choose what is best for your expanding empire. research and greater stability will get you acces to higher level upgrades.*for the military part its a deffinitive advantage to learn the combat system (generally ranged in back, spears/sords in front and cavalry at the side and grouped attacks on smaller detachements) and fight your own battles. the auto ressolve works fine, but also dpends on commander skill. so a layer may be actually beat an enemy the AI can not. it certainly works well (in dry weather at least) with the units responding well and the distances not being overly long. the troops also seem to be well balanced and the bonus system (as reward for victory) is well thought out and very usefull to an able and foreseeing commander.
