number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This is a good game, not great and probably not living up to its advertising, but still quite enjoyable.I am one of the lucky people, who never had any technical problems, well aside from AI not being able to attack fortified settlements - particularily from the sea.The graphics is amazing, the gameplay is somewhat simplyfied, which is somewhat enoying. The forced march stance, as well as the ability of army to sail the seas is particularily stupid decission. The traditions of the armies and the whole system of provinces on the other hand, were quite briliant solutions, though personally I would like to see more buldings.Unfortunately the single worst thing about this hame is its DLC history (and future seems no better). CA or sega refuse to understand, that any modder worth the name, is well capable of changing few textures or (if given tools to do so) slightly change the campain map. The dlc's that are currently being sold are little more than that. It is very unfortunate, that the franchise and the firm responsible for such a great expansion pack's such as Barbarian invasion, kingdoms, or more recent "fall of samurai" is now wasting both our and their time making stupid lame DLC which add few units and change few skins - something bellow avreage modder is able to do - instead of changing the gameplay, introducing new mechanicsas we should expect from them.I however still recommend this game, it is a good game, and whoever is claming otherwice is either lier, or had a technical issues that are likely to be solved by now. I however strongly advice against buying any DLC's because the only way of stopping selling of useless crap is by not buying it.

												A fresh take on the highly successful Total War series.New region management system, that enables large regions with many cities to be managed as a whole.Large variety of troop types relevant to home region.Limited amount of units allowed in action at any one time, brings a more tactical strategy throughout.Fantastic visuals and audio.Main campaign is long and involving.Possibly my favourite Total War to date.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												Rome 2 provides a great empire-building strategy with epic Battles presented with the newest graphics. Even though there are still some bugs I really enjoy the game - it enhanced several problematic areas form Rome 1 such as the possibility of naval battles and sustainability of the empire - giving me another round of my possibly most loved game of the 21st century so far. The positives: - combat is (usually) swift and smooth - graphics are fine - allies actually work - new army stances - good MP campaign - nice mods available - intuitive and clear UIThe negatives: - AI is still dumm - Few repeating battlefields - I would expect more - Sieges are mishandled & the city design is lacking at places (such as gaps in walls!) although the building textures are beautiful - The "intrigue" side is useless at best, annoying at worst. - Diplomacy still limited and AI is illogical, albeit it is easy to navigate - "Oversimplification" of economy, cities and empire manegement in generalOverall I'd say this is one of my less played TWs, and while being a solid game it was certainly not the best TW by a longshot. MP is fun even after a while, but SP gets boring relatively fast.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												As a fan of strategy it is only natural that I am a fan of the Total War series, that said I was hesitent to get Rome II at first for reasons that many of us are aware of, at launch it was a buggy nightmare that will cause people to doubt Creative Assembly for quite a while, that and Shogun 2 was excellent enough to not need to move on. Many months later combined with a sale day I was tempted, but first consulted a friend about it. He assured me the game was now very much fixed so I decided to go for it. Put simply I was not dissapointed.One thing I liked right from the get go was the fact that for the main campaign, known as the Grand Campaign, the map is huge and whether your commanding the Roman war machine or fighting against it you will be there a while and there will be many battles to be had. Most of the series signature features are there, the map, agents that serve various purposes, huge epic battles. That said the family tree is gone sadly, and I do mis it quite a bit as it made me feel even more invested in my game, families still exist but in a somewhat different form that instead plays a part in your chosen culture's internal politics which you are tasked with balancing rather than straight up dominating due to the risk of civil wars that can arise because of the internal factions within your government. Building on this is a system where events will happen and you will have to decide how to deal with them, with the outcome having effect of the political situation within your culture. Mileage will vary on whether or not this a good replacement for the Family Tree but it is a good system nonetheless.Overall I enjoyed Rome II just like I enjoyed Shogun II, that said many will argue that Shogun II is the smarter buy right now due to be noticably cheaper and I am inclined to agree. That said if you are itching for more total war on an even bigger scale and you spot it on sale go for it, and happy conquering!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												To be honest this is easily creative assembly's most impressive and immersive title to date, with a greater variation of battle types that can now accommodate both land and naval forces. The most impressive Battles take place when attacking or defending one of the major capital cities of the ancient world, and managing a fleet of reinforcements as you defend a siege provides a brilliant challenge. These encounters are just as intimidating as they are exciting, making the addition of a top-down, tactical viewpoint near essential. If you are in to turn based strategy games then i would advice you to give this game a shot, its well worth your money, i give it a 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I am a long time Total War fan. I've own and have played all of them (including other Creative Assembly titles like Viking: Battle for Asgard). I've over the years become a loyal customer since I felt like I always got my money's worth.Rome II has ended that and made me lost my faith for Creative Assembly altoghether. I had patience when they were sorting out the bugs at launch, month after month after month. Now it is mostly playable, but is it fun? For the most part: no. There's no driving force behind the game, nothing that keeps me wanting to come back for more. Some other reviewers have already gone into detail, but some of the issues are of a graphical nature, but also that just that conquering new provinces on the campaign map becomes dull. I also tried out the multiplayer coop campaign with a friend, but just as with Shogun II it eventually becomes unplayable due to glitches and bugs mostly relating to desynching.I don't know what has happened to Creative Assembly during the years, but they no longer seem to be the same. Now I also noticed the new Hannibal title has day one DLC, which makes my stomach turn even more. My recommendation? If you want a grand strategy game, this isn't it. Go back to the older games, or look for a Paradox Interactive game. Creative Assembly has lost it's place as king of the hill and they are going to have to work hard to come back to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												New Total War Players; If you are thinking of getting into the total war series i would suggest Attila unless you really want the Roman era  Buy this on sale if your looking for an army management game with strategic battles.  It can be complex at first but extremely satisfying when you overcome difficult battles.  Diplomacy is in the game but it isnt complex or intelligent enough to make it seem real.   You make peace, you trade, you WAR.    Your goal in this game is to conquer the world, not build the first space ship.Old Total War Players;   I am disgruntled that they haven't implemented any successful type of unit movement or physics system in the way units interact with eachother or the environment;  Managing units climbing castles, or on the castle walls is a nightmare.   The physics of the armies charging into eachother in Attila (and all recent TW entries) seems to have taken a step back from the Medieval 2 version where two giant armies charging into eachother would create a thunderous explosion.   Now the armies seem to stutter step their way into the opposing army and then they kind of stand around and watch eachother while a few guys kill eachother.   I enjoy these games enough to keep coming back but never until the prices are 50+% off.     Total War has an expensive DLC regime that is expensive and "unfriendly."   There is something wrong at Creative Assembly when new entries take a step back in many areas while they still can't improve on some of the weird problems that have been around for 10+ years like wall battles during seiges, general unit movement and interaction, and unsophisticated AI.  I would be more forgiving AND loyal if they didn't turn around and fleece me for DLC that doesnt really improve anything.... its just a new coat of paint

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Warning; This review is only inteded a certain demographic.-Those who intend on inted on purchasing the game late-Those that want to buy it and much of the DLC on sale (somewhere along (50-80% off)-Also this is from a player who is a total war vet and also played the last games-Otherwise you might find this game and review quite appaulingThis game when if first came out was launched in a very incomplete state, the Co-op campaign was completely bugged out, many of the essential features like the ability to throw pila while stationary were completely missing and the battle ai was so damn drunk you could easily walk around them and capture the city square without them even noticing. But now since CA did a major facelift on this game I think I can say that this game is for the most part complete.Some of the things they added from the last iterations -The ability to view the entire campaign and battle maps by using the tab key-Added greater diversity of game machanics e.g. melee attack, armor penetration, health. -It's much easier than before to keep a coherant line you can even assign subordinate ai commanders to take over and soft lock formations.-The amount playable and non-playable factions in the game is both refreshing and even somewhat overwhelming and each one brings with it it's own unique playstyle adding months of replabiliy. Like for instance if you play a Germanic faction you must try to create a coalition in order to gain power.-As always the graphics for this game is beyond astonishing especially if you have a decent computer. You can make out even small details like the insignias on units to the small projectiles being thrown throughout the battlefiels. However, some cons that still need to be adressed in my opinion-The family tree and political system in this is a complete joke, most of the things you really have to worry about is just the commander traits and army traditions.-Compared to other games like EUIV, the diplomacy options have improved but still lack big options. -Many of the on map resources seem to be too common to have any real value. Unlike Shogun 2, most of the buildings in Rome 2 can be constructed in about anywhere. -For various reasons many of the major factions seem to be too passive for their own good in some playthroughs. In a playthrough of Rome, I was able to get to Carthage several times withought any real resistance. (Experience may vary). Overall I consider this a pretty good game overall, but still shy of the level of depth of Shogun II. I would defenatly recommend this to people who want more of a variaty in unit selection and enjoy the ancient era.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I love the Total War series. I've played Shogun, Rome, Empire, Shogun 2, and now Rome 2.I would rate Shogun 2 to be much better than its predecessor, but Rome 2 feels like more of the same. Still, more of the same isn't a bad thing. The graphic obviously improved, additional factions are welcomed, and the campaigns are challenging. Although unfortunately, I found the sea battles to be more of a chore than anything.It's a 7/10 for me. I hope they'll be releasing Empire 2 soon. I want to see how that stacks up against Europa Universalis IV. Currently my favorite strategy game of the decade.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I should be thankful that someone told me this was on a free weekend; this games been out for a while now and I'd still not seen what sort of crap I was missing out on for myself...Minimal expectations in mind, I took my time to look at all the playable factions; theres a "decent" amount regardless of DLC, however the number of actual nations is just so vast compared to other games.Anyway, picked the Kingdom of Pontus in what is modern day turkey or so, and soon as i started playing I was hooked.Diplomacy has improved slightly since Shogun 2, AI nations actively try to earn favour and security from their neighbours with a will to survive rather than conquer others, unless survival means to conquer (unless their barbarians, to which they will only listen if you're giving them a swirly).On a strategic view battles now feel more important to me, due to the lack of armies; it makes victory more valuable and losing will have a relatively severe affect on the security of your nation, leaving gaps in your frontlines; and in that respect wars should be planned accordingly.Knowing the crushing details about this games release, I feel that most of the ideas and details have been decently ironed out over the past year or so, thought it is missing a few things that would have been nice to include, such as trading territory. Still I genuinely think the 30 hours I've put into it was time well spent.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												When I first ever heard of Rome 2 being announced, I flipped out. Being a huge fan of the Total War series, even Spartan: Total Warrior, I was pumped for this game. Then, it came out. Bugs, glitches, idiotic AI, and more problems ruined this game. Luckily, however, I watched a review of this game before buying a while ago. Now, fortunately, I have heard that the bugs are gone, the AI is mostly fixed, and the game is now playable. When it went on sale, I knew I had to add this to my collection, and I have to say, it was worth it. TL;DR: The bugs are gone and the game is now playable, fun, and worth it if on sale.Now for some specifics.Pros:- Decent graphics- Fun and addicting grand campaign mode (like always)- Fairly easy to learn for newcomers- Challenging, but fun, even on lower difficulties (I might just suck)- New features added which I always wanted in the first Rome: Total WarCons:- I legitametly can not think of anything that takes away from the experience of this game, thus ruining the point of a pros/cons chart. Thanks Volvo.Verdict: 9/10   Worth it if on sale, but not the full asking price.

												Great game, and in its current state it is nearly flawless(if you ignore the usual quarks of CA game engines, I however have had zero crashes since the Emperor Edition was released a while ago. Great replayability, great graphics, a huge thriving modding community, and the DLC isn't all just a money grab/if you just buy what you want almost everything enhances the gameplay options alot. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												Rome 2 provides a great empire-building strategy with epic Battles presented with the newest graphics. Even though there are still some bugs I really enjoy the game - it enhanced several problematic areas form Rome 1 such as the possibility of naval battles and sustainability of the empire - giving me another round of my possibly most loved game of the 21st century so far. The positives: - combat is (usually) swift and smooth - graphics are fine - allies actually work - new army stances - good MP campaign - nice mods available - intuitive and clear UIThe negatives: - AI is still dumm - Few repeating battlefields - I would expect more - Sieges are mishandled & the city design is lacking at places (such as gaps in walls!) although the building textures are beautiful - The "intrigue" side is useless at best, annoying at worst. - Diplomacy still limited and AI is illogical, albeit it is easy to navigate - "Oversimplification" of economy, cities and empire manegement in generalOverall I'd say this is one of my less played TWs, and while being a solid game it was certainly not the best TW by a longshot. MP is fun even after a while, but SP gets boring relatively fast.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I am/was a big Total War fan. For the sake of this review I will ignore that the game had a terrible launch.First off the game is waaayy more playable with the patches, the campaign isn't a mess and is actually fun, the campaign works. Unfortunatly I don't play Total war for the campaign; I play Total War for the battles and Rome 2's battles are bad, not terrible just bad.First off the audio has not been improved the music sucks life out of the game and the voice acting is well Sh*t. The other sound effects (sword and shield clashes, marching etc) are good however I would prefer to hear someone screaming from being killed instead of the sound of metal clashing.The animations are rubbish, the kill moves are unrealistic; soldiers slide across the floor to set up for the moves and when they do the kill moves look staged. Also the soldiers can be killed by a none kill move or a simple stab however the soldier that died has the same animation as if he got hit by a projectile and this looks stupid. The soldiers rubberband (this is more obvious in slow motion). There is still no unit collision; the units stop in perferect synchronization when they "clash", also when you issue a order all of the soldiers in the unit respond at the same time like robots it is not realistic. When two spear units clash they leave a gap and only one or two soldiers in each unit will fight eachother. The User interface in the battles is still stupid they still use the art style for the units and there is no guard mode. There are many more issues with the game (like how the light can refelct off sand) but I can't be bothered to explain these issues do not buy this game or its dlc.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Well, first of all it's so funny to see negative reviews by the people who actually played the game several hundred of hours anyway :DI keep enjoying the TW series since the Shogun times and Rome2 is also an awesome game.Of course it has some flaws just as every one of the previous TWs had, like very repeating animation (a lot of units from different factions fights and moves exactly the same way, however some of them, like greek hoplites could use phalanx and fight like they really did IRL, but the real romans military tactics is not illustrated in Rome2 accurately enough, said but true..), also the variety of battle maps is pretty low, naval battles looks too awkward (well, at least for me, but I am not a fan of TW naval battles at all, I usually use to just skip them). Also it's very annoying that you have no option to move your units on a global map or just hire them without a general. I personally have some feeling of a lack of technology developement, economical action and buildings functionality deepness - it's so easy to imagine some additional features and functions for these aspects that could make the game more deep, interesting and historically accurate, however the developers decided to make it just more simple, that's why the game becomes a little boring on a global map. That is also pretty weird that you are not allowed to check the "4 turns for a year" option by default. It is available as a custom mod in a workshop, however your agents become overpowered with this modification.Overall, Rome2 is really a very atmospheric and enjoyable game. Battles are so spectacular, graphics looks awesome. It has a large modding potential, just take a look on the workshop. UI is more logical and useful, comparing with the previous games of the series. There are a lot of units and factions, that makes Rome2 a very replayable game. Diplomacy works even better than I expected. A lot of multiplayer options..If you bought the game just as soon as it was released and you was dissapointed by all these bugs, game balance and AI issues, let me give you a piece of advice not to do so and wait until a game is fully tested by the early-buyers and polished by the developers with the early-buyers's feedback help. It's just as simple as that - if you don't want to be disappointed with a game you are waiting, just dont buy it too early and wait for some patches to make it finished, developers nowadays usually don't release completely finished games.Also I wanted to say that SEGA sells the "blood and gore" DLC separately not just because of it's greed, but eventually mostly for avoiding the original game from getting the mature rating.

content:
Posted: February 22
												This game has been really up and down for me, but I'll go into detail as to why. I love the TW series and have played everything from the original Rome to now. So I was obviously expecting some of the issues that arose around release involving lagging, video quality problems, crashing and AI difficulties. But those have thankfully been ironed out now, so we're left with a game that's stable, but more importantly, heavily moddable. Some of the things wrong with this game are easily fixed with some of the more popular mods available in the workshop, like the AI being completely incompetent at times, sailing their only fleet out to the middle of nowhere and leaving their capital undefended while you're camped on it with significant armies.I've found that it's very easy to get bored during some of the longer campaigns, because it's so simple to find yourself repeating strategies for different factions. You'll learn the best direction to expand in and subconscously follow it in most of your campaigns. It's a trap I fell into a few times and had to consciously avoid doing it to keep the game fresh. Try different things every game, different strategies, different directions. That's how I've gotten the most out of my time playing. The DLC's are good if you can get them on sale, I wouldn't recommend paying full price for any of them, The game in general is a lot of fun. The battles are realistic for the most part, the strategies you can employ are widespread and the unit diversity is good. The city/economy building is also a lot of fun, trying to find ways to stick a knife in someone's back while you're sharing a border and multiple allies is always an interesting struggle. There really is something for everyone in this game if you want to find it. I'll recommend it to anyone chasing a decent turn-based strategy.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												In a game such as Rome II Total War you cannot give an accurate review without a detailed account of the ‘Spear Brothers’, one of the most revered,  blood thirsty and - at times - gangrenous of all the units in this medieval role-play-simulation game. If the Brothers of the Spear were not written into the game, we would likely never have seen the likes of the Total War franchise; it is said that Tim Ansell, the mastermind behind Creative Assembly who developed the game in 1987, had a dream were the Suebian Spear Brothers came to him in the night, laden with documented plans for the creation of such a game series. Whether this is entirely true or not we cannot be sure, but we can be sure that the Spear Brothers will continue to inspire a generation of video game players, young, old and even those not born yet.The Germanic tribe of the Spear Brothers is a tribe hardened by horrific war. At the time of Rome II, iron supplies - especially in West Germany - were very sparse. It is no surprise then that the Spear Brothers, the mighty warriors, were given priority of the metal for their dreaded ‘Spear Brother Spears’ or ‘framea’ in their own tongue. It is murmured in legend that the larger the man, the larger the spear. We have no reason yet to doubt this, according to the many geophys surveys that have been undertaken to find the truth of these giants of the battlefield.It would be a crime to end this review without mentioning the battle cry of the Spear Brothers, due indeed to the fact that few have ever survived it. One account comes from a Briton monk, Jasper, who whilst riding Maurice, his donkey into battle, witnessed the most ferocious and worrisome cry he had ever heard from the mouths of the Brothers of the Spear who he was gradually trotting towards. He could see the blood spurting from the ears of his own brothers, drenching each other in crimson pain. The horses were bleeding too while they manically ran into each other. Jasper, who now believed he was entering the blood and fire occupied Seventh Circle of Hell, only survived because when he eventually reached the front line, all the Britons were dead and the Spear Brothers had gone back to their tribes with haste, blood thirsty for more combat with their own peoples. The tale goes that Jasper lived the rest of his reasonably long life with Maurice, entrenched somewhere in the Aiguilles d'Arves in France, safe from the devilry of the Barbarians. It is said descendants of the Spear Brothers (SB) continue fighting, albeit virtually; if you are lucky enough to encounter one, be wary, hold fast and please remember ‘The Story of Jasper & Maurice’.

												Even though this is not my favorite setting / timeframe, this is my favorite Total War.The controls and interface feel a lot smoother for me; I used to feel like every battle in Empire or Shogun was a struggle against the game controls and UI, but I don't have this problem in R:TW2 anymore.The campaign map is huge with a large variety of playable factions - and the DLCs add extra campaigns and even more factions. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												EDIT: I initially wrote this review two months after Rome 2 was released, which I think is obvious given my reaction to it. Total War games are, since Empire, not known for being in a particularly high-quality state at launch, but Rome 2 really took the biscuit. It was dreadful.Anyway, fast forward seven months. It's almost the end of June now, and Rome 2 has received 13 patches to date, as well as two main DLC expansions and several "free-LC" updates. The second of those major DLC expansions, Hannibal At The Gates, brought me back to Rome 2, and I have to say that the state of the game is far improved. Those awful "capture the flag" bits are gone, the technical performance of the game is better, there are more factions, more units, more features, more everything. The HatG mini-campaign is (annoying Agents aside) about as close to a perfect Total War campaign as I could ask for, and the factions are more balanced. Those unbearable turn-load times I mentioned before? Dealt with. Basically almost everything has been improved.There're still some glaring errors- siege AI remains fundamentally thick-headed, naval battles are still dogged by the AI insisting on clumping all its ships together in a mess when it regroups, and the policy of charging for factions still makes me sick- but the game is in a state where it can be played and enjoyed. That mod that brings the original Rome music into the game is brilliant too!I've left the original review below.* * * * * * * *Given how much I was looking forward to this after the first Rome game, Rome 2 is disappointment in video game form. Technical issues have abounded from day 1- it looks like I've got over 100 hours logged, but most of that was spent waiting for the AI to take its turns. Though this and many other issues have since been patched, it's a mark of how important it is for a game to launch with at least a pretence of smoothness: I haven't gone back to Rome 2 in a month. It's not just the bugs that have killed my enjoyment, it's some quite fundamental alterations to the way the game plays as well as some baffling design choices. As usual, the game lacks difficulty after a certain point, and the game's attempt to introduce a mid/late-game challenge is to spawn rebels with inexplicable amounts of troops instead of, say, actually building up enemies to be a threat. Agents are more of an irritation than anything else; the AI seems to prefer a bunch of smaller armies instead of larger ones that makes fighting them more akin to a game of whack-a-mole than anything else; multiplayer has been utterly eviscerated since Shogun 2. There are some bright spots: the new cinematic mode makes engagements a joy to watch, for instance, and the army traditions help breed attachment to your forces and can lead to some nice emerging stories. Unfortunately this is nowhere near enough to make up for the disappointment of everything else- the AI, the design choices, the multiplayer, the loathesome attitude towards DLC. Avoid if at all possible.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												One of the better games in the franchise, I`d like to say. Sadly, every Total War game is good, more or less. Yes yes, there are some aspect every now and then that could have been improved upon or some mechanic that did not work as intended, but looking at it`s completeness; Well made.Total War: Rome II is a strategy game that incorperates aspects of both RTS (Real Time Strategy) and turn based gameplay. Think of it as the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of King Sid Meier (Civilization) and harlot Westwood Studios (Command&Conquer) with some EA-phylis on top.You play on a world map (Well, THE world map.) and control a faction representing historical nations/tribes and so forth during this timeperiod. You micro manage cities in a rather simple format, controlling influx of trade, food, slaves and all other things that makes the world go around. You do this by building different buildings, stomping uneducated Gauls into the dirt and the occasional diplomacy (Aka, siege engines).The game is a rather realistic depictation of roman era warfare and the amount of different units and their intricacies is staggering. + beachhead battles? The D(day) is strong in this one.If you enjoy entertaining the idea of forming shieldwalls, javelin/archer crossfire and the occasional barbarian-balls-to-the-walls-with-big-two-handed-swords charge, then this game is for you.My most enjoyed game in the franchise is most definitely Total War: Rome, with Shogun so close behind that it`s hard to differentiate. I enjoyed Shogun a tad bit more than Rome II because of the weaponry. I`d like to point out: I love archers. Archers is love, archers is life. If I become a dad, I am naming my son: Archer, or it`s fairer twin: Archerette.♥♥♥♥ THE ROMANS AND THEIR GOD DAMN JAVELINS! Not that they aren´t as effective, if not more so.Why are you still reading this wall of text!? Go topple some walls already! Buy buy buy!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. I've been playing Total War games since Rome 1 and I'm a big fan of the series. That said, this series has fallen a long way and is nowhere near what it used to be. It is tedious, clunky, and not very much fun.Honestly, I'd start with some positives, but there isn't really anything in this game that hasn't been done in other TW games and done better. If it were anything, I'd say the way you now have some control over how your generals develop and the army levelling system that adds a bit of tradition and character to your armies and navies.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~The game overview map is the first thing you have to deal with and it is poor. It looks about as good as Medieval 2 did, maybe worse. Add to that the fact that you have to go to an entirely different map mode in order to zoom out and it's a step back. Army movement is cumbersome and although the different movement types seem like a good idea at first, you'll be super annoyed when your army gets ambushed because you forgot to go back to a regular stance. Cities look decent and change as you build certain buildings so that's a nice touch but not exactly ground-breaking stuff.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Next up is the completely useless politics system. You can pretty much ignore this feature of the game. It is one of the least immersive aspects of gameplay I can remember from any game, ever. If you play as Rome you will control one of three factions, all with their own perks and drawbacks. Within this system, you can gain power against other houses and gain promotions for members of your faction which provide more perks. All of your generals and admirals will come from these characters. All sounds interesting until you actually start playing the game and realize that absolutely none of this matters. Press a button, get perks. Press another button, lose perks. And to totally honest, with all the other numbers and stats flying around, you'll never notice or really care if your army recruitment costs are reduced by 3% because one of your characters became quaestor. The character system from Rome 1 and Medieval 2 had more depth to them and they weren't all that particularly deep to begin with.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Next up is provinces, cities, and army recruitment. Another step back. The province system was, once again, a decent concept that was very poorly implemented. Basically, each province contains anywhere between 2-4 cities. There is a provincial capital and the rest are minor settlements. If you own each settlement in a province, you can enact an edict which gives you yet another perk. Of course you have to manage public order. Within cities themselves, you have a limited number of buildings you can build in each one. After awhile, the combination of buildings that you need becomes very dull and formulaic. Each minor settlement needs a farm. Each province needs a temple for every 2 settlements. You'll end up building all trading ports and market settlements as the interior of your empire becomes more secure. You'll end up going through and removing all military buildings because there's no point having a barracks in Carthage when you own 100% of Northern Africa. Tedious. Boring. And don't get me started on how completely asinine army recruitment is now. You no longer recruit through the cities  but directly into the armies themselves as long as you are located in controlled territory. Not only is this pretty unintuitive, it's also never explicitly mentioned if all the military buildings in your province have an effect on one another or only units that come from that city. I'm sure I could have found out but with all the different things affecting your troops, it really wasn't worth knowing.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Diplomacy in this game is also a joke. There is no depth to it (which isn't exactly a new problem for TW games). Still though, it would be nice if it were possible to interact more with other nations and if states that were Reliable played like they were reliable and Devious nations played like they were Devious. Honestly, it feels like Diplomacy is just a waste of time since you're just going to crush them in a few turns anyway. Maybe I'm a little spoiled here coming from Europa Universalis but diplomacy in a grand strategy game is kind of important.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Now for the supposed bread and butter of this series, the battles. Possibly the most disappointing part of this game. The graphics are not good quality. Troops look alright but the environment is terrible and don't make sense. Take a look around and you start to wonder how it's possible you're fighting on a completely flat plain with a 10,000 ft mountain off in the distance every single time. The sound is bad and you'll hear and remember everything the characters have to say after 2 battles. Lack of any remotely effective range weapons really makes the battles stale. You won't even use Velites after awhile because all they do is rout or skirmish behind your lines and then throw spears into the backs of your principes because you forgot to turn Fire At WIll mode off. Cities are pretty cookie cutter with little variety. It will feel like every time you just march your infantry in, rout the enemy, then chase them down with your Equites. Pretty much every single time. It definitely does not help that there are shockingly few varieties of units. All in all, the battles are just not fun and you'll probably end up auto-resolving quite a few.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~I bought this game for $15 on the last day of the Steam Holiday Sale. I told myself to wait because I knew there was a high probability that I would not enjoy this game. I was right. I'm not upset at the money I spent on it. What I'm really upset about is just how disappointed I am in this game. It's really making me question whether or not there was anything all that special about the TW games I played in the past. Paradox Interactive is really pushing the frontier on strategy games at the moment and without the joy of the battles in TW, what you're basically playing is a crappy, buggy version of one of those games. I cannot discourage everyone from buying this game strongly enough. I think some people could find it fun, but there are so many better games out there that you should really look for one of those. Technology, competition, and time have far surpassed anything that Creative Assembly have come up with for awhile now and they are most certainly trading solely on their past glories. I will never buy one of their games ever again. :(

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Has taken me more than year to be able to conjure up a review, and I'm still not overly sure. My sessions still often end in "Rome II has unexpectedly crashed," I have unmodded legendary saves that won't load, and I cannot play for nearly as long as on the original Rome without getting bored.My main concern is that my current legendary campaign, although almost complete, is no fun at all. Diplomacy on legendary seems to be something that escapes me: factions half way across the map declare war for no reason when I have good integrity and it is near impossible to sue for peace with anybody but, if you do, they often declare war again a few turns later. The battles are not neccessary challenging but the constant spam of agents and armies from every side make it such a grind to make progress. CA said they were limiting armies to make battles more meaningful with bigger impact; however, with a restricted number of armies, it just turns into mine being holed up, fighting many meaningless battles that take a couple of turns to recover from, with enemy agents constantly limiting their movement!The modding community is, for me, the only thing that rescues this game as most of the crappy features in the original (save politics, family trees, and awful unit collision/charging) can be altered. Admittedly, a lot has been fixed since release, but there are still many things that seem inherantly broken to many paople; I really think I only play because of my interest in the time period, and due to a huge amount or nostalgia for Rome I.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												TL:DR:  8/10I pre-ordered Total War Rome II but only just started playing the game due to the amount of negative backlash levied at the game from launch. Now I have finally started to play the game and I have really enjoyed it - but I should note that I am not playing the purely "vanilla" version of Rome II. After much reading I decided to download Toons' "All in One Mod" for Rome II and it is really good. So please note that my subsequent comments are coloured by having played the mod.Rome II does some things really well compared to previous Total War games (of which I have played most of them). I really like how the Auto Resolve for battles has been addressed, whereby it shows you the likelihood of victory based on the battle stance you take (aggressive, balanced, defensive) and also the percentage of troops you will have left for each choice. The enemy AI is also well balanced and fights well in the field battles as well as on the diplomatic side of things. I really liked the addition of the Pros and Cons listed by each faction for why they like or dislike your nation. This made it much simpler to determine why they might reject an offer as opposed to past TW games where it was infuriating to be rejected and not understand why. Having naval support during battles is a nice touch also and builds upon the naval warfare introduced in Empire, even if it's still quite clunky at times.The Spies and Heroes/Champions are also much better designed in this game than the previous Rome and Empire. Now you can assign perks to the individual agents and level them up as you desire. I remember thinking in Empire "What is the point of the spy! His chances of assassinating someone is barely 20%!" Now I have used them to great effect in weakening cities, garrisons and travelling armies. A great improvement all round!There is also much more opportunities to conduct war in the political arena with assassinations and securing promotions etc. This has been greatly expanded from Empire and the previous Rome and adds a broader dimension to the game.One thing that I don't like so much is the way armies can be split and travel. It is impossible (as far as I can see) to transport troops from one army to another unless the General travels with them in tow. This may well be more thematic but I feel that it hinders the game play a bit. I also completely disagree with CA's decision to make this such a DLC heavy title/franchise. Some additional campaigns and so on are fine as added DLC to me but adding a Blood and Gore mode and other minor aesthetic changes that were already in the game files and just required "activation" is ridiculous. Companies need to stop selling us half-completed games! But all in all I thoroughly recommend Rome II - especially if you seek out a mod like I did. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Do not by this game.I'll start with some of the good points.- The graphics i think are very good, both in battles and on the campaign map but mainly in the battles with the close ups on individal soldiers, effects and looking on the battle as a whole.-Diffrent factions- unlike shogun 2 for example the factions all have different soldiers and there are loads of them giving the game much more re-playability.-there is loads of strategy involved and you can control your faction in loads of different aspects (if you like that kind of thing) .Now why you shouldn't buy it. unlike many people my problem with it is not the early software issues or how the soldiers fight or anything so detailed in the gamplay. My problem with it is much worse, it is incredibly boring.-The politics and all that is fantasticly dull and is way too complicated, especially if your playing as Rome.-The game is really restrictive in how you can play. In old TW games you could have as many armies as you like. The games  were much less complex. In Rome 2 your number of armies is limited based on the size of your empire and those armies have to have generals. This leads on to the fact that the generals are too important and complicated and i couldn't care less about them.-It takes ages to do anything. You have to spend about 2 hours playing each battle endlessly pausing and playing and, God, the clicking, so much clicking. Then you finish the battle and re-enter the misery of the campaign where you cannot, due to the army limit and the fact that settlements take so long to become happy after being captured, capture any more settlements in less than about 79 million turns.-There's just too much to think about when your playing. Food supplies, people's happiness, technology and buildings, politics and diplomacy, generals, armies, settlements, recruitment, navies, it goes on forever.Basicly the game is too complicated and boring for most human mortals.

												Total War: Rome 2 has developed in to something very enjoyable for the ones interested in the total war genre and time period. content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Ran horribly badly on my Mac. All the banners would get stuck as black boxes on screen until I couldn't see what was going on at all. Tried different graphics settings to no avail. Moving the camera around was awkward at best and a disaster at worst. Fine that it pans and you can move forward and back, but there appeared to be no way to rotate the camera. Then sometimes the camera would take off moving on it's own and I wouldn't be able to control where it was going at all. Also didn't really seem to be much of a strategy to the game, Just move your units around and attack. Maybe it gets better further into the game, but I found it simplistic. With all the other problems, it wasn't worth trying to continue on with it very far.  Needless to say, I deleted the game before even finishing the prologue. Glad it was a free weekend and I didn't purchase this, but can't recommend any other Mac user make the purchase.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												I have never been very keen on Tactical/Strategy games.  Not because they're bad, I am usually bad at them.  But when I checked out Heir of Carthage playing this I was very impressed with the details and I just had to buy it for myself!The game is super fun, being complex in every-way.  You really have to spend time learning the different aspects such as Politics, Diplomacy, Warefare and Economy command.  I have just under 80 hours on my belt and I have yet to fully understand the mechanics of Rome 2.  It's a fun filled investment!Unfortunately, there are some really cool factions, such as Sparta and Athens that you would like to play that you cannot unless you purchase over-priced DLC.  Sparta are a faction in the Grand Campaign yet are unplayable.  I honestly find this mindblowingly frustrating!  I paid £9.99 for Wrath of Sparta and wrongly assumed that would unlock Sparta to play in the Grand Campaign.  Turns out this is incorrect and extra DLC must be purchased.  I personally would prefer CA creating the full game without the DLC so when we purchase Rome 2, it feels like the full game.

Posted: November 22, 2015
												I have thoroughly enjoyed rome 2, but at the same time this could have been so much better. I never played rome 1 or medieval to death and maybe that explains why i'm not constantly feeling cheated at the game just blatantly not being as good as those. Everything is beautifully presented on the map, the icons and the buildings etc, but this games problems are not interface related. For starters, the warface engine used in the battles destroys the experience in battle. Infact the only fun i have in these anymore is either A) Using my OP units or B) performing basic battle tactics....almost all of which are enough to outmanouevre the♥♥♥♥♥♥AI.Combat is completely broken. The engine insists on having men perform 'kill moves' in completely scripted stab then withdraw scenes.....instead of just stabbing the ♥♥♥♥ing guy infront of you to death quickly and efficiently. The roman and barbarian, eastern and hellenic units all fight thus in the same basic way- the only way to break the deadlock in the later stages of the campaign on VH or legendary ( After you've butchered you're way through the customaryshockingly bad start faction surrounding your home province ) is to get more and more OP Units which eventually spoil all the fun of combat in the first place. With no family trees, you're practically invited to use a 4 turn per year mod in order to get better invested in their life and victories....but all this does is make them massively overpowered, twice i fought large scale battles outside alexandria against full stacks of egyptians and both their commanders were level 10. This from a faction that hadnt actually gained another full province in the first 90 turns....they just sat in their homeland accruing tarits and getting more and more unbalanced.The building system is poorly explained at the start ( not helped by the terrible encyclopaedia system) and the whole system of commerce/politics not really explained. My seleucid campaign was eventually ruined/spoiled after i conquered an african tribes final city in about turn 10. this conatined one of their own factional military buildings.....yet somehow allowed me to recruit silver shield swordsmen and royal cataphracts - massively OP late game units.Agents are totally overpowered. As a consequence i now find myself agent spamming on every save i do....simply because they are broken on this game. DO NOT USE 4 turns per and then use agents. The spies ability to 'poison provisions' in an enemy army- sometimes killing as many as 400-500 men, and the champions 'raid' ability ( inflicting damage to every building in a town or city) are just some of the highlights. By the end of the game they are more powerful than standing armies.The online unfortunately loses the avatar conquest features from shogun 2, which i personally enjoyed. Yes the try -  harding some people were willing to go to just to level up a smidge more was just unenjoyable, but i still felt the game benefitted. Online battles are still fun, but ( in a similar way to medieval 2 and particularly shogun 2) are often decided by whoevers overpowered units perform better in the long run. In the hands of a competent ( slightly evil ) player the syrian armoured elephant is capable of such destruction as to be utterly ridiculous. This made all the more galling ofcourse by the fact thet whenever the ai has control of them they seldom get 25 kills.....Ultimately this game is not as good as rome 1 in alomst all comparable things. Shogun got a bit of a free ride because of its beautiful presentation-though the combat was still broken, though this game was robbed of that because of the state of the ai and presentation at launch.I dont want to give it any kind of rating as i hate scores but at the end of the day if you are new to TW you should not be playing this first when rome 1 and medieval 2 exist, unless you're a graphical manic like me.Ps. The expansions to this game , caesar in gaul and hannibal are very good, adding interesting new factions and different settings obviously...but would have benefitted from some napoleon esque scripting in their layout- rome for example are 9 times out 10 hammered in CIG by all the ten-a-penny barbarian factions, spoiling the expansion a tad.

												Total War: Rome 2 has developed in to something very enjoyable for the ones interested in the total war genre and time period. After the Emperor Edition update the game really feels polished enough to uncover the core experience. The glaring issues have been washed away mostly and there remains a core idea of the game that somewhat works enough to enjoy it.Heavily recommended for the fans of this time period. Seeing the nations you read about or watch in movies or TV series in action with nice graphics and a good turn based system is a great experience. Rome 2 could have been another great game like Shogun 2. It didn't end up going that high up in the quality scale but that doesn't mean that it is not a very good game.Must play for the fans of the time period and the total war series.85/100

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												TL:DR:  8/10I pre-ordered Total War Rome II but only just started playing the game due to the amount of negative backlash levied at the game from launch. Now I have finally started to play the game and I have really enjoyed it - but I should note that I am not playing the purely "vanilla" version of Rome II. After much reading I decided to download Toons' "All in One Mod" for Rome II and it is really good. So please note that my subsequent comments are coloured by having played the mod.Rome II does some things really well compared to previous Total War games (of which I have played most of them). I really like how the Auto Resolve for battles has been addressed, whereby it shows you the likelihood of victory based on the battle stance you take (aggressive, balanced, defensive) and also the percentage of troops you will have left for each choice. The enemy AI is also well balanced and fights well in the field battles as well as on the diplomatic side of things. I really liked the addition of the Pros and Cons listed by each faction for why they like or dislike your nation. This made it much simpler to determine why they might reject an offer as opposed to past TW games where it was infuriating to be rejected and not understand why. Having naval support during battles is a nice touch also and builds upon the naval warfare introduced in Empire, even if it's still quite clunky at times.The Spies and Heroes/Champions are also much better designed in this game than the previous Rome and Empire. Now you can assign perks to the individual agents and level them up as you desire. I remember thinking in Empire "What is the point of the spy! His chances of assassinating someone is barely 20%!" Now I have used them to great effect in weakening cities, garrisons and travelling armies. A great improvement all round!There is also much more opportunities to conduct war in the political arena with assassinations and securing promotions etc. This has been greatly expanded from Empire and the previous Rome and adds a broader dimension to the game.One thing that I don't like so much is the way armies can be split and travel. It is impossible (as far as I can see) to transport troops from one army to another unless the General travels with them in tow. This may well be more thematic but I feel that it hinders the game play a bit. I also completely disagree with CA's decision to make this such a DLC heavy title/franchise. Some additional campaigns and so on are fine as added DLC to me but adding a Blood and Gore mode and other minor aesthetic changes that were already in the game files and just required "activation" is ridiculous. Companies need to stop selling us half-completed games! But all in all I thoroughly recommend Rome II - especially if you seek out a mod like I did. 8/10

												Ok so were do i start. I wouldnt say i recommend this game, because although i have over 150 hours on it, i felt that it wasnt worth that amount of money, maybe 30 dollars at the time. Its a way easier game than any other total war series game, the AI is stupid. On the 6 or 7 campaigns i hace played, no more tan 10 times the AI attacked my cities, but only when there were no soldiers on them. Also, the AI army is very basic. You will never found a high rank army with the best units on an AI army that can be at least a match for you, but mostly levy pikemen and scouts and so on. It is very easy to win, the only thing is that it takes time to conquer all the provinces. It is truly amazing how stupid they are. It seems that major factions are always on the defensive strategy, as they are weak and stepped on by smaller factions. Jesus what a waste of 50 dollars. But hey, i love being a Roman and conquering everyone, and the graphics are awesome. Maybe by playing at legendary difficulty it can be a good gamne

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Do not by this game.I'll start with some of the good points.- The graphics i think are very good, both in battles and on the campaign map but mainly in the battles with the close ups on individal soldiers, effects and looking on the battle as a whole.-Diffrent factions- unlike shogun 2 for example the factions all have different soldiers and there are loads of them giving the game much more re-playability.-there is loads of strategy involved and you can control your faction in loads of different aspects (if you like that kind of thing) .Now why you shouldn't buy it. unlike many people my problem with it is not the early software issues or how the soldiers fight or anything so detailed in the gamplay. My problem with it is much worse, it is incredibly boring.-The politics and all that is fantasticly dull and is way too complicated, especially if your playing as Rome.-The game is really restrictive in how you can play. In old TW games you could have as many armies as you like. The games  were much less complex. In Rome 2 your number of armies is limited based on the size of your empire and those armies have to have generals. This leads on to the fact that the generals are too important and complicated and i couldn't care less about them.-It takes ages to do anything. You have to spend about 2 hours playing each battle endlessly pausing and playing and, God, the clicking, so much clicking. Then you finish the battle and re-enter the misery of the campaign where you cannot, due to the army limit and the fact that settlements take so long to become happy after being captured, capture any more settlements in less than about 79 million turns.-There's just too much to think about when your playing. Food supplies, people's happiness, technology and buildings, politics and diplomacy, generals, armies, settlements, recruitment, navies, it goes on forever.Basicly the game is too complicated and boring for most human mortals.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Rome II is both a grand strategy turn-based game, as well as RTS. In Rome II's campaign you have the option to select from several different classical civilizations, each with their own advantaged and disadvantages. The campaign operates like any other total war game. You must balance economy, diplomacy, military and navy, and now in Rome II, politics. Territories have changed since previous total war games. Now several territories are grouped together in provinces in order to help manage them more efficient. Players must also be able to balance public squalor, and food in their nation. Public squalor has a negative effect and can lead to revolts. A way to combat this is to build certain shrines, entertainment buildings (like a coliseum), or public sources to water like aquaducts and fountains for example. However some of these come at a price and will deplete your food storage. Many of the buildings have trade offs and benefits, but other buildings can be built to counteract these. Rome II was released unfinished, and littered with bugs, but since its release it has fixed many crucial issues making it a playable game. Not to mention the fact that there are a plethora of mods and addons out there that improve the game, or even change the game completely.>VERY IMPORTANT<This is a perspective of the single player gameplay in Rome II, not Multiplayer as I do not play MP.Gameplay 8/10+Game plays great now with few to no bugs that I have come across since its plauged release day. Most have been fixed or are undergoing fixes and balances.+The UI is a little more streamlined and cleaned up since other total war games, many buttons offer a drop down window with more options to select during the course of battle.+Line of Sight (LOS) system. Rome II offers a new LOS system in which terrain features can block the view of other units offering greater strategic gameplay (moving through forests or behind large hills to hide troops).+Vanilla Rome II (no addons) is relatively fast paced and has recieved negative reviews for its arcade like gameplay. However with addons battles can be more realistic and drawn out than Vanilla.+Tons of units to chose from for each nation, and even more with addons. It's a big improvement from Shogun 2 where you had the same type of units for almost all factions.+40 unit card battles - hugely epic-Vanilla Rome II battles are often shorter than they should be, too arcade-like.-UI can be a little too big during 40 unit card battlesAI (Battles and Campaign Map) 8/10+AI on campaign map are a little more aggressive than they were before. They are constantly creating armies and trying to push into your territory. (However on easier difficulties their armies are usually limited to a few. It's better to play on harder difficulties, more realistic)+AI on the RTS side seek high ground  when it's nearby. They do not go out of their way if it is far away to head to high ground (seen this happen in shogun 2).+AI on RTS side stay in formations, there is far less awkward jumbling of formations ebfore they charge at you.+In large battles the AI will look to flank you with cav and archers-You really have to play on harder difficulties for the AI to perform correctly and create multiple larger armies, and make intelligent decisions on the battlefield. This could be bad for newer players who are not familiar with RTS and grand scale strategy.-Sometimes during an attakc on a settlement, the AI's defending navy will land their forces further away than necessary and those forces will sit there on the beach.-Sometimes the AI will chose to smash into your lines on the battlefield and refuse to commit troops elseware to exploit a victory.-Sometimes after beating another regiment in battle, your unit will sit there and get attacked and not retaliate. ( A little more micro would be required- not a big deal but if you're getting attacked you don't just stand there).Visuals 10/10+Rome II is by far the most beautiful RTS game I've played to date.+Soldiers react to the flow of battle. If you are losing they will drag their feet and have their heads down looking tired and broken. While idle soldiers will cheer and taunt the enemy.+Generals will give a speech before battle. They will recognize the type of army you're facing whether it be barbarians, eastern empires, greeks, or north african empires. (the more you play Rome II the more boring these get since there are so few speeches)+Combat animations are awesome+Gore mod is not as exaggerated as it was in shogun 2. Looks more realistic. -You need to have a pretty top notch rig to run Rome II in high fps with top graphics regardless of what CA wanted (making it playable on any computer)DLC 3/10+Cool new units+Cool effects with gore mod+Fun new campaign-You should not have to pay for these small editions-The DLC content is stuff that was withheld from the release of Rome II in order for CA to make more money off their game. Really its stuff that should already be implemented in the game since day 1.Overall I think it has turned out to be a great game despite features in the DLC section that should have already been added since day 1. That being said, the gore dlc is understandable as releasing a game with a T rating (no gore) opens the game up to a greater audience. Releasing the gore after makes it M only if you buy the gore. All in all I can't wait to see what CA comes out with next.EDIT/UPDATE: Download Divide Et Impera, it makes the game 10x better with more indepth strategy, longer battles, and huge unit rosters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I am/was a big Total War fan. For the sake of this review I will ignore that the game had a terrible launch.First off the game is waaayy more playable with the patches, the campaign isn't a mess and is actually fun, the campaign works. Unfortunatly I don't play Total war for the campaign; I play Total War for the battles and Rome 2's battles are bad, not terrible just bad.First off the audio has not been improved the music sucks life out of the game and the voice acting is well Sh*t. The other sound effects (sword and shield clashes, marching etc) are good however I would prefer to hear someone screaming from being killed instead of the sound of metal clashing.The animations are rubbish, the kill moves are unrealistic; soldiers slide across the floor to set up for the moves and when they do the kill moves look staged. Also the soldiers can be killed by a none kill move or a simple stab however the soldier that died has the same animation as if he got hit by a projectile and this looks stupid. The soldiers rubberband (this is more obvious in slow motion). There is still no unit collision; the units stop in perferect synchronization when they "clash", also when you issue a order all of the soldiers in the unit respond at the same time like robots it is not realistic. When two spear units clash they leave a gap and only one or two soldiers in each unit will fight eachother. The User interface in the battles is still stupid they still use the art style for the units and there is no guard mode. There are many more issues with the game (like how the light can refelct off sand) but I can't be bothered to explain these issues do not buy this game or its dlc.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Firstly, I am new to the Total war Series entirely. I have played CIV V (150Hrs), and the closest material I have in the way of experience to games like this. I did not play Rome TW 1, I jumped on the 75% off sale and have not played it much. What I have played speaks leaps and volumes about its performance as a whole.; its failure to intrigue someone and help them maintain interest is a complete failure. It was 2014 and you get character graphics on the adviser (just a head... A HEAD), portraits that the PS1 would out preform. There was little effort spent in polishing this game. I wish I could say it was just an aesthetic polishing I'm referring to, however I am not. There is a plethora of bugs, including but not limited to your units falling off the map. Hey that’s cool. Who needed the general anyway? Hah.... :(  Units doing nothing, not following orders, formation, or the like. I wish I could talk more on this, but I want to get to the huge flaw of this game. Its major issue: This game does not care about you. It's true. It will not help you, it will not give you the tools you need to move forward. It will be hard, it will not warn you, it will hate you, it will leave you cold and stranded at the bus stop as your fingertips are chilled by the ever so penetrating wind from its constant neglect. It will laugh, as you attempt to make sense of why you have to be a politician and lead the war. Why you have to delegate taxes, when you really just want to kill something. Why a game that looks like a glorified roman chess board turns out to be constant nail in the frontal lobe. Reminding you that you are not worth the effort to love, to care about, or it would have given you the tools to accomplish greatness, and the reason behind the reasoning of being a political dictator while you claim to protect the citizens you bleed dry to fund your growing "empire". The game is hideous, the game play is broken, also Rome hates you.  If the developers cared about anything beyond the initial purchase from you, it would have been a captivating experience on a progressive scale of understanding. Instead it assumes you have hopped on forums before purchase or that you will afterward, to make sense of anything. To spend 100 hours learning the game before you can play it. Instead of being able to learn as you go. If I wanted to spend more time in forums learning a game then playing it, I would play EvE online more.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												In a game such as Rome II Total War you cannot give an accurate review without a detailed account of the ‘Spear Brothers’, one of the most revered,  blood thirsty and - at times - gangrenous of all the units in this medieval role-play-simulation game. If the Brothers of the Spear were not written into the game, we would likely never have seen the likes of the Total War franchise; it is said that Tim Ansell, the mastermind behind Creative Assembly who developed the game in 1987, had a dream were the Suebian Spear Brothers came to him in the night, laden with documented plans for the creation of such a game series. Whether this is entirely true or not we cannot be sure, but we can be sure that the Spear Brothers will continue to inspire a generation of video game players, young, old and even those not born yet.The Germanic tribe of the Spear Brothers is a tribe hardened by horrific war. At the time of Rome II, iron supplies - especially in West Germany - were very sparse. It is no surprise then that the Spear Brothers, the mighty warriors, were given priority of the metal for their dreaded ‘Spear Brother Spears’ or ‘framea’ in their own tongue. It is murmured in legend that the larger the man, the larger the spear. We have no reason yet to doubt this, according to the many geophys surveys that have been undertaken to find the truth of these giants of the battlefield.It would be a crime to end this review without mentioning the battle cry of the Spear Brothers, due indeed to the fact that few have ever survived it. One account comes from a Briton monk, Jasper, who whilst riding Maurice, his donkey into battle, witnessed the most ferocious and worrisome cry he had ever heard from the mouths of the Brothers of the Spear who he was gradually trotting towards. He could see the blood spurting from the ears of his own brothers, drenching each other in crimson pain. The horses were bleeding too while they manically ran into each other. Jasper, who now believed he was entering the blood and fire occupied Seventh Circle of Hell, only survived because when he eventually reached the front line, all the Britons were dead and the Spear Brothers had gone back to their tribes with haste, blood thirsty for more combat with their own peoples. The tale goes that Jasper lived the rest of his reasonably long life with Maurice, entrenched somewhere in the Aiguilles d'Arves in France, safe from the devilry of the Barbarians. It is said descendants of the Spear Brothers (SB) continue fighting, albeit virtually; if you are lucky enough to encounter one, be wary, hold fast and please remember ‘The Story of Jasper & Maurice’.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Now that it's all patched and up to standard, Rome 2 is a fun game.  Great graphics, great faction selection, the scenery looks stunning ... what else can I say?  This game, and Total War games in general, are great among strategy games for their cinematic battles, and in this department, the game delivers.  The downsides might include the fact that some of the faction rosters may be a little repetitive, and some of the names of generals are slightly historically inaccurate for their culture and the time period in which the game is set.  Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8/10.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												I have never been very keen on Tactical/Strategy games.  Not because they're bad, I am usually bad at them.  But when I checked out Heir of Carthage playing this I was very impressed with the details and I just had to buy it for myself!The game is super fun, being complex in every-way.  You really have to spend time learning the different aspects such as Politics, Diplomacy, Warefare and Economy command.  I have just under 80 hours on my belt and I have yet to fully understand the mechanics of Rome 2.  It's a fun filled investment!Unfortunately, there are some really cool factions, such as Sparta and Athens that you would like to play that you cannot unless you purchase over-priced DLC.  Sparta are a faction in the Grand Campaign yet are unplayable.  I honestly find this mindblowingly frustrating!  I paid £9.99 for Wrath of Sparta and wrongly assumed that would unlock Sparta to play in the Grand Campaign.  Turns out this is incorrect and extra DLC must be purchased.  I personally would prefer CA creating the full game without the DLC so when we purchase Rome 2, it feels like the full game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I am a HUGE FAN of the total war series and a big history nut. This game was, is, and will be the biggest disappointment i have ever had.Let me just start and say that the game can be pretty fun at times and has its pros, however they are greatly overshadowed by all of the negatives.One word: STREAMLININGThis is probably the simplest total war game yet, and it really takes away from the experience.Now this could be a positive if you are new to these games, but for hardcore fans this is a slap in the face. All of the factions are divided into 3 types (Hellenic, Barbarian and Rome rip offs) ALL OF THEM FEEL THE SAME! The Macedonians feel like the SeleucidsThe Iceni feel like the ArverniEgypt feels like Carthage.and on and on AND ONThe only difference between all of the factions is different named units with slightly different skins.Or some crazy exotic unit like fully armored war elephants that can rip army's to shreds.To add on to thatWALLET♥♥♥♥♥♥br>There is already two full dlc campaigns and a unit pack dlcall incredibly over priced and worthless. But don't worry, there are no over powered units in the dlc'swant to know why?BECAUSE ALL OF THE FACTIONS FEEL THE SAME!The dlc units are  just re-skined units with different names and a funny accent.If you enjoyed the innovative and Amazingly addictive multiplayer of shogun 2 (in my opinion it was a lot of fun, disagree if you want.) If you liked the RPG mechanics of your online general in Shogun 2If you had fun playing with clan mates in a game with full clan support in shogun 2.If you had fun Playing With your own personalized army holding the flag you designed in shogun 2.Play shogun 2The multiplayer in Rome 2?Its badIts terribleITS ABSOULUTLY TRAGIC.Bare Bones and Pointless.Doesn't even include the fun free for all battles that Rome one had.I could go on and on for a lot longer then you are probably willing to read, so i will just let you make a decision.If you are a super hard core fan, get it on a super sale for as cheap as it will getbut just be absolutely sure you want this game before you waste you money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Rome Total War II, its a great game in the series, after a few startup hiccups the game is a great addition. A few major highlights in my personal opinion are: Addition of naval battles, a great way how they added these battles with great ships and lovely graphics. a true chance to fight the battles yourself if auto-resolve wouldve given you a loss or too many losses. Do mind, when you have a large navy and attack a city, it will sometimes be difficult to actually land all units. Co-Op Multiplayer, I love playing together with a friend and establishing a massive realm together, also player vs player works great in multiplayer. This was one of the best additions to the game in my believe. Improved graphics.Unfortunately everything has a negative side, below are my personal believes this may be different for you. Historical accuracy, a lot of units or city names lack historical accuracy, as I'm a history fanatic thats important to me. This is not a reason NOT to buy the game though. You now have cities and villages - in provinces - its new, its different, personally i dont like it as you can't wall up every city to defend it. it does give an additional challenge to the game which is good. Battles can become a massive meat grind where neither of the 2 parties is really making any progress in winning.One big downside on this game are all the DLC's for new factions and new units or even to see some blood&gore, you have to pay for every addition to the game, some worth it, some not.Overall, its a great game and i would recommend anyone to buy it if you are into grand strategy games with a historical twitch to it. Just try and see how large your empire can become with legendary settings.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Brief ReviewTotal War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition. Is a similar and familar experience to the other Total War Games. Still rickety in many places and, for all its improvements, it remains a very similar experience. It's not worth getting now if you were on the fence before. It's not a radically different experience or a dramatically changed game. Like the Roman Republic itself, it's still prone to collapsing and to repeating its mistakes over and over, but that doesn't stop it from being terribly entertaining and, at times, worryingly compulsive. Total War: Rome 2 is good, quite a bit better even, but it's not the best thing since sliced bread.Pros and ConsProsHuge BattlesTurn-based and Real-time StrategyExcellent handlingGorgeous LandscapeSiege BattlesHuge Array Of LocationsNumerous options for destructive experimentationConsAIBad PrologueAI PathfindingAn EndingWhy all this violence? Cant I just have sign that say please stay away

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Where do I begin with this game? After sinking over 800 hours into it, there is a lot I could say, but I will try to keep it short. Overall, the game is great, and there are many improvements from the original Rome Total War. Being able to have large 40 unit armies during the period of Ancient Rome is somwthing I have enjoyed for many many hours. The campaign map's size alone is also very impressive. However, some things bother me about this game. While there are bugs, just like every game, there are things that they left out/got rid of from other Total War games that were great features. 1. The ability to customize your army/general, like in Shogun 2. This feature was one of my favorites from the Total War series, as it made me feel like i was really in control of my army. 2. I can never understand the online multiplayer in Total War games. It should be possible to play campaigns online with way more than two people. Especially considering the size of the campaign map in Rome 2, there should be a possibilty of at least up to 8 player games. 3. PAYING FOR BETTER BLOOD AND GORE. I mean really? You have to charge for that? I paid for it, but it definitely should have been an update not paid DLC.      So, i would recommend this game, but only to those who enjoy Total War games. If you are looking for a good RTS game, you may want to look elsewhere, only because the mechanics of this game are not the greatest I've seen. If you are looking for a good Total War game to start with, I would suggest Medieval 2, or Shogun 2. This game is still too pricey for someone looking for a good game.

It is a great game that I love, but not the best to dump money into until this issue is fixed.
