content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												This game is fantastic except for the fact that they got rid of the family tree. not cool man. I like building a dynasty/legacy. the general mechanic sucks in that way. mods that go up to 12 turns a year make it a little better. the battles are great. AI is solid. the character models are gorgeous, which oddly enough is a problem. they are so gorgeous, but there are so many of them, and they are so unique and awesome looking that it makes it hard to pay attention to any of them at any given time so it just sort of becomes a huge overstimulating mess if you zoom in to watch any part of the battle. also, the battles are way too fast paced. even enormous battles sometimes last about 10 minutes, which again, makes it really hard to enjoy any of the visuals. also, every total war game before this one had better castle seige mechanics. the cities in this one, just seem WAY TOO BIG. the battles always happen on basically 1/10th of the entire city, and the AI annoyingly takes advatnage of this and sends units to the opposite side of the city to attack, making castle seiges just a total pain in the butt. Shogun 2 is better than this game in pretty much every aspect. however, i could not help but enjoy playing as the macedonians and re-taking over the success states. this game is fun, its just disappointing due to the fact that literally every game before it was better. if you love history and the total war franchise, shogun 2 is the best one. this one is good, but arguably not even as good as medieval 2. now they made a medieval 3 and did not make it as a big money grab and actually took their time with it and did not make 50 DLC's...then i would pay attention to this franchise again. i recommend rome 2, but shogun 2 is better. be Athens and conquer trade in the mediterranean. super fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												If this was the game CA released to begin with, it would've ranked up as one of the best in the series. Beautiful visuals and an enormous attention to detail, interesting and varied unit rosters for each faction, a thematic soundtrack, a yuge and engaging campaign map full of dozens of nations and tribes with legit working diplomacy (an enemy of your enemy will actively seek to trade with you or seek a military alliance for example), battle AI that managed to surprise me by using formations effectively and actually trying to outflank me and finally (in my opinion) a more visually interesting and streamlined UI.It's not perfect by a long stretch; true to the series it can be too easy (especially as Rome) and upping the difficulty doesn't make the AI smarter, it just lets them cheat with more money and better stats, 1 year per turn means your generals drop dead from old age before you've even had a chance to properly level them up, the AI will sometimes not attack you during sieges or tire its units out by running them all over the map for no reason and the performance is pretty awful for a game of its age, although I did find upgrading my Radeon drivers to Crimson 16.9.2  boosted my framerate by nearly 20fps!If you're a fan of the series but have put off buying Rome 2 because of the awful state of the game at release, you're a fan of the time period, or you just fancy building an empire - definitely pick this one up. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												This game is fantastic except for the fact that they got rid of the family tree. not cool man. I like building a dynasty/legacy. the general mechanic sucks in that way. mods that go up to 12 turns a year make it a little better. the battles are great. AI is solid. the character models are gorgeous, which oddly enough is a problem. they are so gorgeous, but there are so many of them, and they are so unique and awesome looking that it makes it hard to pay attention to any of them at any given time so it just sort of becomes a huge overstimulating mess if you zoom in to watch any part of the battle. also, the battles are way too fast paced. even enormous battles sometimes last about 10 minutes, which again, makes it really hard to enjoy any of the visuals. also, every total war game before this one had better castle seige mechanics. the cities in this one, just seem WAY TOO BIG. the battles always happen on basically 1/10th of the entire city, and the AI annoyingly takes advatnage of this and sends units to the opposite side of the city to attack, making castle seiges just a total pain in the butt. Shogun 2 is better than this game in pretty much every aspect. however, i could not help but enjoy playing as the macedonians and re-taking over the success states. this game is fun, its just disappointing due to the fact that literally every game before it was better. if you love history and the total war franchise, shogun 2 is the best one. this one is good, but arguably not even as good as medieval 2. now they made a medieval 3 and did not make it as a big money grab and actually took their time with it and did not make 50 DLC's...then i would pay attention to this franchise again. i recommend rome 2, but shogun 2 is better. be Athens and conquer trade in the mediterranean. super fun.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Now that it's all patched and up to standard, Rome 2 is a fun game.  Great graphics, great faction selection, the scenery looks stunning ... what else can I say?  This game, and Total War games in general, are great among strategy games for their cinematic battles, and in this department, the game delivers.  The downsides might include the fact that some of the faction rosters may be a little repetitive, and some of the names of generals are slightly historically inaccurate for their culture and the time period in which the game is set.  Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												This game has been really up and down for me, but I'll go into detail as to why. I love the TW series and have played everything from the original Rome to now. So I was obviously expecting some of the issues that arose around release involving lagging, video quality problems, crashing and AI difficulties. But those have thankfully been ironed out now, so we're left with a game that's stable, but more importantly, heavily moddable. Some of the things wrong with this game are easily fixed with some of the more popular mods available in the workshop, like the AI being completely incompetent at times, sailing their only fleet out to the middle of nowhere and leaving their capital undefended while you're camped on it with significant armies.I've found that it's very easy to get bored during some of the longer campaigns, because it's so simple to find yourself repeating strategies for different factions. You'll learn the best direction to expand in and subconscously follow it in most of your campaigns. It's a trap I fell into a few times and had to consciously avoid doing it to keep the game fresh. Try different things every game, different strategies, different directions. That's how I've gotten the most out of my time playing. The DLC's are good if you can get them on sale, I wouldn't recommend paying full price for any of them, The game in general is a lot of fun. The battles are realistic for the most part, the strategies you can employ are widespread and the unit diversity is good. The city/economy building is also a lot of fun, trying to find ways to stick a knife in someone's back while you're sharing a border and multiple allies is always an interesting struggle. There really is something for everyone in this game if you want to find it. I'll recommend it to anyone chasing a decent turn-based strategy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												After 3 years, I'm still coming back and playing this for hours on end. I finally won my first campaign as Parthia, because I would always just start new campaigns. I'd say the strongest point of this game is the start of campaigns, when literally anything could happen, any AI faction could rise up and become a major player. You can play the same faction infinite times and your experience would be different each time.However, the biggest problem I have with the game, the reason why I was never finishing campaigns, is how stale the endgame is. It gets super repetitive once there are only a handful of factions left, and there's hardly any diplomacy at that point, just conquest after conquest. The politics "mini-game" seems tacked on, or not fleshed out to its potential. And Diplomacy can sometimes seem strange, factions refusing to trade with you even though you have tons of resources and they have none. Every once in a while a faction will declare war on you right after agreeing to a treaty.But in the end, the strengths of this game come out on top. Battles are epic, especially when they're between two powerful and advanced factions. The growth system for cities is ingeneous, and the wide variety of cultures at play insure a unique experience for each faction (outside of the Greek city-states). This went from one of the worst Total Wars at launch to one of the best. It's in my top 5, maybe arguably my top 3 with Rome and Shogun 2.9/10, would recommend.

												Very disappointing. With increased graphics and more clever mechanics on the battlefield, everything else is dumbed down to compensate. Gone are the complex research trees and individual towns. In a time when roaming bands of outlaws are literally everywhere most towns are incapable of a simple wooden wall to protect them.And there are about 3-5 different designs of town.If you liked how previous Total wars were RTS with Civ like components well then go buy the latest Civ and an RTS.Shogun 2 was a well thought out and nice update. this is a hideous clone of what was once a gold standard.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I am a HUGE FAN of the total war series and a big history nut. This game was, is, and will be the biggest disappointment i have ever had.Let me just start and say that the game can be pretty fun at times and has its pros, however they are greatly overshadowed by all of the negatives.One word: STREAMLININGThis is probably the simplest total war game yet, and it really takes away from the experience.Now this could be a positive if you are new to these games, but for hardcore fans this is a slap in the face. All of the factions are divided into 3 types (Hellenic, Barbarian and Rome rip offs) ALL OF THEM FEEL THE SAME! The Macedonians feel like the SeleucidsThe Iceni feel like the ArverniEgypt feels like Carthage.and on and on AND ONThe only difference between all of the factions is different named units with slightly different skins.Or some crazy exotic unit like fully armored war elephants that can rip army's to shreds.To add on to thatWALLET♥♥♥♥♥♥br>There is already two full dlc campaigns and a unit pack dlcall incredibly over priced and worthless. But don't worry, there are no over powered units in the dlc'swant to know why?BECAUSE ALL OF THE FACTIONS FEEL THE SAME!The dlc units are  just re-skined units with different names and a funny accent.If you enjoyed the innovative and Amazingly addictive multiplayer of shogun 2 (in my opinion it was a lot of fun, disagree if you want.) If you liked the RPG mechanics of your online general in Shogun 2If you had fun playing with clan mates in a game with full clan support in shogun 2.If you had fun Playing With your own personalized army holding the flag you designed in shogun 2.Play shogun 2The multiplayer in Rome 2?Its badIts terribleITS ABSOULUTLY TRAGIC.Bare Bones and Pointless.Doesn't even include the fun free for all battles that Rome one had.I could go on and on for a lot longer then you are probably willing to read, so i will just let you make a decision.If you are a super hard core fan, get it on a super sale for as cheap as it will getbut just be absolutely sure you want this game before you waste you money.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I was very hopefull for this game, and have given it chance after chance to impress me. However I really feel that this is a good reprasentation of how the gamming industry has gone down in quality over the years. what I mainly mean by saying that is that companies used to make sure a game was a good complete final product before they released it. now though it seems that every game is released far to soon becuase the companies didnt budget properly for the release. meaning that we get a half♥♥♥♥♥product until they are able to fix the bugs. this means that the game has had to have like somewhere in the realm of 30 updates since its release in october. one update totally made the game completley unplayable, and SEGA was interely unhelpful in helping me getting the game running properly again. I had to have my entire computer memory wiped by geek squad (something that cost me upwards of $200) just to get the game playable again. The positives: it is a very epic and large game with many improvements from the original rome total war. the campaign map is much larger and more in depth. The battles have the ability to have blood and gore and are much more fluid than the original rome total war. Negatives: the load times on this game are a huge low point. sometimes it will take 15 min just load a saved game. also the turns sometime take 10-15min just for the other nations to do there turn, during which time you better be moving your mouse around or the game will just dump you back to the dexktop becuase it thinks ur idle if you dont move th mouse in 60 seconds now. And the constant updates are really starting to get so old that i am about to be completley over this game. the past 4 times I have come to play the game I have had to wait upwards of 30min to an hour just for some new stupid update to be downloaded. Just to play the game. this is far to much waiting and waiting and waiting just to play a game. I really hope someone from SEGA reads this and realizes that people do not appreciate being sold half completed products. oh and maybe they could make the game work properly instead of constantly focusing on putting out new DLC. just so they can make another cheap quick buck. very disapointed in a company I have supported since the mid 90's.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Easily my favorite Total War game. Drastically improves diplomacy, as well as handling your large empire (making it easier by breaking them up into provinces). The game adds a power struggle within your empire so you can play politics by killing generals or other important members of your faction (to ensure your parties dominance). Let another faction gain too much support and a civil war can occur. The armies you control can grow in both size and strength as your faction allows you to create more armies and navies (this helps to organize your military and customize their own symbols/traditions). This game mixes strategy, diplomacy, and combat all into one.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												This game has deffinitely recieved its fair share of crticism, on launch the game has numerous issues and 9 patches deep it is still not complete, releasing a buggy game is not acceptable. Looking beyond that the game has some enetertainment to offer. First and foremost looking at this game you need to look past the previous titles and see this game for what it is. THe graphics are great, the strategy offered on the campaign map is different and more unique than the previous games, old fans complain understandably but to a new user or someone who has not played a total war game in a long time the strategy present will be challenging and interesting. Battles play out great, larger and bigger than ever before.The game does have a learning curve and to fully learn the game you will have to go thru the guides and get some experience to understand it all but once you get it you are looking at an awesome game with some of the best battles a total war game can offer.In its current state the game gets a solid 7/10. With some more patches and hot fixes the Ai could use some more improvements. Modding support is deffinitely another plus. Once the Ai is complete and you can find the mods you prefer the game is worth the money.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												First of all, this game has made alot of impact to society through its historical features. History has been one of the most challenging subject to understand because of its complex and mysterious timeline which makes alot of people really confused, making it one of the most anyoying subject known. However this game had changed people from hating humanities based to loving humanities(economics, history,etc) This real time strategy have a unique content in comparison to other games. First would be the graphics, here in ancient world of Total War astonishing graphics shown (the zooming in method) helps people to analyse the gears and the culture through the weapons and also helps people that loves technology to get a better view of what a good real time strategy game should be. Secondly is the campaigns, here the campaign are free and everything is permitted, which supports both pros and cons. The pros are it teaches people to actually control an empire focusing not only on military but also diplomats, economy, etc. This really could help people know how the actual world can be. In the other hand the cons are it is a game, therefore cheats could happen. Overall I would recommend to everytone to play this game and obtain all the advantages. Marco Lembong

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I have played all the TW titles and all I can say is that this game has significantly improved since it was released. Its still not perfect, but I think its as good as we can get it and expect from CA. I personally don't agree with gaming companies like CA releasing alpha or beta games, but the fact is that the meaning of "finished game" is a metaphore. It doesn't exist, there is no such thing as a finished game nowadays, since even if they claim that a game is finished. Updates, dlcs and what have you all contradict this notion.Furthermore I would like to point out some other things that immature people and children need to know.1) There is no such thing as a finished game. Updates nowadays along with dlc's contradict this. 'Finished game' is a metaphoric concept, it is a made up notion and no longer exists.2) CA and developers like CA are all under a certain deadline, everyone knows this. If we're to blame someone for a crapy of un-furnished game, then we should blame the ones who pressure CA and not CA itself.  3) Money makes the world go round. Hence why the concept of the dlc was created, since it is another form of making more money from games. The concept behind this is to release un-finished games, so that content which should have been included in the game are sold off separately, hence more money being made off on top of the initial sale of the game. Why release a game finished, when you can milk the many 'sheeple' who buy these games. Of course, people will continue to complain, but at the end of the day these 'sheeple' always out weigh those who do complain. The concept of the custome is always right no longer has relevance in today's world. Its an extinct notion. If you want to improve or create something more to your liking, then make it yourself. The TW modding community is a perfect example of this.4) Try the Radious Mods. If the vanilla version of the game doesn't suit your taste and makes you cry like a baby, then try this mod since I've played it and its practically fixed most of the issues RTW2 had at the very beginning. Its the best this game can go and in fact I no longer update my RTW game because of this. Those who bought CING are all fools who like wasting money. 5) We should all put ourselves in CA's shoes because till we all do this, how can we possibly complain about the lack of juice this game has when we can never comprehend the difficulties that CA faces to begin with. Running a company is very difficult, you can't have everything you want, nothing is totally perfect. Its OK for some of us to sit at our computers and complain, but to be honest. I'd rather not complain since the worse thing that could happen is that CA stops producing these games and if that were to happen, then I'd be very unhappy. Fact is, there aren't many game developers making historic strategy games right now due to the niche market its in. In fact, only two companies out there stick out as the best strategy game developers of our time; Paradox Studios and Creative Assembly. There used to be Maxis, but that's gone down hill. For me CA's TW francise is as good as it will get, till another 'CA' starts up to compete, which is highly unlikely.Take care everyone, peace out!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												When I first started Total War: Rome II, I had no clue what to do. Or even the real purpose of playing the game. Over time, in 5 minuets, I understood. The same concept in the game applies to all other Total War games. It was to CONQUER (Grand Campaign) and breaking the enemies moral... and that was in 5 minuets when I first started Total War. This review will be only about/mostly about battles. Not the Grand Campaign.Likes-High detailed units that destroyes weak computersHigh graphicsSimple and easy to understand in 1-2 hours of playing, except for the game mechanicsDifferent factions, not like StarCraft where there are only 3 factions with less new unit to play withGame mechanics (ex. unit moral, charges can be affected by the slope of the land, forest blocks missles, etc.)Updates, updates, updates. They appear unually every month or two, changing the game in different ways. Ex. When archers were useless due to their less than 30 damage, now they are useful with over 30 damage. Also, battles last longer with more armor given to the units.Unit rosters are usually huge, not like StarCraft in multiplayerNot everything is balanced *look up*The community and friendliness in multiplayer battles with other players. After a few games and laughter with each other, there's an established community that last very shortly. Dislikes-Super elite unitsDoes not usually follow historical ways and I know why thanks to balancing *sobs* *Disappointment*Micro manage is not challenging enough, I see hammer and anvil tactics or something similar a lot. Sometimes it's just an anvil. The other time, it's just a hammer. What the game is missing is sickle. Every units in every fractions are in a boxy formation. Why can't they have loose or uneven formationBad melee combat/strange melee combat. It's like knights and samurais fighting each other. One is super defensive and the other is super offensive. Like Veteran Shield Warriors vs. Principes. I find it strange, but I don't know about you guys though.When one person lags/having internet issues, everyone suffers. Battles lag with laggers. I'd like the StarCraft system where we wait for the lagger to drop out. At the same time, having a nice/mean chat with each other.Conclusion-Overall, the game is great, but has poor micro that StarCraft surpass.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I was very hopefull for this game, and have given it chance after chance to impress me. However I really feel that this is a good reprasentation of how the gamming industry has gone down in quality over the years. what I mainly mean by saying that is that companies used to make sure a game was a good complete final product before they released it. now though it seems that every game is released far to soon becuase the companies didnt budget properly for the release. meaning that we get a half♥♥♥♥♥product until they are able to fix the bugs. this means that the game has had to have like somewhere in the realm of 30 updates since its release in october. one update totally made the game completley unplayable, and SEGA was interely unhelpful in helping me getting the game running properly again. I had to have my entire computer memory wiped by geek squad (something that cost me upwards of $200) just to get the game playable again. The positives: it is a very epic and large game with many improvements from the original rome total war. the campaign map is much larger and more in depth. The battles have the ability to have blood and gore and are much more fluid than the original rome total war. Negatives: the load times on this game are a huge low point. sometimes it will take 15 min just load a saved game. also the turns sometime take 10-15min just for the other nations to do there turn, during which time you better be moving your mouse around or the game will just dump you back to the dexktop becuase it thinks ur idle if you dont move th mouse in 60 seconds now. And the constant updates are really starting to get so old that i am about to be completley over this game. the past 4 times I have come to play the game I have had to wait upwards of 30min to an hour just for some new stupid update to be downloaded. Just to play the game. this is far to much waiting and waiting and waiting just to play a game. I really hope someone from SEGA reads this and realizes that people do not appreciate being sold half completed products. oh and maybe they could make the game work properly instead of constantly focusing on putting out new DLC. just so they can make another cheap quick buck. very disapointed in a company I have supported since the mid 90's.

												If you are coming to look at Rome now the probability is 1) your not a longtime fan of the series2) You were waiting around for it to be on saleIf your of the 1st group then I would join the 2nd, the battles do look amazing but that is about it, the game is simply dull and not worth more than £10 as you will lose interest quickly. A lot of people have spent a lot of time trying to enjoy this game, (this was expensive on release) but it has remained even with dlc and mods massively empty. You will simply run out of stuff to do, ending turns until the only real challenge emerges in the form of a civil war, but these are not exactly fun, slogging back through the map to the territories you already controlled but lost to armies that appear out of nowhere. Likely you will use this feature called the political system that measures the time until a civil war begins for when its time to call it quits.If you are waiting for it go on offer just be weary that it deserves a lot of the negativity surrounding it, but if its on sale it can be forgotten about in your library.Enjoy

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												It's hard to say no to a Total War game since I've loved every single version so far, even Empire Total War. However, if I had knew about the bugs and glicthes on launch, I probably would have waited for the game to be fixed. That being said, it's been a few weeks now and the game is starting to look pretty good. Gameplay wise, the game is the same as any of the other Total War games. There a few new features added in, and most have improved the game. For example, Siege battles are a bit more challenging and now you have restrictions on how many armies/navies you can have, which is good because the AI doesn't spam like 50 small armies anymore. Speaking of the AI, it's probably the only thing I have to complain about. It still sucks, but the AI is defintely an improvement over Shogun 2. However, I still find it stupid when I see a whole unit of swords charge head first into my pike formation. The Graphics are really nice, but sadly you require a pretty good computer to run things on High/Ultra. I'm currently running on Medium with an i3. However, the graphics are still beautiful and the animations are really exciting, as the battles feel pretty real now. Overall, I recommend this game for everyone to try. However, make sure you have an i5 and a good video card to unlock all the wonderful aspects of this game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Finally a worthy successor to Rome: Total War!Though no Total War game can ever hope to match the height on which the original 2004 Rome: Total War dwells, this sequel required over a year to rise from a pricey bèta to a worthy successor.Alas, certain features such as the family tree are still absent; the political system is still a mess and the AI still occasionally behaves like a woman on her period. But who cares, Total War is about warfare and conquest. Using the acclaimed Radious Mod I find myself actually requiring careful planning rather than mindlessly march off to war. Now, one can face multiple enemies, and if that sufficiently weakens you, other nations may use that as a casus belli and attack you at your most weakest moment. And I love that! But what drives me into writing a review in the first place? Never have I cared for expressing my opinion in such a public way. Well, the situationi is that certain friends of mine have this game in their wishlist and right now, its 66% off. That, and I would like to try cooperative mode...To quote a famous sports brand: Just do it.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												It's not bad. I feels like a step back from Rome I, though. What I really wanted was just Rome I with new graphics. Oh, well. maybe Rome III will be more my style.The two major complaints I have is 1) the general system and 2) the mission system. The number of generals determines the number of armies, and you never have enough generals. Which is odd. There are prospective generals that want you to hire them, you want to hire them, but the game says 'no, you have enough'. I don't like that. Also the guided mission thingee really jacks with my game. I don't want to play through historical events; I want to make my own. The whole thing just felt like it took every opportunity to tell me how wrongly I was playing their game.If neither of those things bug you, the game is pretty amazing. I played through several hours worth before moving on, so that speaks to how good the rest of the game is :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												A fantastic strategy game with a perfect combination of exciting campaign gameplay and intense and difficult real time battles.  Real strategy is required in this game to succeed not only in battle, but also as a nation. Many options are presented to you in Rome II when it comes to your empire. Will you expand via military force and conquer all in your path? Or will you make connections, allies and trade, becoming the richest and most influential nation in the known world? The choice is yours in Rome II and it does so in great fashion. There is always room for improvment and Rome II isn't perfect. A few things could be more fleshed out, such as general(Family Tree from TW: Attila would have been great) and I've always yerned for a more personal connection to your units within an army. A simple window for stats for that unit would be nice with # of kills and battles, total losses perhaps. Overall Rome II is an amazing strategy game, easily one of the best. I recommend it to any RTS fan, and even newcomers. It may be overwhelming at first but it's easy to get into and has a boat load of content.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												4/5- Great fun being a roman commander, with more unit variation than Shogun 2 but lacking the polish and engaging generals/agents of Shogun 2. DLC whoring is nowhere near as bad as I thought(except greek states).TLDR:It isn’t the worst total war(Empire), but it is not on the level of Shogun 2(the best).  Overall it has that flavor that total war seeks to give you, but instead of the flavor being focused on generals, it is more focused on provinces(similar to Medieval 2).Most reviews tackle this game from patch 7 and earlier(like 6 months from release kind of times), but emperor edition was the “relaunch” of the game. I also assume that you know what this game is. If you don’t google and youtube have your answer. I played this around 10 hours at release, 50 hours at patch 4, 50 hours at patch 14, and probably 20 hours at patch 15/Emperor Edition. I plan on playing much more coop campaign. I did preorder this game and got greek states 'free'.-----Campaign: -----A good selection of nations with various cultures, with a decent building system that they pulled out of shogun. Diplomacy is pretty good, not Europa Universalis level, and not shogun 2 level, but its not a detractor like in some other total wars. I really like the building system and agent limits, although spies are still too powerful. Most fights will end up being in provinces without walls which is fine with me. The early/mid game is quite fun, with lategame being not as interesting as the realm divide but now there are big enemy nations that form, so yay.+Varied starts and nation types.+amazing game for coop campaign, no desynch issues and you can draw on the map.  +relaunch redid the building system to make interesting choices on specialties and bonuses for specific provinces.+reasonable turn timers/load timers. About 1 minute loading screens for battles, 30-40s for turn timers.+Attrition and unit replenishment has been changed to shogun level, so it will take 6 or so turns to get a good unit back to strength.+AI will actually attack you, so more stances will be used and you can actually have ambushes on them from choke points.+The happiness and food systems work much better than before, it is a mechanic you need to build around, while not being as ridiculous as it was on release with stupid food losses of -8 for a reasonable T3 temple.+I personally like the limit on armies based on how big your nation is. With the new building system you can actually have decent garrisons.-some of these nations are very similar- most of the greek states or barbarian tribes use the same general units, and because they start right next to each other it could make for a pretty boring expansionary period to fight clones of yourself.-family trees are gone, and they have been replaced with a subpar system of traits and gravitas to make your generals interesting. On the whole your generals and their armies are less engaging than shogun and medieval, with a boring upgrade tree.-Traits and upgrade trees still poorly documented and pretty boring. Might want to grab toadies Traits mod.-Autoresolve is still kind of borked. Mostly when dealing with elephants, Horse Archers, and Town Garrisons(Not sure what is wrong with these- sometimes it is correct and sometimes it is not).-Civil wars not as interesting as realm divide. A lot of the time the "big empires" are pretty subpar and the Civil wars are annoying as a mechanic.---Battles:--- There is a good deal of variety here between nations, pike/hoplite heavy cultures play very differently from general infantry or barbarian cultures. When you zoom in things look fine. These are some of the best battles in the total war series(tactically).**NOTE-  If you have trouble telling units apart, turn your “unit detail” setting down to low- the unit detail is actually the variation between soldiers in a unit, so I play on low and things look perfectly fine.+General unit ‘types’ such as skirmishers and heavy infantry are a necessity, so you can’t just make an army of full heavy infantry and win every game(in campaign even!). AI doesn’t build enough horses though in my experience, but it’s about the same as the other total wars, not perfect army composition.+AI is perfectly acceptable in both sieges and open battle. Only time I have seen it bug out is with 2 or less ladders and sometimes it will have 2 towers blunder into each other if it builds too many.+Very few unit abilities worth using every time now- some charges are still in the game and sadly no really interesting general abilities like in shogun 2. Generals get 2 or 3 abilities that are okay, but they won’t really change the battle by being there as they did in S2.+Battles are longer than launch(most take about 3 minutes to skirmish and 5-10m of line fighting) and tired units are much slower at killing other units, a really nice tactical addition that makes a lot of the abilities much more situational.+Things to legitimately do in battle now! With the long fights comes tactical opportunity. Flanking is very important, as is having fresh units and skirmishers.+They made the unit cards forced into a single bar! This adds at least 3 inches on your screen of viewable space, and makes a huge difference to how big the UI appears.+Amazingly…the warscape engine is working fine. They have updated it so multiple soldiers can attack the same enemy and on the whole units aren’t bugging around floating everywhere. I would not have believed it if I did not see it myself! Just go watch a video.-Some units look weird in their 2d sprite mode when you zoom out, pikemen do not show you deployed pikes and roman infantry tend to blur horribly.-Boat battles are still confusing to tell what is going on and fiddly on ramming motions. At least transports are fixed to be terrible at fighting.-sound is subpar. General speeches are back but you need to zoom in really close and they will say a few lines. There are also lines that units say when attacking other units which again you need to zoom really close, probably not happening in the middle of combat so I did not realize that they recorded like 100 different ones until I looked it up on youtube.--DLC:--This was what I thought Rome 2 was made for- when the “greek states” were day 1 DLC, I thought this was going to turn into “want to even think about playing nation X? DLC!”. And by the starting positions from the core game, this was mostly true. At launch you could play most of the nations neighboring rome, but for some reason only one nation on the Spanish peninsula(carthage, which was also in Africa). I expected much whoring on releasing dlcs, but quite frankly they have not really done this. There is a perfectly good core experience here without needing to buy DLCS(Except for that greek states one). The only other DLC I have bought is the blood pack which has added visually to the battles(it adds more animations as well as blood by the way!). All of the DLC here is either bonus nations or extra campaigns, which are perfectly valid DLC.Final tips:*Go pick up a music mod, the base music is pretty boring. Either the rome 1 music mod or the very nice Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ II music pack adds quite a bit to the experience. This is the only mod I use since the rerelease- no need for sweeping balance mods anymore.*If you have a weaker processor, the siege AI will cause lag(weird stuttering of units when they reach the walls)- best 2 ways to fix this are to turn down the unit detail setting or get less units on the board(small unit scale). With a Q6600 @ 2.4GHz this hits for me at around 3000 units in a battle (stack v. stack on large unit size). So I had to turn unit size to small and now I can take up to 1 stack vs 2 stacks without lag.*It really is amazing how far this game has come. I ran out of characters right here, go watch "why rome 2 failed" vid to see why it got the well deserved low ratings before.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												No realm conquest in MP, single player game is horribly broken in both the strategic and tactical layers. Game feels completely unfinished, even compared to Empire Total War.Strategic game takes forever, you will be autocompleting battles for 90% of the time you spend on the strategic map because you know you won. Once you're bigger than 3 or 4 provinces no AI player will be able to stop you because they will all be puny. Enjoy spending another 100+ turns of next turn and becomming even more lopsided as you tech up and grow your economy. The map and world are setup for a Roman empire that will never span the Mediterranean like it did historically if the AI controls Rome.Tactical AI needs work, gets stuck in buildings, happily dies vs gate oil in every siege, took several patches to make the amphibious AI work and even then will land in the wrong place at the wrong time all the time. The clean and simple Shogun 2 units have been replaced with a bunch of reskinned slightly alterted units that require constant management for their fireoffs (faster reload for ranged, beserk). Naval battles are completely awful, even worse than Shogun 2.Do not buy on sale even, maybe at a $10/$15 price point.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Its nowhere near as bad as people think it is/want it to be. It isn't a revolutionary Total War game at all,though, and in trying to push the series so many steps ahead they kind of took it a few steps back. The UI in the campaign map is awful,but I really love what they have done with the presentation. This series has ALWAYS been about two gigantic armies fighting, and this game takes that up to 11. People have a lot of rightful frustration with this Franchise for never evolving, and it is not misdirected, its true. People want this game to have the strategic,overall arching aspects of a Paradox game while still having the amazing presentation that Total War is known for, and this game does not do that. This game still has a very bare bones economic system,the diplomacy system is still almost useless and it does not compare to Rome Total War at all.But despite a number of the issues ive mentioned, after all the patches have come through, and even with some frustrating AI (they can be really good or they can be the worst youve ever fought) The game retains the heart of previous TW games. Without a doubt,the glory and spectactle of Epic Total War battles is still there. And its a good game with that.I definitely reccomend it.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Okay, honestly, this is a good game.  The vast majority of the extremely harsh criticisms about this game are purely based on very, very high standards.  The AI is not as good as it could be, but after 7 patches the game has greatly improved.  The campaign world itself is immersive and beautiful to look at, although you should expect to have a decently powerful machine to see it in its whole glory.  Nearly every faction has a unique feel to it, although some more than others, most notably the Romans, Germanic tribes, and the far east factions.  The battles themselves are pretty graphically demanding, and most of the time way too short.  It bugs me when I command a battle involving over 3000 soldiers, yet the action is over in an extremely unrealistic 15 minutes.  But nonetheless, the battles are very enjoyable and look stunning and realistic if seen with a powerfulish machine,(especially with the Blood and Gore pack) and the Creative assembly does a very good job of building off of what they were able to accomplish in Shogun 2.  Overall the diplomacy is tolerable, and greatly better than anything before Empire: Total War.  What Rome II does very well is really give off the vibe of the ancient world; whether it be armies on the battlefield or the clash of cultures on the campaign map, it is a satisfying feeling when the factions feel alive and independent.  I have been an avid player of the Total War games since the original Rome, and its extremely refreshing to witness the ancient world in new-found light.  Bottom line:  Rome II has weak points, no doubt, but its worth playing if you have enjoyed other TW games and, when seen in its full glory, is by far the best looking TW game, especially on the battlefield.  I would recommend it. 8.5/10

This game still has a very bare bones economic system,the diplomacy system is still almost useless and it does not compare to Rome Total War at all.But despite a number of the issues ive mentioned, after all the patches have come through, and even with some frustrating AI (they can be really good or they can be the worst youve ever fought) The game retains the heart of previous TW games. Without a doubt,the glory and spectactle of Epic Total War battles is still there. And its a good game with that.I definitely reccomend it.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Buggy release, full of disappointments (especially for total war series fan which pre-order the game, like me). The combat system was very unbalanced and the AI was a disaster in September 2013 when the game was launched, on top of that, a lot of cool features were missing (seasons, family tree, politics etc.). So I understand the people that were complaining about the game. But now after 10 patches the game has improved a lot, more factions, the AI is a lot better (still sucks at sieges, but can pose quite a challenge for inexperienced players in land battles, especially in higher difficulties, due to morale buffs to his troops), seasons are now reintroduced (in latest LC), wonders are repaired and visible in battles,  the battles feel more balanced and require more tactics (especially when outnumbered), the troop variety has greatly increased (if you include the DLC's packs) and for 2.5 EUR you can have blood effects. Anyway it's starting to become a very good game, it's extremely addictive and the hours of gameplay can be from a few dozens to thousands (if you want to finish the game with every faction) + if you include the DLC CiG and HatG, + the bonus provided freely by mods, can last forever. The price demanded today of 55 EUR is worth it (it wasn't worth it when it was launched) and if you include the 2 good DLC's (CiG and HatG) 15 EUR each (Greek and Nomadic factions DLC's are 7.5 EUR each but it's better to get them at a discounted price because they don't really offer too much content, I got them for free: Greek DLC because of preorder, and Nomadic DLC because of promotion), + Beast of War pack and Blood and Gore pack 2.5 EUR each, you will reach at a price of 90 EUR, which is quite a lot for a game (Advice: Easter is coming, and there will definitely be a lot of discounts, Rome 2 was at 50% discount during Christmas, so if you want to save money, it will be better to wait) but we are talking about a game that offers hundreds/thousands of hours of gameplay, not some Call of Duty that you can finish in 6-10h max, for 50 EUR, so if you are a history fan, like me, it's definitely worth the price tag. I also would like to mention that there are still some great features missing: Family Tree, Politics, Good Siege AI etc. but hopefully CA will add them in the near future. In the end, I REALLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME, because with all the bugs at launch, with all the bugs in the present and with all the missing features, it's still the best history RTS game on the market (with no real challenger to his genre), the thrill of battles is priceless.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Absolutely stunning! The user interface is a little tricky to get to grips with but once you understand it it is incredibly versatile! The graphics are absolutely gorgeous. I love zooming in to see my vast armies up close just before an assault. The diplomacy screen now makes it nice and easy to work out your trade agreements and alliances e.t.c. It gives you a breakdown on what is affecting your relationship with another faction so you can adjust your actions accordingly which is a huge improvement over previous Total War titles. There are still a few bugs here and there at the time of writing this review (08/03/14) but Creative Assembly have been working as hard as possible and releasing patches every week to get the game up to standard which is great! I would recommend modding the campaign game so that each year takes 4 turns instead of 1 as your generals seem to pass away from old age rather quickly otherwise. There is plenty of support for this game and an incredible amount of mods knocking around now too! Definitely pick it up if you like historical strategy games!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												So i picked up this game on sale December of 2014.  I have never played the Total War series so the entire series and mechanics were new to me.  Let me start off by saying that this is one of the best games I have played hands down.  I had heard a lot of issues with it when it first came out, but in the Emperor edition I have found nothing of issue.  I am a huge history fan, with Rome being my favorite, so this game really hit all the sweet spots for me.  Historically its pretty accurate, units, buildings etc. are all excellent.Gameplay wise there is a bit of a learning curve.  Tactically its very satisfying to command an army against odds the computer says you will not win and wipe the floor with the invading force.  I particularly enjoyed taking command of artillery units and turning the tide in battle.  I still haven't quite figured out the happiness/order formula in the game, so every now and then I had a wave of slave revolts to contend with.  That always seemed to be when I was militarily reaching so perhaps its a byproduct of not tending to my conquered settlements as much as i should have.  On a side note i liked the nod that gave to HBO's Rome series in the skill cards you can assign generals (XIIIth !!!!!!!!).Overall I am really happy with the purchase I made.  This is a game I'll be spending a lot of time with I can already tell.  The DLC is fun if not game changing.  Caesar in Gaul is a fun romp through the Gallic Wars.  The only critique I can give on it is that its just a larger campaign map for the Gaul area.  The Roman Civil War is fun to play (shots out to Octavian), and overall its worth the buy when on sale.All in all I'd rate IX/XROMA INVICTA

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Since I've played a few more Total War titles, both new and old, I can finally decide how I feel about this game.Graphically, it is stunning. The details are amazing, the effects, divine. However in the heat of battle one cannot pay much attention to these details.The AI is... interesting, the AI strategy is to either rush the capture points (or you), or just stand there and wait. I've rarely seen flanking manouvers or kinks and vees.Compared to the other total war games, Shogun, Napoleon, Attila, it is very buggy and flawed. There is untapped potential, there are bugs and glitches, and there are useless features. On it's own, this game is very very good.Since this was my introductory game to the series, it holds a special place in my heart, buts it's brothers and sisters just put it to shame.Also: Strategery simulator 11/9

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												- nutshell - worse in every single way compaired to rome1 except for the graphics which look awesome when viewing the fights on the battlemap. but still recomended because it is still a good game in its own light and also really where else are you going to go for this stuff -nutshell - -strategic map   -cons                       -city building- less options and freedom when building, following the shogun2 model of 2-6 building plots to    assign  structures tovery dumbed down compaired to rome1, medieval2 method                       -3 types of agents avalible but very limited cap on each type in early game and still quite restrictive in late game, also no action videos, wtf CA seriously                       -armies are capped now not just by what you can support but by an unexplained arbitary number, so if you feel like leaving some extra men to suppliment your garrisons you had beter be prepared to sacrifice a whole stack from your total forces even if you only want to leave 2-3 units it counts as a whole stack to the total                       -deplomacy is dumbed down compaired to previous games. simple options and less freedom.    -pros                       -pretty, the graphics have, as would be expected, been updated durring the last decade                        -i find myself liking the army personalisation, each army has its own legacy and like the generals in shogun 2 they gain experiance and can choose skills/perks/new attributes from a set for their current level.this allows you to craft an army into siege experts, veteran attackers or defenders, occupation troops with a bonus to public order   ect                       -city models on the map accurately reflect the battle map, which i just think is kinda cool-Battle map    -cons                       -AI, the ai is just plain, old fashioned stupid. forget flanking, faints, tactical formations or any resemblence of inteligence. most battles just end up with the ai throwing its units at you until you break or they do.  i can count on one hand how many times i have seen a tactical manouver by the compon minor town siege battles the ai just throws its men down the shortest distance to the town center with no regard to formation or your own unit placement. and on walled towns i have only ever seen an army use 4 ladders (one choice) as the sum total of their siege equipment and they usualy end up just standing infront of your main gate throwing flamming torches at it regardless to whether their ladders reached the walls  or not.you really have to be up♥♥♥♥♥♥creek to lose these sieges, which you can be with not being able to suppliment your garision of two pleb units  with out using a valuable army slot                           -thats actually about it for cons on the battle map for me. most of my other grievances are aimed at particular units like legionarys not being able to throw pilum with out charging first ect.       -pros                            -very bloody pretty.   as a bloke that doesnt mind inviting extra carnage to his army just so he can watch it unfold i really enjoy the new level for graphic fidelity.  watching 4000 odd guys duking i out with graphics that i would expect from some 3rd or 1st person rpgs is very gratifying to watch                           -tactical map is very useful for getting an instant view of your force disposition                            -naval assaults, just so much win.  ive wanted this including since i first watched troy years ago. also allowing tactical assaults on towns and allows fleet crew to assist land armies in city assaults random grippes no sli profile - self explanitary really, this is a huge demanding game, i have two cards, i want to use both of them. CA and nvidia both claim its in the others hands to move forward with the sli compatibility so both are doing bugger all as far is ive heardpaided unit dlc packs with 5 new units in them- just wow CA really. massive kick i nthe balls from what i concidered an oldschool, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t company.expecially annoying after i played 40 quid for the preorder anyway and then want 3-5 quid a pop for stuff thats avalible free from the workshop.if you have played total war from empire onwards then would will love this thisif you are still hanging on from before that then things will annoy the crap out of you but you will still love it

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I was very hopefull for this game, and have given it chance after chance to impress me. However I really feel that this is a good reprasentation of how the gamming industry has gone down in quality over the years. what I mainly mean by saying that is that companies used to make sure a game was a good complete final product before they released it. now though it seems that every game is released far to soon becuase the companies didnt budget properly for the release. meaning that we get a half♥♥♥♥♥product until they are able to fix the bugs. this means that the game has had to have like somewhere in the realm of 30 updates since its release in october. one update totally made the game completley unplayable, and SEGA was interely unhelpful in helping me getting the game running properly again. I had to have my entire computer memory wiped by geek squad (something that cost me upwards of $200) just to get the game playable again. The positives: it is a very epic and large game with many improvements from the original rome total war. the campaign map is much larger and more in depth. The battles have the ability to have blood and gore and are much more fluid than the original rome total war. Negatives: the load times on this game are a huge low point. sometimes it will take 15 min just load a saved game. also the turns sometime take 10-15min just for the other nations to do there turn, during which time you better be moving your mouse around or the game will just dump you back to the dexktop becuase it thinks ur idle if you dont move th mouse in 60 seconds now. And the constant updates are really starting to get so old that i am about to be completley over this game. the past 4 times I have come to play the game I have had to wait upwards of 30min to an hour just for some new stupid update to be downloaded. Just to play the game. this is far to much waiting and waiting and waiting just to play a game. I really hope someone from SEGA reads this and realizes that people do not appreciate being sold half completed products. oh and maybe they could make the game work properly instead of constantly focusing on putting out new DLC. just so they can make another cheap quick buck. very disapointed in a company I have supported since the mid 90's.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Total War: ROME II is an immersive and very in depth strategy game that offers countless hours of fun. The single player campaigns are grat tests for the players ability to keep their chosen empire under control. The real fun is in multiplayer, grab a friend and start either working together for the greater good, or drive a dagger in their neck. Total War: Rome II is one of my favourite strategy games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Combat in this game is not as fun as Attila; trade is not as fun as Empire. That said, it's a well-rounded Total War experience. Unless you're trying to run it on your Mac. Don't. It has nothing to do with how good your computer is and everything to do with how little Sega cares about good code. It will crash constantly on any Mac platform. Ignore the little Apple symbol on the store page. For transparency, I would recommend this game on PC as it plays fine on my Windows partition, but am giving it the thumbs down from Caesar for the unbelievably bad compatibility issues on the Mac.Pros:- Excellent graphics, truly stunning on higher settings- Many traditional TW elements, such as the context-specific generals speeches before a battle- Lots of little details, like snippets of dialog you can hear when zoomed in on a unit- Beautiful, if intermittently disorienting, world map- Characters and Agents are customizable as they advance, unlike many other iterations of the game- Famed units can be re-founded after they are destroyed and regain hard won characteristics- Expansions, expansions. Lots of different scenarios, though the mechanics of each aren't quite as creative or interesting as Medieval's expansions or Attila's Horde Mode.- Naval combat actually makes sense.- Combat itself plays very differently from other period TW games; if you try to play it like Medieval or Empire, you will lose. Much like medieval tactics likely wouldn't work in the ancient world.Cons:- Trade is not as interesting as Empire or as easy to follow as Medieval- Faction system and internal politics remain somewhat opaque; for example, I can't for the life of me fathom why I would want to assassinate my own guys, but it seems like something I'm supposed to do. Faction events are basically just luck of the draw, pick an answer and hope it's right.- Factions lack individual character in many places, perhaps partly due to the sheer quantity of them- Still suffers from performance issues on PC, even when you discount the abominable release. Often unplayable on Mac.- Sometimes becomes repetitive or bland as campaigns draw on; new enemies offer few new challenges.- Balance of settlement construction is still pretty wonky, you'll spend an awful lot of slots on public order buildings instead of exploring the tech tree. You can master Public Order, but it's like pulling teeth.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I preordered Rome 2 before it came out and paid A$89.99 for it. The game was an absolute disaster. Two years on, it is now pretty fun to play although there are still many small flaws remaining - incorrect unit descriptions, incorrect piercing damage, no hoplite phalanxes, weird projectile damage,  etc etc. However, the game is a vast step forward from Rome 1 and a number of quality of life improvements are evident. Overall I enjoy the game, although now that i've played a few campaigns as various factions the game is all starting to feel very samey. Expect to lose battles to the AI now, although later in the game it becomes a big steamroll as usual.Romans have the best roster by a country mile, and by contrast some other factions can feel quite bare, especially when you get bigger. As it stands, I would give Rome 2 a 7/10 and pay up to A$30 for it, given the time you'll get out of it. The only DLC i have is Greek City States (free with pre-order). I am considering buying one or two of the campaign packs on special.  I have given the game a thumbs down because at release, it was absolutely appalling, around a 3/10.

												I have been playing the Total War series for a while now and Rome 2 has a fantastic campaign system. The graphics are amazing in ultra or high settings. There is a great range of factions and the province system really works well.However, the game feels under optimized and I also feel that the multiplayer system has many flaws as it is very hard to get people to join your battle. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												It's hard to say no to a Total War game since I've loved every single version so far, even Empire Total War. However, if I had knew about the bugs and glicthes on launch, I probably would have waited for the game to be fixed. That being said, it's been a few weeks now and the game is starting to look pretty good. Gameplay wise, the game is the same as any of the other Total War games. There a few new features added in, and most have improved the game. For example, Siege battles are a bit more challenging and now you have restrictions on how many armies/navies you can have, which is good because the AI doesn't spam like 50 small armies anymore. Speaking of the AI, it's probably the only thing I have to complain about. It still sucks, but the AI is defintely an improvement over Shogun 2. However, I still find it stupid when I see a whole unit of swords charge head first into my pike formation. The Graphics are really nice, but sadly you require a pretty good computer to run things on High/Ultra. I'm currently running on Medium with an i3. However, the graphics are still beautiful and the animations are really exciting, as the battles feel pretty real now. Overall, I recommend this game for everyone to try. However, make sure you have an i5 and a good video card to unlock all the wonderful aspects of this game.
